PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and—by leave—read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to advise honourable senators that the printed copy of the daily Senate Hansard for last Saturday, 18 December, will be available within the next hour to an hour and a half. The electronic version is now on the parliamentary database service, accessible from the personal computers in senators' offices. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the staff of Hansard, the Sound and Vision Office and the Parliamentary Information Systems Office who worked throughout Saturday, and in some cases Sunday, to support the Senate—and I should include all parliamentary staff that worked at that stage.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tambling—What about the Transport Office?

TALK.START.PARA: —I said all staff.
—I endorse those comments about the staff. It is a pity the government did not realise the consequences to the staff.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely a motion to give precedence to a motion to defer further consideration of the Native Title Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: It is time that this farce was brought to an end. If ever there was an understatement, it is probably the word `farce'. The government has brought us back here again because it says that this bill depends upon a fragile consensus. We now see that the fragile consensus has collapsed. When one reads the headlines in the Australian this morning, one sees that rural communities, as far as they are represented by the NFF, have abandoned—

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr President. I indicate to Senator Hill that the government will not contest this particular motion if he wants to put it now and proceed to the substantive motion.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Hill) agreed to:
That a motion to defer further consideration of the Native Title Bill may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business until determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That further consideration of the Native Title Bill 1993 be an order of the day for the first day of sitting in 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: What I started to say on the suspension motion is that we have been recalled in farcical circumstances. The government, I think, has forgotten that this is the week before Christmas. This is the week when not only parliamentarians, who are not perhaps of such consequence, but the staff of this place and of the parliament—the clerks, Hansard, the security people, the transport people; and the staff of parliamentarians as well—have obviously made other arrangements.

PARA.TAB: This government set down a legislative program for this particular session. It was due to end last week. In normal circumstances the business of the parliament could have been disposed of within that timetable. However, this government is so determined to get through this piece of legislation, whatever deficiencies might be incorporated within it, it has broken its timetable. It required that the parliament not only sit ridiculous hours last week but sit on Saturday, to the inconvenience of all the parties I have just mentioned—and now we are dragged back here on the week before Christmas as well.

This is not the environment within which sound legislative decisions are made. I would have thought that was an understatement. The reason we have been dragged back here is that the government is concerned that what it calls its `fragile consensus' for the Mabo legislation might collapse if there were any delay. Mr President, we made the point last week that a fragile consensus is not a sensible foundation for legislation of this kind; legislation that has within it the potential to create such community disharmony and stress. We said last week that this legislation needed at least a sound foundation and that the government ought to go away and see whether it could build that sound foundation within the community.

I would have thought that that was a sensible and rational request. We have talked about setting up select committees that would enable the parliament to deal with that in a sensible way; committees that can go out into the community and talk to the people not only about the government's proposed piece of legislation, but also about what the states are either in the process of enacting or have enacted, how both can possibly mesh together and how it would be possible to build within this country a cooperative scheme to deal with native title as has been determined by the High Court.

Native title as determined by the High Court is not in dispute and the need to comply with Commonwealth legislation such as the Racial Discrimination Act is not in dispute, but there are many management questions that arise out of the High Court decision on Mabo No. 2 that do need to be dealt with through a cooperative federal-state arrangement. If they are not, then uncertainty will continue and it will be at a cost to economic development, particularly pastoral, mining and tourism development. But it will also be at a cost to Aboriginal people who wish to have the concept of native title enacted in statutory law so that how it is to work, how it is to be claimed, how it is to be protected and so forth can be set down in the black letter laws of this country.

I regret—I say this with the benefit of hindsight—that when Mabo No. 2 was put down we did not quite see the difficulties that it would raise. A sensible approach would have been—as was suggested to the Senate committee by Mr Caston QC—that the governments of Australia, both federal and state, immediately set up a royal commission and take it out of the political arena. A royal commission could have looked at all the technical, management and social issues that would arise out of Mabo and put a formula to the parliament out of the political environment within which there could be a state and federal program for implementing the changes into statutory law that are necessary as a result of that case.

That would have been a sensible approach, but apparently it was not thought of and time has gone by. I am still not sure that it might not be the best way to go now. But a royal commission, of course, is outside the hands of the parliament. What the parliament does have is the capacity to set up its own committees that can deal with the detail of these matters. I know that there is some concern that the committees of the parliament are too political—that they are just part and parcel of the political process. I do not think that is necessarily a weakness; in fact, it can be a strength, because it is the democratic process being implemented in another way. Constituencies express a voice through the parliamentarians in this place and I, for one, am not particularly afraid of that. A properly balanced select committee set up by this chamber, which has a fine record in these matters, would have had the opportunity, as I said, to go out into rural and regional Australia and talk to those who are most affected by Mabo No. 2 and to come back to this parliament with recommendations as to how Mabo No. 2 might be most effectively implemented through statutory law.

The government was not prepared to do that. The only reason is that it has said that Mr Keating has conducted his own process of inquiry. He has called upon and brought in only those whom he believes it is necessary for him to listen to. He has come to a determination on that basis. He is determined to ram that decision through the parliamentary process because otherwise there is a certain loss of face to him. That is an unsatisfactory way to do things. We all know that what he would like to do with this chamber is just have us act as a rubber stamp in these circumstances, but we are not prepared to do that.

Mr President, it is not too late for the parliament to adjourn this matter, take it out of this farcical environment in which it is now placed and set up a select committee. This select committee could be properly representative of this chamber and therefore of the various viewpoints within the Australian community. This committee would have the capacity to commission expert advice; call upon such specialists as may be necessary to deal with the highly complex legal questions that this chamber has been wrestling with over the last few sitting days; deal with the problems of maintaining social cohesion through such a traumatic experience as seems to be developing in this process; and deal with the economic questions that will arise out of the fact that the title of pastoral leases is under question. There is uncertainty in future mining developments, which is not in the national interest at a time when we are trying to pull this country out of recession and provide jobs for the almost one million unemployed.

All these matters could be dealt with in a sensible, rational way by calling upon the best possible advice that is available out there in the community; objective advice that is outside the parliamentary process but which can be brought into that process by means of a select committee of this parliament. Would that not be a sensible, rational way to deal with this matter? When this parliament meets again in early February—which is only two months away—the debate would be based upon better facts and better legal advice, and those uncertainties would be removed. I would hope that out of that process could come a legislative result that would be very much more in the interests of the Australian people than what we are getting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Take a point of order.
—I am trying to give a speech; you take a point of order.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the point being made is that the family is meeting at the end of the room again; that is, the three principal factions—the ALP, the Australian Democrats and the Greens. They are deciding whether to foist this on the Australian people today, even though what we know has occurred over the weekend is that the fragile consensus has collapsed.

PARA.TAB: The mining community has now abandoned this process. The rural community has abandoned this process. The states are abandoning this process. I wonder whether the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) heard Premier Goss on AM radio this morning. Everyone recognises that this farce is leading only to bad law and the potential for social and community stress. What is occurring in this place today is not in the national interest—and the government knows it.

I make a simple plea at this late stage to those that I hope could be a little independent of this government and little more rational and sensible than this government that is, of course, being driven by the ego of Mr Keating. I ask the Democrats and the Greens: Are they interested in sensible process? Are they interested in good quality law? Are they interested in social cohesion? Or do they want to put all those at risk by a process that has developed, as I said, into no more than a farce?

This may be their last chance to get it right. I just say to them that they should take this last chance and say, `We want to end this silly nonsense and the harm that is being done to the staff and to the spirit of the parliament'. They should bring this to an end and allow us to do our job properly within reasonable time constraints. This is their chance. We will see now whether the Greens and the Democrats, having reflected upon the collapse of the so-called fragile consensus over the weekend, are now prepared to accept their national responsibility and support this motion. Let us do things in a sensible way.

TALK.START.PARA: —This attempt by the coalition is yet another example of how it wants to delay the substantive business of this house. It continues the tradition of the first three weeks in this parliamentary sittings when we had hardly five hours of dealing with substantive legislation. All the coalition is doing is obstructing and wasting time. The reality is that we have started to debate this bill constructively; amendments have been moved and have been either rejected or accepted.

PARA.TAB: I would remind the coalition that the Australian Democrats opposed the government's amendment to clause 24. If coalition senators had really wanted to get that principle up on behalf of the pastoralists and the mining industry, they should have joined the three National Party senators who crossed the floor. But they did not. They might now realise their mistake, but that is no reason to hold up the further consideration of this bill.

We need to get into this legislation and deal with it substantively. Aboriginal people have waited long enough. It is time that we did something to put a base of justice in our dealings with the Aboriginal community. If the coalition thinks it will tire us out, I believe that it has made a wrong judgment. This is one bill where an endurance test will work against the coalition. It has simply picked the wrong bill. If necessary, we will sit until New Year's Eve.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to the opposition that, while the Greens (WA) agree with the concerns about the way in which the bill has been dealt with, at this point we do not agree to defer it when we really need to keep pressing on with it. The point still has not been reached where we find this bill acceptable, but we want to have the chance to fight some of those amendments and the clauses that are yet to come. So we will not be supporting this motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear from what has been said by Senator Spindler and Senator Chamarette that there is manifestly not majority support in this chamber for adjourning consideration of this legislation in the way that the opposition proposes, nor should there be. We are debating, in a measured and I think reasonably sensible fashion, the substantive issues that are involved. We have been debating them for some 19 hours already, and we are perfectly prepared to go on debating them until the debate is concluded. We will do so—and it is entirely appropriate that we should do so—because of the significance and importance of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Under these circumstances, might I suggest to you, Mr President, and to other honourable senators, that there is no point in prolonging further a procedural debate of this kind. Accordingly, I move:
That the question be now put.
Question put.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Original question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Hill and pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion relating to the conduct of business of the Senate, namely a motion, moved before the resumption of the committee of the whole on the bill, to provide for the reference of proposed amendments to the Native Title Bill 1993 to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: If we ignore for the moment the sort of ideological response we get from the Senator Spindlers of this world, who want to pretend that nothing has changed over the weekend, we find that there have been some critical developments in this debate which make it abundantly clear that no-one, including the government, has the least idea of the legal implications of these clauses. We have already had three separate clauses deferred for further consideration. We have had the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) indicating that amendments are being drafted but that he cannot foreshadow them at this stage. Now we have an indication that the Democrats may be looking at further amendments. In other words, we are being asked to give a blank cheque to one of the most important pieces of legislation ever to come before this chamber.

PARA.TAB: The position of the National Farmers Federation is a classic example of the dangers involved in proceeding any further down this path. Two weeks ago, the National Farmers Federation, and Mr Farley in particular, was arguing that the bill, unamended, had to be supported in the best interests of all concerned—presumably that included farmers and miners—and therefore there was no need for any amendments. Now we find that when the Democrats' refusal to support a particular amendment results in that amendment being defeated, the National Farmers Federation withdraws its support for the legislation, arguing that it creates too much uncertainty about land title and rights.

There is no-one out there, apart from the ideologues, who would argue that this legislation is sufficiently clear in purpose and intent to be allowed to proceed in its present form. We still have heaps of amendments to deal with. We still do not understand the full implications of them. The government can do its best on the run, but, as we have seen on three separate occasions, the government has had to defer consideration—on the second occasion on the initiative of Senator Chamarette, who, of her own volition, acknowledged that it would be wrong to proceed further with debate on that particular clause. In other words, there is an acknowledgment on both sides of the chamber that there are very great dangers in proceeding to deal with matters in the dark.

I do not know whether Senator Chamarette heard what I said; it is very important that we all appreciate this. After the government had been forced to defer consideration of one clause and we came to another clause, Senator Chamarette actually got up and moved that we defer consideration of that clause as well. All parties agreed with that. That is a classic indication that on both sides of the chamber there is an acknowledgment of the dangers involved in trying to get these things right on the run. In those circumstances, what is critically important, if those opposite are interested in fairness and justice, if they are interested in not just squeezing out—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: can these caucus discussions, between Senator Evans and the Democrats, take place outside in the lobby?
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Evans is sitting down now.
—This is a gross obstruction, Mr President. It is interference with their thought processes.

—Order! When I am speaking or standing, there will be silence. A meeting of about eight people took place here just a few moments ago and I let it go. If you raise the point of order I will sit the minister down, but there has to be a bit of give and take.
—I take it that such a point of order would not come out of my speaking time.
—No.

—If anyone in this chamber is interested in fairness and justice and ensuring that any bill that goes through this parliament has the effect intended, surely those opposite would have to agree that the legal implications of this matter need further consideration. This morning, when Premier Goss was asked whether the deal was falling apart, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we're certainly very worried. I've got officers urgently trying this morning to find out what the hell is going on in Canberra.
Later, he said:
. . . we understand there is hundreds of amendments or hundreds of pages of amendments being introduced into the Senate.
He continued:
We may have to bail out of the process.
He also said:
. . . we're quite concerned that the whole package might be going off the rails.

There we have someone who was hitherto a strong supporter of the legislation. We have had Mr Farley, who made a fool of himself in front of the nation by giving a blank cheque to the bill, now realising that it needs amendments—amendments so vital that he has withdrawn support for the bill because the very same amendments for which he did not see a need two weeks ago have not gone through. So we have a situation where even one of the government's strongest supporters now recognises that it is absolutely imperative that the legal consequences of these amendments be exposed to further consideration. I know that honourable senators opposite do not give a damn about that; they are only interested in getting any bill through at any time. We are not. We are here to see that the matter is properly and carefully considered. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will obviously oppose this motion for exactly the same reasons as earlier given. It is a repetitive motion and the opposition is in grave danger of stretching rulings that have previously been made about misusing the time of the Senate by making successive contingent motions for suspension. But we will come to that should the opposition subsequently try this on again.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I would have thought that anything that follows from what Senator Gareth Evans said is irrelevant. Mr President, you should point out to him that this is not a re-run of the previous motion. The previous motion was in relation to the whole of the Native Title Bill. This is in relation to the legal implications of certain amendments which have not yet been voted on. In those circumstances, we cannot possibly proceed on the basis that this is a repetitious motion. I therefore ask you, Mr President, to direct Senator Gareth Evans to put any remarks that he might seek to make in that context and not on a false premise.

—Order! I have allowed Senator Alston to move this motion. Technically, I believe, it is not in line with the previous ruling that I gave because the same contingency was used. At this stage, I will have to reserve my decision and wait to see whether a similar motion is next moved.

—Then, Mr President, let me deal with the terms of this motion, since it appears that we will be debating it for what is left of the half-hour. I have only this to say: there is no justification for adjourning the whole debate on the basis of a proliferation of amendments. We already have before us in the chamber all remaining government amendments we propose to move in the course of this debate—save and except for the possibility that it might be necessary to later respond in a corrective way to something not yet foreseen. I do not expect that to be the case.

PARA.TAB: There are only three remaining government amendments before us. The first is government amendment No. 75 on the body corporate question, which goes to a number of different clauses but with the same basic theme. The second is government amendment No. 69A, which relates to clause 238. The third government amendment is No. 50A relating to clause 208. There are a number of Green and Democrat amendments in circulation. I believe that just about every amendment proposed to be circulated has already been circulated and we have all had ample opportunity to look at them. There is simply no substantive justification for what opposition senators are doing.

As to the extraneous material that has been introduced by Senator Alston I simply say this: it is the case that as of two or three weeks ago the National Farmers Federation and similar groups were content with the terms of the Native Title Bill. However, they have since decided that they want further reassurance of a belt and braces kind in relation to two or three clauses. Also, a couple of problems were shown up by the Senate standing committee inquiry, particularly the definitional problem about water and the onshore application of the bill. It was necessary to clarify industry concerns about the water matter. While it was not necessary, it was, in our judgment, desirable to clarify industry concerns about clause 24 and related matters. In total good faith we, the government, went down that particular path.

For the record, let me correct any suggestion that might be made or that has been made from any quarter that there was some sort of a wink and a nod deal between the government and the Australian Democrats on the voting down of clause 24. I made it absolutely clear and the government made it absolutely clear at all relevant stages of the discussion that we wanted this amendment, that we wanted the Democrats to vote for it, and that we would take whatever risk was associated with that amendment when it came to the third reading vote. That has been our position over the course of the last two or three days and that remains our position.

At issue here is not only the good faith of the opposition but also its sheer intellectual capacity to work out the interests of the various groups it is purporting to assist. Any reasonable person would have seen that it was of assistance to the fishing industry to pass the clause yesterday that the opposition helped to defeat. Any reasonable person would have seen that it was in the interests of the mining industry to pass the clause relating to the amendment to the arbitral process which the opposition served to defeat. Any reasonable and sensible person would have seen that it was manifestly in the interests of the legislation to pass the clause 24 pastoral industry and mining industry provision which the opposition—which the Liberals—again served to defeat. Those opposite have made absolute fools of themselves over this issue. They should not try any more diversionary manoeuvres of this kind.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now facing a $500,000-a-day farce to keep this parliament sitting. The legislation cannot go through as it is. If it does, those opposite will close down the pastoral industry and they will close down the mining industry. That is a fact of life. We are talking about a $37 billion industry that those opposite will cut the legs from underneath; that is a fact of life.

PARA.TAB: The government's bill has failed. The government has had its chance. It has done its deals and it could not deliver. Any sensible, responsible government would say, `We did our best. We tried to get it through', and would then admit that it had failed. But, no, the government will put Australia at risk—the rural industries, the pastoral industries, the mining industries at risk—because it does not have the courage to back away from something that it cannot deliver.

This debate is now not for the good of Australia; it is for the good of Mr Keating to save his political neck. To save his political neck, government members are wrecking Australia. They are putting all the wealth creating industries at risk—$37 billion worth of industry at risk. There are 470,000 people employed in the mining and pastoral industries, and government members have put those people's jobs at risk. Those opposite have failed, and we are going through this $500,000-a-day farce to keep these two houses of parliament sitting.

Those opposite knew, Rick Farley knew, the mining industry knew and everyone else in Australia knew that this bill would fall to the ground unless clause 24 got up. Government members could not deliver that, so they now have to face the reality of the situation. The reality of the situation is that the government should get this parliament up, go back and redraft the clauses, send a Senate committee out to find out what is wrong with this bill and then try to do a deal with the whole of the parliament so it can get the legislation through. Pursuing this current course of action is just a waste of taxpayers' money. The government is keeping this parliament sitting up until Christmas. I will sit over Christmas if that is what the government wants to do.

Government members are destroying every decent job in Australia. The government's unionist mates are relying on this legislation, which it cannot get through, to support 470,000 unionists' jobs. The government is putting them all at risk because it cannot get the legislation through. It cannot guarantee their jobs. Those people give $180 of their hard-earned money to pay for government members to keep their party going, and the government is going to betray those jobs. Every one of their jobs in the mining industry and the pastoral industry will be put at risk.

That is on one side of the ledger. Mr Keating's political credibility is on the other side of it. That is the government's idea of balance for the good unionists who support the Labor Party. Those opposite are an absolute bunch of frauds if they go ahead with this legislation. They should sit over there and hang their heads in shame at putting those jobs at risk because they have to protect Mr Keating's hide. They do not have the courage to face up to that. They are a bunch of frauds who will not stand up for their Labor Party unionist colleagues, each of whom every year puts in $180 of his or her hard-earned wages to support this bunch of hypocrites. How can they ever go out again and face a union meeting?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Boswell, you know that `hypocrite' has been ruled unparliamentary many times in the past.

—I withdraw. How can government members attend Labor Party meetings and say, `Brothers, we are for you; don't worry about your jobs. We have just destroyed your jobs, but we're with you, brother; righto, comrade, we've got to face those rotten capitalists'? I know what goes on at union meetings. How can they look them in the face? The fact is the government has been done like a dinner and now it is time to cut for the good of Australia.

—I support the motion moved by Senator Alston that the remaining amendments to the Native Title Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. This farce really does need to be stopped. Senator Boswell thought that the cost of this farce is $500,000 a day. Regardless of the cost, it is a waste of taxpayers' money if we do not get it right.

PARA.TAB: The government, the Greens and the Australian Democrats believe that Mabo No. 2 is the appropriate response. Surely the government has the confidence, through the balance of numbers here, to have the bill passed any time it wants. It would be in the interests of the government's integrity to get the bill right.

I noticed newspapers this morning quoting Senator Kernot that the bill must have integrity. How can it possibly have integrity when amendments were shoved through here on a Saturday and when more amendments have been foreshadowed here today? When we tried dealing with amendments on Saturday, on four or five occasions, Senator Gareth Evans and others said, `There is a problem; we need a bit of time to fix it'. So these matters are postponed and postponed because the government does not realise the consequences of this legislation.

The only way the government will comprehend the consequences is by giving these amendments some decent consideration. I noticed that Senator Gareth Evans has provided himself with an escape clause, which all other government members might like to consider giving themselves. Senator Gareth Evans has covered his own back and left all other honourable senators who have spoken in favour of the bill to wear it.

Senator Gareth Evans covered his own back by adding at the end of his speech a little clause, `save and except any unforeseen consequences'. So he has been the good guy, saying, `It's all okay, except for what we can't see is wrong'. He has admitted the existence of that escape door and, despite acknowledging problems, he has left his colleagues to come out and say, `This bill is right'. Senator Gareth Evans sat here on Friday and Saturday. Time and time again, he wanted to say, `This is just a filibuster, this is an excuse to delay the bill', but he found himself dealing with substantive problems on the bill that need to be properly addressed.

If those on the other side are not a pack of gutless wonders, if they really believe that this is the proper approach to Mabo No. 2, then they should have the stomach to wear the public debate over January and come back in February and get it right. The government will not fall in January: it will have the numbers in the House of Representatives. Labor members would not dare do anything other than what their leader told them. Their leader talks about forelock tugging. There is a lot of forelock tugging going on now with government members competing for the position of Treasurer. They all want to be Treasurer. So we know they will come back in February to support this bill. Presumably Senator Kernot's leadership is safe and her lot will all come back in February.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not bet on that.

—Maybe not; I do not know. I would have thought her position was safe. The Australian Democrats will come back in February and support this bill, as will the Greens. So what is the problem with getting it right this time?

PARA.TAB: Senator Gareth Evans says, `There are only three government amendments left'—a typical narrow focus, as though all this place needs to debate is his amendments, forgetting all the amendments of the Greens and the Democrats that are yet to be dealt with. He is trying to pretend to the media that we are now dealing with a simple problem of only three government amendments. What a lot of rubbish! We have buckets and buckets of amendments left.

Senator Gareth Evans has not told us how many of the Democrat or Green amendments the government will support. We do not know how much time we need to give to their amendments because we have no idea which of those the government is to support. Senator Evans, in trying to say that this is a simple situation, is avoiding the issue of the wide range of amendments put forward by the Greens and the Democrats that deserve to be dealt with.

Last but not least, Senator Evans raised the intellectual capacity of people on this side. For a man who was weeping on Saturday about people being condescending to him and who was saying how ungracious it was, yet again his condescension comes out, yet again political correctness comes out, that unless we agree with him we must be dumb. We obviously got it wrong if we do not agree with Senator Evans.

This is no way to deal with this bill. If those opposite have any stomach, if they are not a pack of gutless wonders, they should at least get the remainder of this bill right and send it off to a committee to get the detailed consideration of the amendments. The government's own Premiers agree that they now do not know what this bill means. The mining industry does not want it; the farmers that it conned do not want it. The government should at least get it right.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have lost sight of the fact that a majority of this Senate voted for the Native Title Bill to proceed. No amount of time wasting, filibustering or everything else that opposition senators want to go on with will distract us. It will not take us away from the vote we took, which is that debate on this bill should proceed to finality. That was a majority decision. It is one that opposition senators find hard to live with. It was a majority decision and we are all committed to proceeding along that way.

PARA.TAB: I remind the members of the opposition that when we resumed this session of parliament we spent three weeks debating procedure. There was no interest whatsoever in legislation. We spent three weeks on procedure and five hours of that three weeks on legislation. Members of the opposition could not care less about the government's legislative program, and they know it. They have no commitment to getting on in a cooperative fashion, hearing the debate—whether they agree with it or not—and getting to the end of the process.

The opposition's tactics are all concerned with distracting attention from Liberal instability, from coalition tension, and they are aimed at getting back at Mr Rick Farley. That is what their tactics are about. They have nothing to do with wanting to improve the legislation. Opposition senators have said they are not interested in improving legislation. They have totally opted out of the process of making this legislation better for the people they represent in this Senate.

They have walked away from their responsibility. They failed to vote for the crucial amendment on Saturday, which protected the interests of the people they supposedly represent in this place. People in the fishing industry, the mining industry and the pastoral industry ought to be asking the fundamental question why.

Senator Boswell, with the greatest of respect to him, chose to go for coalition `stability' and vote against the one amendment that he now criticises everybody else for. That needs to be put on the record in case people tuned their radios into this passionate outpouring only a few minutes ago. What we have to ask about this process is—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Kernot ought to be recorded as voting against it too.
—There is no point of order.

—It is very well known how I voted. I would not want people to be able to hide behind the rhetoric of this morning's emotion. Senator Boswell quite definitely supported the members of the Liberal Party and did not support his three backbenchers who crossed the floor on this matter.

PARA.TAB: Let us ask why we should do what the opposition is seeking to do. Should we take the remaining amendments to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs? I do not believe any purpose is served by doing that. The opposition will have plenty of time in the committee stage that remains—nobody knows how long that will be—to examine each and every amendment yet to come before us. It has plenty of time.

Certainly, we have three government amendments. We also have several Green and several Democrat amendments. We will have plenty of time to examine the impact of those amendments in the normal way in which we do with every other piece of legislation. There is nothing different about the process. If we could get on with it now, we would discover it. The point of this morning's exercise is totally political. The coalition does not care about this bill; it does not care about improving this bill. It cares only about wasting time and about trying to prevent those of us who do care about the rights of indigenous Australians from simply getting to the point of taking a vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. You should remind Senator Kernot that she did not vote to improve that amendment either.

—Dr Martin Luther King once made the observation that where injustice exists it is a threat to justice everywhere. The legislation before the Senate aims at achieving the elimination of historic injustice to Aboriginal people. The Senate ought to be focused upon that and focused upon eliminating—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. We have passed the second reading stage. I know that Senator Loosley might have missed out on that, but the point is that we are debating here an urgency motion as to why it is urgent that the question of deferral be addressed. Senator Loosley should address that subject matter or else sit down.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Senator Bishop has no concept of notions of justice. I would expect that intervention from her. The simple fact of the—
—Mr President, on a point of order: I ask for that remark to be withdrawn. That is a reflection.
—Order! Withdraw.

—If you ask, Mr President, I will withdraw. What do we see from the coalition? As usual, we see a capacity only to seek to frustrate, delay and obstruct. With every major element of this legislation that comes before the Senate, we see the coalition again revert to type. It has become the guardian of gridlock in the Australian parliament. Continually, it seeks only to delay and to defer. Why? In terms of national leadership, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the government have been absolutely unwavering in their commitment to justice and reason. We see opposite an ultimate and catastrophic failure of national leadership on Mabo, just as we have seen on all the other issues that have come before the parliament.

PARA.TAB: In terms of historic record, there is no greater issue of significance than Mabo in relation to what the Australian parliament has been obliged to deal with this year, what it ought to deal with this year, and what it has endeavoured to address consequent upon the High Court decision and the sweeping away of the absurd doctrine of terra nullius. What is the answer? Those opposite again call for another Senate committee with an indeterminate reference, an indeterminate time and indeterminate consequences.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I would ask that you draw to the attention of Senator Loosley: firstly, the terms of reference relating to a select committee that were explicitly put in Senator Hill's motion; secondly, the Hansard; and, thirdly, the report of the Senate select committee which was tabled whilst he was away. Obviously, he has not chosen to read that report. He is totally out of order and has totally missed all of the points in this debate.

—Order! Senator Tambling, there is no point of order. Time limits were placed on these speeches for the very reason that continuous, endless points of order were being taken, such as those that are being taken this morning.

—Late on Saturday night, we had the absolute catastrophe of the coalition once again using its numbers to block reasoned legislation. We now have the utter farce of the coalition endeavouring to blame the government for the fact that its votes defeated the amendment and for the fact that its votes defeated the proposition.

PARA.TAB: This is an absolutely lunatic proposition. The judgment of history in respect of Mabo will be upon the coalition; there is no doubt about that. We are not dealing with judgments to be made this week, next week, or early in 1994; we are talking about the judgment of Australian history, which will be upon the opposition for the ultimate failure that it displays continually.

Why is that so? There is no creativity opposite. Every time Dr Hewson looks for a solution, he has to look over his shoulder. So it was much easier to use 36 blocking votes on each and every occasion that an item of consequence came before the parliament. Let that be on the record. As Senator Kernot made clear, the politics of this chamber in respect of Mabo as far as the coalition is concerned has much more to do with the weakness of its leadership and the vacuum that surrounds it than any other conceivable approach to the legislative merits of the proposal that the chamber is debating.

We have seen nothing but delay, deferral and obstruction from the coalition. When was the last intervention of the coalition on any major legislation that served to better or improve it? Nothing comes to mind. We have a situation where not only the majority of the chamber but the majority of Australians want this resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has concluded.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The rule of the standing orders relating to relevance was not enforced during the preceding half-hour. The time limit that is now required under the sessional order, with five-minute speeches for each honourable senator and 30 minutes for the debate, precludes other senators from debating the issue. Mr President, if you are going to allow the issue to be debated as you have for the last half-hour, then that precludes me from debating that issue. I wanted to say something about the issue. I have another suggestion as to how this matter could be proceeded with, but that cannot be done unless the motion for the suspension is adopted.

—In reply to Senator Harradine's point of order, Senator Harradine is basically correct about relevance. The procedure committee allowed this five-minute debate because of the difficulty that every person occupying the chair was having in enforcing the relevance rule. Senators needed only to mention a word about urgency for it to be relevant again. They are the procedures that have been adopted by the Senate.

—by leave—Mr President, as you know, I have voted for this measure in general terms. On occasions I have voted with the opposition on certain amendments, but I supported the motion for second reading and the key amendments that the government has introduced as to the definition of land, and the protection of the belt and braces, as Senator Gareth Evans said of clause 24. After renegotiation, I voted with the government. If the government felt that these amendments were necessary for the integrity of the bill—and they now have been voted down—we have to question whether the bill now has the integrity that the government considers it ought to have.

PARA.TAB: I am beginning to believe that this matter needs to be looked at again after we have concluded the debate. I am not supporting the truncation of this measure. I think that we should examine, and come to a conclusion on, the amendments. After all of that, I do not see any problem with the whole bill being looked at again once it has been passed.

It depends on the operation of the bill. Clauses 1 and 2 of the bill commence immediately, but the remaining clauses commence on proclamation, unless proclamation has not occurred after nine months. It might be necessary for the bill, once passed, to then be considered further by some committee. It certainly needs to be considered by the government. I am not able to move an amendment to Senator Alston's motion should this suspension go through. That is why I raise the question of relevance. It does preclude that sort of procedure from being presented to the Senate.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Clause 24.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Now that we are all back here, we would be interested to have some sort of guide as to what the government's plans are. Clearly, to deal with the rest of these amendments properly will be several days work. I understand that the House of Representatives is being recalled at 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon. Nobody particularly wants it back here when the business of this place is not ready to be passed on to it.

PARA.TAB: I wonder whether the government might, therefore, give us some indication as to what it has in mind. In particular, has Senator Evans agreed with the minority parties to guillotine this debate, or is he in the process of seeking to negotiate a guillotine, as he does on every other occasion at the end of the session? The Australian Democrats come out and say, `No way will we ever gag or guillotine', and then Senator Evans drops over there and they say, `On this one occasion we will'. That is what happens every time at the end of every session.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. Senator Hill sought leave to ask me a question; he did not seek leave to embark upon a major rave. Could he get on with his question and I will be happy to answer it.

—Mr Chairman, on a point of order, I think this matter can be resolved quite speedily and quickly if Senator Kernot stands up and rules out absolutely any idea that she would support a guillotine. That is all she has to do.
—Stop stunting and get on with it.

—It is not a question of stunting. The government has dragged the parliament back; it has decided to waste half a million dollars a day of taxpayers' money. We would like to know how long the government intends that this farce should continue? Are we staying here after Christmas? What is the government's plan? Clearly, there is an enormous amount of work before the chamber. How many hundreds of amendments are still to be debated? I understand there are more amendments. I understand the Democrats are out there drafting more amendments; the Greens have just circulated more amendments. The Democrats are still out there drafting them, trying to overcome the little difficulty that has arisen as a result of the other night.

PARA.TAB: This will go on forever at the rate we are proceeding now. The government and minority parties have refused to be part of a sensible process to coordinate all this through a Senate committee, so just what is the government's plan as to debating the balance of this bill and the time it will take?

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I have every confidence that, if we do not waste any more time in the way we did this morning, given the number of substantive issues which remain—which are not impossibly large in number even though there are, of course, a great many amendments—a great many of the amendments are in fact technical in character and will not detain us. So far as the government is concerned, the government amendments are, as I said—subject to anything that I do not know about at the moment and cannot anticipate—all before the opposition as proposed on the original running sheet, with three additional ones that were the subject of separate circulation.

PARA.TAB: The opposition has before it I think just about all the amendments that I am aware of that are likely to be moved by the Greens and the Australian Democrats. Senator Hill fulminated a moment ago about another Green amendment—No. 33(b). If he looks carefully, he will see that it is exactly the same as 33(a) that was circulated yesterday; it has just had a change of letter to avoid possible confusion with an earlier amendment circulated either Thursday night or Friday morning and to avoid the possibility of confusion when we come to that in the debate. So it is exactly the same thing; just with a different letter on the top right-hand corner. One or two other smaller matters may emerge over the next couple of days, but basically I can say quite frankly and honestly that, to my knowledge, the chamber has in front of it just about all the material—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just about.

—About 98 per cent—how is that for `just about'? The opposition has about 98 per cent of the material it needs, and certainly any relevant material that may come in will be needed for items or clauses that will be reached much later in the debate. Under those circumstances—given the fact that the opposition has all the material and given that the number of substantive debates that remain are probably no more than 15 or 20 when we look at the different subject matter—I believe it is perfectly reasonable, in view of the time we have left today and the time we have tomorrow, to think in terms of concluding this debate in the Senate by dinnertime tomorrow. That is our intention; that is our target.

PARA.TAB: There are discussions taking place about the possibility of having a more orderly debate in order to secure that particular result with that as the target. I do not know whether it will be possible to reach agreement about that, but there are a great many hours of debate left today, tonight and through until the dinner break tomorrow—a great many hours. It is perfectly possible to contemplate an orderly debate of all substantive issues that need to be debated during that period.

There has been no agreement, although there are some discussions taking place. If the opposition is prepared to contribute to those discussions in the rational and constructive fashion that, despite its public posturing, it has shown on occasion in discussions about the process I have had outside this chamber; if we get some of the cooperation on the subject of orderly process that has been apparent privately from Senator Alston and Senator Hill, whatever honourable senators opposite say and carry on about publicly; if they are prepared to do publicly what they do privately and if they are prepared privately, perhaps in the next couple of hours, to help us a little more to get some order into this debate; then we can have some rational process. But there is only so much hypocrisy that I can put up with.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. For Senator Evans to stand up here and say that Senator Hill and Senator Alston act publicly in a way which is different from conversations they have had with the minister is an absolute outrage and a reflection upon them. I ask that it be withdrawn.

—If it is a reflection upon them, it is a reflection which is thoroughly justified. It sticks a little in my craw having to put up with the amount of hypocrisy that I have to put up with when I know the attitude that has been taken.
—Withdraw! Talk about hypocrisy!
—If you choose to regard it as a reflection, Mr Chairman, I will withdraw. If you so rule of course I withdraw, because any member is entitled to take it as such.

—Senator Evans has withdrawn. I was not going to rule the remark unparliamentary in the spirit of robust debate, but Senator Evans has withdrawn it if it is seen as a reflection upon Senator Hill and—
—If Senator Hill and Senator Alston take offence I withdraw.
—Perhaps a personal explanation.
—Mr Chairman, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Are you claiming to be misrepresented?
—Yes, I am.
—The honourable senator may proceed.

—By way of quick introduction, can I say that I am constantly appalled at the way in which Senator Kernot thinks that discussion in this chamber is superfluous and that the real action is outside. If she thinks that, in the context of a three or four day discussion, we should not move to a personal explanation for a couple of minutes I am even more appalled than I was a moment ago.

PARA.TAB: We are not in the business of promoting a filibuster. That has always been our position. We have therefore taken steps over a period of days to try to organise our program and our response in a considered and orderly way. We have nominated a number of people with special areas of responsibility to ensure that there is not unnecessary duplication and to make sure everyone contributes in a constructive way. I have a list here which I could show Senator Evans to give him an indication of that. It has the government's amendments grouped by subject matter, and we have allocated them to a number of individual senators.

We have made every attempt to ensure that the debate takes place in a constructive manner. I would have thought even Senator Evans would have the grace to concede that—even though Senator Kernot apparently does not think anything ought to be taking place in this chamber. I heard Senator Evans give credit to Senator Ellison the other day. We have raised matters which I think have led to a much higher standard of debate than is often the case in the committee stage.

We know that there is often the temptation for people on both sides of the chamber to just rabbit on; to wander in and make a contribution which covers precisely the same ground as others. Therefore, in terms of our position, I make it perfectly clear that we have never indicated that we expected or wanted the debate to be concluded by a particular point. We certainly did not want to truncate the debate. But we did want to ensure that no-one could accuse us of filibustering and that any contributions that were made, were made after proper consideration in particular specialised areas. That is what we have done to date.

I think the calibre of the contributions has been extraordinarily high, which reflects the seriousness of our attitude toward this bill. That is why I am absolutely appalled to think that Senator Kernot's view seems to be that to do as little as possible is the way to proceed.

Even the minister has generally managed to control his infamous temper on most occasions to the point where he has acknowledged that there have been some very valid questions raised that deserve proper and considered answers. He has got those answers and at no stage has he ever said, `This is a filibuster. You blokes are just playing games. You have said one thing in private and another in public'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I sense one coming on. If you are giving us an assurance now, that is excellent. Thank you very much; I am indebted.

—We do not want people on the High Court who will jump to conclusions and make assumptions about what they think the arguments might be or what they think the parties might intend. We prefer people occupying high judicial office to be careful and considered in their responses at all times. The last thing we would ever want from an aspiring judicial officer to the highest court in the land is to make unwarranted and unjustified assumptions and aspersions about the integrity of any member of this parliament. I hope that if Senator Evans gets this job and has finally given away his ambitions to go to the UN, he will start behaving himself and not reflect adversely on those who in good faith want to contribute to the debate in a sensible manner. We will have Senator Evans's personal explanation and apology right now.

—by leave—I do not want to waste any more time, but I say for the record that I have no aspirations to join the High Court and I have made that perfectly clear. Might we avoid further references of that kind which do simply serve to prolong the debate unnecessarily?
—What about the UN?

—Similarly, I have no aspirations. I go where my party takes me. Can I quickly say in response to Senator Alston that I acknowledge that the great majority of the debate we have had so far on the substantive issues has been fair enough. They have been difficult and complex issues which have required questions. It has been appropriate to seek information and responses and I think the debate has been conducted at a reasonably decent level so far.

PARA.TAB: However, I do want to say that a lot of the issues that we have debated go to the heart and core of the substantive issues involved in the legislation. It is perfectly possible, given the way in which the clauses are constructed, for a number of those issues to be raised on almost infinite occasions over the course of the next two days or more, if the decision were to be taken by the non-government parties to embark upon a general filibuster in an attempt to talk this out. Naturally, the government would be concerned at any sign of that happening and would wish to take steps accordingly.

In any event, quite apart from that concern, there might be some virtue in structuring a debate around those clauses which do obviously demand detailed further consideration, with less time being devoted to those clauses which obviously do not demand that further consideration because they have not been the subject of any foreshadowed amendment or opposition. We will certainly continue to explore the possibility for a more rational ordering of this, bearing in mind the many hours that are left.

Finally, there are many other ways of wasting time and protracting proceedings than by filibustering on the particular substantive clauses. The procedural debate we had this morning, these personal exchanges and so on are obviously further contributions to that. We have already wasted an hour and a half of substantive debating time. Might I express the hope of this side of the chamber, and make a request to those on the other side, that they do understand the seriousness of purpose of the government in getting this legislation through; they do understand our determination to get it through this week; they do understand our willingness equally to debate substantively all the issues that need to be debated; and they will understand in all those things and will cooperate in at least getting a final result on this by the time we rise.

We are perfectly prepared to sit further than beyond tomorrow night, should that prove to be necessary. We are absolutely determined to get this legislation by Christmas and we will take whatever steps necessary to do it. If people are aware of that, maybe there will be a little bit more cooperation in terms of trying to get to that point by tomorrow evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman—
—Is it a personal explanation?

—No, it is not a personal explanation. I am asking the Chairman for some procedural direction. I would like to comment on some aspects of Senator Evans' reply to Senator Hill. Do I have to seek leave to do that?
—The honourable senator requires the leave of the Senate.
—I seek leave to address one point.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise one issue. Senator Evans said that amendment 33A and amendment 33B were in essence the same. If honourable senators look at both the amendments, they will see that one of them is half a page and the other one is a whole page. They are substantially different. I suggest that Senator Evans has not read or carefully studied these amendments.

—Can I explain and cut this short? There was an original amendment 33A moved, then there was a revised one which is much longer and which should have been numbered 33B. When that amendment was put around the Senate on Saturday it had the notation 33A which did produce confusion because senators had both a short amendment and a long amendment with the 33A notation on it. The 33B notation has been put on the longer version. There is clearly a difference between those two. The only amendment that is relevant, as I understand it, is the one marked 33B. I understand perfectly what Senator Crane is saying and it is unfortunate. The only one Senator Crane needs to take notice of is 33B. The others have no status.

—No. Senator Evans does not want me to say this. This confirms precisely and exactly what Premier Goss from Queensland said. He said, `We have amendments on amendments; there is confusion on confusion', et cetera.
—Because this is a parliament. This is a legislative chamber. That is what happens in parliaments—you have amendments.
—Senator Evans does not really want me to say this. Effectively amendment 33B allows those holders of native title to breach by definition the laws of the state.

—I raise a point of order. Senator Crane was given leave in order to raise a procedural question, not to embark upon a substantive debate. The procedural issue must have been resolved by my reply telling him that there is only one of those pieces of paper which has any status, the one marked 33B. Accordingly, any other discussion must be about matters of substance. Senator Crane is now going to those matters of substance. Might I suggest that you ask him to desist, Mr Chairman, and confine himself purely to procedural matters? We will have ample opportunity to debate that point when we get to it.
—There is some validity in what Senator Evans says, but I think Senator Crane said he would only be half a minute so he might take just half a minute.

—I will only be half a minute because this is very relevant to what the minister said. The amendment permits breach of season laws which are administered by state governments, endangered species, flora and fauna laws, pollution laws and noise abatement laws, et cetera. They can kill koalas, platypuses and echidnas and eat them with impunity. Under this amendment they can deliberately light bush fires. This sets up a different class of laws and all the problems with it. There is a significant difference and I believe the minister has misled this chamber.

—by leave—I want to ask a question so that we understand what the government's attitude is to existing clause 11. We had very detailed and substantive debate on clause 11 on Friday. The matter was deferred because Senator Evans said the government was bringing in an amendment to replace the amendment which was foreshadowed and withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: Is the government proposing to bring in such an amendment? If so, is it bringing in an amendment itself or will it acquiesce to somebody else's amendment? If it is to acquiesce to somebody else's amendment, what is the proposed amendment the government is acquiescing to that effectively amends clause 11? How can the minister say that the outline of the debate to be had is clear, defined and understood when he himself clearly misunderstood the impact of clause 11? If we have the opportunity along the way we will go through all the errors that he made in giving answers to questions. We are far from understanding what the issues are to be settled. Very simply, my question to Senator Evans is: where is the government's amendment of proposed clause 11 as it was deferred, or is he still working on it as we speak?

TALK.START.PARA: —Consideration of clause 11 was deferred until we reached proposed new clause 196A; that still remains the case. Proposed new clause 196A has now been moved in the form of Green amendment 33B, to which Senator Crane was just referring.
—Is that on your behalf? Are you inclined to support it?
—Yes, we are inclined to support that amendment. There will be no other government amendment.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, there was some consultation about its terms, as one would expect. I do not know what those opposite are chortling about because that is the way in which the legislative process is supposed to work. If those opposite would prefer us to bring in our bills and sledgehammer them through, the way they do in the House of Representatives, if they would prefer there never to be any input or any amendments moved by anyone else so that it would be just a straight numbers exercise—if that is their approach to the legislative process, that can be accommodated.

PARA.TAB: In this instance, the Greens suggested an original amendment to clause 11 on this question of the application of state laws. However, we did not find that original amendment acceptable. There was some discussion about possible ways of limiting the scope while still opening up the issue of permissible forms of native title activity running conterminously with certain laws of state application. The government is presently disposed towards supporting the Greens amendment, subject as always to the way in which the debate goes. If, when we get to that debate, those opposite can come up with a knock-out blow and show us some fundamental flaw in the way in which that amendment is drafted, we will consider that. We are approaching this in a spirit of constructive deliberation.

If there are any obvious problems in the operation of clauses, if those opposite can show a flaw in something to which we cannot give a sensible and considered response, we will respond accordingly. That is the spirit in which I have approached this whole debate. I have not just pushed the arguments of those opposite away. I have tried to respond meaningfully and systematically to every one of the points that they have raised—I think that they have been a bit surprised at the extent to which I have been able to do so over the last 19 hours—and that will continue to be my attitude.

I want to be personally confident that the government can stand up and defend completely the integrity, the common sense and the consistency of every clause in this particular bill. If, when we get to it, those opposite can point to some flaw in a particular clause—of the kind that they are foreshadowing here—I will be very interested to listen to them and I will respond in a constructive and considered way. That is the approach we are adopting. I think it would be very helpful if all of us approach it in that way, and I acknowledge Senator Ellison and some of those on the other side have done so. They have been seeking to understand what is involved, asking questions and, if they get a reasonably sensible answer, they move on to the next point. That is the way we will do it.

The short answer to Senator Bishop's question is: those matters will be discussed. There is no separate government amendment waiting in the wings to come in and catch those opposite by surprise. The amendment to which we are giving strong consideration and which we are presently inclined to support—subject to what I have just said—is Green amendment 33B. Perhaps we can now get back to the committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On this side of the parliament we have a coalition with the National Party. When, for example, amendments are moved as coalition amendments, people understand that deals have been done between the Liberal Party and the National Party. For instance, the National Party gets positions on the opposition front bench. But where there is evidence in this chamber of a de facto coalition between the government, the Greens and the Australian Democrats with an agenda that we do not yet know about, when the Greens have been allowed to move an amendment that the government in this place undertook to move over two days ago, and when there has been semi-admission of an implicit agreement from the Democrats to a guillotine, I think we are entitled to know what deals have been done along the way to result in this de facto coalition. I ask Senator Gareth Evans to come clean and let us know precisely what agenda he is running: firstly, in terms of deals done for particular amendments; and, secondly, in terms of the future for the guillotine.

—by leave—In future I will not grant leave for questions that are manifestly point scoring exercises. I do not mind in the slightest dealing with substantive issues, I do not mind in the slightest dealing with procedural issues, but, if anyone on the other side is going to get up and seek an opportunity to speak just to make that kind of bucketing political point, he or she cannot expect much cooperation from us.

PARA.TAB: To reply substantively to the honourable senator's statement—to the extent that any part of it deserves substantive reply—of course there has been lengthy discussion over the last few days. The truth of the matter is that there always has to be discussion between us and other parties because we do not have the numbers to pass anything without their support.

We were perfectly willing to discuss the substantive issues with both the Liberals and the Nationals, but the coalition made it perfectly clear from day one that, with this legislation, they are not prepared to go down the path of working together on amendments to improve any part of the bill which may need improving. They have said from day one that they are adopting an attitude of total hostility to it. While they are not acting in quite that way in the chamber—they are asking questions which indicate a willingness to understand the bill and to seek improvements—they have locked themselves in to a crazy procedural and tactical position where they are opposing everything.

That is not the position with the other parties. The other parties are constructively trying to improve the legislation. I am not in the business of doing sordid deals about anything with anyone. I am in the business of getting the best possible piece of legislation that we can. Let me make it absolutely clear that there are many amendments on the list, coming from both the Greens and the Democrats, which the government will not be supporting.

At the moment, amongst other things, we are talking about trying to strip away some of those amendments so that they do not clutter the landscape over the next two days. There are several amendments that we will be supporting; there are many that we will not be supporting. It is not a matter of doing squalid, behind-the-scenes deals. It is simply a matter of this being the only legislative process available to us. We are a legislature; we have to put together the numbers to deal with things. We are not in the business of rubber stamping anything. We would welcome a constructive input from those opposite but, if we are not going to receive any constructive input from them, we have to work with what we get from others. I make no apology for that.

Mr Chairman, might I suggest that we cease this exchange backwards and forwards across the chamber and get on with substantive consideration of the bill. I am perfectly happy to respond to any procedural issues that anyone wants to raise, but I do not think that this political debate is very edifying. It is certainly wasting a lot of time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —With the leave of the Senate, I wish to ask the minister a couple of questions.
—Are they on matters procedural?

—They deal with matters about which the minister has just spoken. They are procedural because they pertain to whether or not the minister wants to finish this legislation by Christmas time. I wanted to ask a question along those lines.
—I would be happy to try to answer it.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard the minister admit that this legislation requires a lot of amendments. Therefore, the details of the amendments require a lot of explaining by the people who moved them. They also require a great deal of scrutiny by this chamber to make sure that they are correct because this legislation is probably the most far-reaching legislation that has been ever brought before this Senate.

PARA.TAB: I ask the minister: is it a fact that he said a little while ago that the government will get this legislation passed willy-nilly by Christmas? Is he trying willy-nilly to get this legislation passed before Christmas because the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made a promise to certain groups in the community that he would have this legislation passed for them before Christmas?

I also ask the minister a question that I asked him the other day. Since the Prime Minister has broken so many promises since the election, why could he not keep his record straight and break another one—the promise to have this bill passed by Christmas—thereby giving this legislation the time it needs by debating it in February? This would mean that we end up with a decent piece of legislation rather than the ramshackle, ragtag bit of legislation that the government, on the minister's own admission, is trying to ram through before Christmas,

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I do not seek leave to reply to that because it was not a serious procedural question. It was just political point scoring of exactly the kind I had indicated that I would be reluctant to grant leave for. I have nothing more to say.
—Senator Vanstone, I am obliged to call anybody who seeks my call, but Senator Evans has indicated that on procedural matters he will be declining leave.
—I seek leave to ask the minister a question—
—A serious question?
—It is a serious question; all I can do is tell him that in advance.
—Can you look me straight in the eye and say that it is?
—Yes, I can.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a discussion this morning about clause 11. As the minister will recall; when this matter was first raised with him, the initial question put to him was whether he had sought any legal advice with respect to this matter. As I understand it, the minister made some remarks about not having checked the archives. But he clearly indicated that in recent times the government did not see a problem with the operation of clause 11 of the bill.

PARA.TAB: Subsequent to that, because we on this side think there is a serious problem with clause 11, a number of matters were raised: whether it could be void due to uncertainty; its application vis-a-vis state laws; the mistakes that were made with the Racial Discrimination Act in terms of not understanding section 109; and that, despite the fact that the minister has raised some examples where the Commonwealth has adopted common law, as I understand it he was not able to raise an example of where the Commonwealth has adopted common law using the words of section 109, `the force of law of the Commonwealth'. That is a distinction I think we had some difficulty getting through. I am not trying to have this debate now; I am just trying to list for the minister the points that—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have just reminded me that I might have it ready to table.

—The minister raised some examples where the common law is incorporated by definition or for convenience sake by using the law of the states, but not an example where it has been by section 109. Subsequently, another case has come to mind—I think it is called In re Uren—where the court held that a law has to be enacted for it to have the force of the law of the Commonwealth. The question is raised then whether that simple one line saying that we give the common law the force of law of the Commonwealth is enough because that may not enact the Commonwealth law. In re Uren—and I invite the Minister to have a look at it—might actually mean that we do have to codify in statute any law before it is able to overtake state laws.

PARA.TAB: The minister obviously knows a lot more about this than I do because he has raised the question. There has been an ongoing debate about whether we can have state and federal common law. This particular case argued that, if we were to say that a body of Commonwealth common law existed, it would not be possible to use that under 109 to override a state statutory law.

Clearly, a number of serious issues with respect to clause 11 have been raised. Accepting the fact that the minister either did not see those issues or think they have the importance we think they have, has he, subsequent to those matters being raised, sought some legal advice? Will he agree, prior to this matter coming back on, to give all members of the parliament the opportunity to see that legal advice well in advance so that, when we do come to clause 11, we will not just go through a rehash of `You think this; I think that' but we will use all the resources available to the parliament to inform ourselves as to the operation of clause 11?

I ask that not just because it would be a sensible way to proceed with the debate—and obviously it would be more informed—but, as the minister presumably understands, if he loses on clause 11 in the High Court of Australia, he has lost the whole thing. So it is a vitally important and central aspect of this bill that was dealt with at some length—and then postponed. I would not want other senators to think that this was just some flippant constitutional issue. This goes to the very guts of the bill. This is similar to the regulations in the Australia Card—bingo, we lose those, we lose the whole bill. This matter is in the interests of the whole chamber. So I ask: has the minister sought legal advice? If he has not, will he, and will he share that legal advice with the parliament?

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The substantive issues that Senator Vanstone raises were ones that I was perfectly prepared to debate again and anticipated having to debate when we dealt cognately with clause 11 and the proposed new section 196A—and that holds.

PARA.TAB: Senator Vanstone has reminded me that I did promise to table the advice that was given to the committee by Mr Robert Orr from the Attorney-General's Department, which dealt with various precedents for the kind of language that is contained within clause 11 and which goes further than the particular precedents that I put out the other day. So I table it now, and that is available for circulation immediately. While tabling that, I also table for circulation information about reservations in state statutes.
