I was asked for that by an honourable senator on the other side on a completely different subject. But I said I would dig out that information and make it available, and I do so now.

As to the larger constitutional question that Senator Vanstone raises, the situation in short is this: I am advised that a quite major piece of constitutional advice was prepared which goes to all the major constitutional issues that were involved in this legislation. The difficulty the government has about making that advice public, of course, is that it was advice given in anticipation of litigation. There is a very familiar principle that applies here about the advice that government takes from its advisers, particularly when produced in contemplation of possible challenge, not normally being made available.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you are asking us to pass legislation that—

—Senator Bishop, please. So I do not think it is appropriate to table that particular document. In the light of Senator Vanstone raising this issue now—and because it is some time yet before we get to this particular clause—I will, however, seek advice as to whether or not it might be possible to put together a piece of paper which deals, at least succinctly—but hopefully effectively—with the basic question of constitutionality: why we think clause 11 is constitutional, and the principles upon which we believe that.

PARA.TAB: I will see whether it is possible to put together something like that in the next few hours. I do not make any firm commitment about that because everyone who is most involved in this whole issue is scrambling about doing other things, and it is very difficult to do these things on the run with the degree of precision that one might like. But we will do our best. It is a fair point, as I acknowledged when we debated the constitutionality issue the last time around, and I will do my best to give those opposite some more information as soon as I can. But, beyond that, I cannot comment further.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank the minister for what he has offered. Obviously, whatever the parliament gets to amplify the knowledge that is at hand for all parties is of some benefit. But I express some concern. When I put my initial questions to the minister about this matter, he was somewhat flippant and indicated that, as far as he was concerned, there was not much advice around about this matter. I am not trying to inflame the debate at all. However, Senator Evans wants consideration from this side for the difficulties he faces; so I am just asking him to have some consideration for senators on this side when we later get slightly different responses to answers he has given us. He has to consider what element of good or bad faith we might attribute to that.

PARA.TAB: The minister says he will see whether he can put together some bits and pieces of advice. He says he wants to keep his advice to himself because it is in anticipation of litigation, which I quite understand. I think I have used the phrase, `This bill is a dead-set ringer for a High Court challenge'. It is no surprise to me at all that he does have advice—which is why I asked the question in the first place—and I was somewhat surprised previously to hear his answer that he did not.

I just hope that some of the people who are supporting this bill consider what they will do if it is struck down. I put to Senator Evans that, if he is going to put together bits of the advice for us to look at, presumably in anticipation of litigation, he will not include the bits that create doubt. So what he gives us will be, quite frankly, less than balanced and perhaps not as useful as it might be.

I understand how on plenty of occasions governments have said that they need to keep advice for a whole variety of reasons—and perhaps in anticipation of litigation is an accepted one. I do not think it is. But on this occasion, I put to the minister that he take back to his colleagues the view that, because this piece of legislation is so important—and as he says there is some urgency to get it through—they need to get it through and they need it to be valid. There is no point in getting it through and it not being valid. In fact, it would be just a disaster with the minister giving longer time for what he might call `the forces of darkness' to come out against this bill. That is what the government will do if it passes invalid legislation.

On that basis, I would have thought that, if we want to sort these problems out and if the government is determined to have this particular response to Mabo No. 2 rather than another one, it is in the government's interest, in the interests of those who want this particular piece of legislation—I do not; I think there is another way to go—to put that advice on the table so we can see the problems.

If the government is sure that this is the appropriate response, let us see the legal advice that the government has so that we on this side can make a judgment. I know that Senator Evans will say, `You've already made up your mind'. But what about letting some other constitutional experts—the wider legal profession—look at this and make an assessment as to whether we are raising clause 11 as some form of delay in the debate or whether there is a genuine fundamental problem with this bill. The government would be better to find that out sooner rather than later.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I understand what Senator Vanstone is saying. The government is confident about the constitutionality of this clause. There is no conflict between what I have said now and what I have said previously. I was not quite sure when I spoke before—nor were the officers. They believed that there was no specific advice prepared on clause 11 or the laws of general application issue. That remains the case.

PARA.TAB: There was no specific advice, as with so many other things that are done in the course of drafting. There is a received body of doctrine or understanding. That is largely internalised with the draftsmen anyway. If they need to discuss an aspect of that, they will do so with officers of the Attorney-General's Department. That does not mean that there is formal written advice flowing backwards and forwards on those particular issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. I understand about the verbal advice.

—There may or may not have been. While Senator Vanstone was talking, I was checking. We will put together this afternoon something in the nature of an advice which explains clearly the basic reasoning of the Commonwealth on this issue, and that will be made available to those opposite.

—by leave—I think Senator Bishop has some points to make and, from what she has been saying behind me, I am not disinclined to agree with them. I want to conclude the points that I have raised, which are from a slightly different angle. Senator Gareth Evans says that he will prepare this advice. Will that advice detail why he thinks he is right? If he wants it to be useful, it will need to address the points that we have raised—void for uncertainty, whether the government can use the wording it has to use section 109 to adopt common law and whether that means that the common law is enacted. If it is not enacted, then what is the government's response to In re Uren? Is Senator Evans just going to give us a bit of legal advice that might address a whole range of matters or is he going to address the concerns that we have raised? That is what we want the advice to address.

—by leave—If only in order to shut Senator Vanstone up, it is in my interest and the government's interest to address credibly as many of the issues that Senator Vanstone has raised as I can, and I certainly will.

—by leave—As I calculate it, we have done, on one interpretation and if we do it by sections, about a tenth of the bill. If we do it by the headings in the government's groupings, we have done a third. So we have done somewhere between a tenth to a third. My estimate is that with reasonable discussion—I can see some weighty matters still to come—we would be looking at another six days of sitting. We simply do not have that time before Christmas. Of course, some of us have to travel quite far and make arrangements to get home for Christmas. Is there a limit as to what time we will sit this week? If it is not completed this week, will we come back next week?

—by leave—I am not going to give a definitive answer on that. I am simply saying, as I said before, that it is the government's intention to get this legislation before Christmas and we will sit as long as necessary before Christmas in order to achieve that result. Christmas, for this purpose, means Christmas Day since Christmas Eve this year is a working day. So honourable senators had better be prepared to operate on that assumption. I hope that assumption does not work out that way. I am very conscious of everybody's desire. I was conscious of it last week when I was howled down on this subject.

PARA.TAB: As I think Senator Ellison is one of those who is approaching this in a serious minded way, can I honestly and frankly say that I have not yet made a detailed calculation of where the substantive issues really are; so far I have only been able to make an impressionistic judgment about that and I am still engaged in discussions to find out. The discussion has ranged pretty comprehensively over all the main thematic issues in the bill and allotted specific provisions.

Given the fact that we have nearly 10 hours left today, 13 hours left tomorrow and, if we sit on Wednesday, another 13 hours then, I genuinely believe that it is possible, without rushing at fences and provided that we are not unduly repetitive, to have a measured and sensible debate—for the opposition to understand where we are coming from; for the government to understand where the opposition is coming from; and for the Democrats and Greens to make their contribution—by tomorrow dinnertime. If that assumption proves to be unfounded, so be it, we will bat on. I am not going to make any judgments yet about sitting after Christmas, but certainly those opposite had better gird their loins for sitting right up until Christmas.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As a number of the issues that Senator Vanstone, Senator Bishop and others have raised go to the core of this essential legal advice, it is so important to give this good and proper consideration. Similarly, a number of the amendments that either have been deferred or are currently sitting on the agenda paper have very significant import for the states and the Northern Territory. What efforts have been made to circulate those amendments to the respective state and territory governments? What responses have been received from them? Will the minister table those responses and endeavour to obtain those views, given the import of this legislation that impacts so severely on state and territory land administration?

—by leave—There is very little that would have caught the states and territories by surprise. There are a couple of aspects that the states and territories will undoubtedly have an interest in, and I guess this proposed new clause 196A-clause 11 issue is one of them. It would not be my intention to bring that on for debate until tomorrow morning at the earliest. It is my intention and hope that this advice we are talking about is obtainable by dinnertime this evening. We will try to obtain it by the end of the day and, hopefully, by this afternoon so that people have an opportunity to look at it.

PARA.TAB: I know there is a real issue here and it is one that we will sensibly address. I do not think it needs endlessly exhaustive attention, but it needs some attention and people may want to bounce it off state governments. I understand that. There will be an opportunity to do so during the day. I know that those state governments with a major interest in this have already indicated their intention to be in communication with the government today. That is no doubt happening as we speak. People are having explained to them what is going on. But there is not too much in that category. All the other stuff has been available for a long time and there are not a lot of new issues that have been raised since we began actively considering this on Friday.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Given that the minister has said that there will be consultations with or anticipation of responses from government today, will the minister give an undertaking to table those responses and advices that are received from state and territory governments as well as the other advice that he has alluded to in answer to Senator Vanstone? I think it is very important that this chamber, which is after all a states house, take into account very properly those advices. Will the minister give an undertaking to give us copies of any communications received from the state and territory governments?

—by leave—I certainly cannot give that undertaking because many such communications are made in confidence by the government concerned. If an individual state or a territory government wants to put on the public record the nature of any communication it makes to us, that is entirely a matter for it. We would not resist that, of course. But I cannot possibly give an undertaking in a blanket way to put out anything which is the subject of intergovernmental communication. That would be utterly at odds with the way things are done. States seem cheerfully willing to get into the public domain on this issue at the drop of every available hat. If there are any doubts, worries, anxieties or formidable arguments about any particular matter that we still have to debate, I guess we will hear about it sooner rather than later. Can I suggest, Mr Chairman, that it would be appropriate now to get back to the substantive issues.
—I wish to speak by leave.
—In the light of Senator Bishop's previous contribution, before leave is granted, it would be entirely reasonably for me to be given some assurance that this is a technical and procedural issue.
—Don't be so supercilious.
—Under those circumstances, leave is denied.
—Petulance!
—No; I have just had one experience of Senator Bishop this morning dropping a bucket when everybody else has—

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. It is not up to Senator Evans to cast aspersions upon the reasons that I want to ask a question, neither is it a matter for him as to whether or not you announce that leave has been granted. His simple statement that he did not like what I said to him before, which is the basis for his not granting leave, is a reflection upon me and I ask him to withdraw it. I also simply indicate that Senator Evans wished to obfuscate in this matter and pretend to give us the complete constitutional advice when it will be some sort of botched up job which will purport to be the complete advice. That is a dishonest way to proceed. I want to put to Senator Evans that it is not reasonable for him to put together some sort of excerpt from the advice he has and not share with the Senate the legitimate concerns that he must already be aware of as to the lack of constitutionality of the amendment which he is proposing to support. If that is not a question of substance, sir, I would like to ask you for your definition of same.
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Evans is able to make a judgment of his own whether he wants to grant leave or not.

—I seek leave to pursue the matter in relation to the opinion. I was out of the chamber and it has been brought to my attention. I do not wish to go on at any great length about it but it is a matter of importance on which we ought to be clear.
—What would you like to do?
—I seek leave to make a brief statement and ask Senator Evans a question in that area.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the minister has indicated that there is constitutional advice available in relation to clause 11 but he does not wish to make that available at this stage because of the possibility of litigation.

—by leave—On the constitutional issues, I am advised that a kind of catch-all major advice was given at a relatively early stage in the drafting of the legislation, which addressed a great many of the issues that do have constitutional implications. I am advised that that advice did not go especially deeply into, if indeed at all, the issue of state laws of general application and possible limitations on them. To the extent that that issue was dealt with in the course of the drafting process, it was the subject at best of verbal exchanges in the way that I have previously described and that Senator Alston would be well able to understand. Not everything is the subject of memoranda. When we are dealing with areas of received wisdom and so on, a lot of these things are dealt with in a slightly less formal way.

PARA.TAB: A formal document was prepared by Mr Robert Orr of the Attorney-General's Department for the committee, specifically in relation to the drafting and drafting precedents and some of the legal issues that underlie the clause 11 issue. I have already tabled that and made that available. The other point that I made is that the more general constitutional advice that had been prepared was something that is inappropriate to table. It goes to the scope of race, power and a whole variety of other issues that no doubt may well be the subject of challenge and on which the government would need to consider its position. Advices of this kind are not normally made available, at least at the time.

In order to enable the chamber to better wrestle with the issues that have been raised and in order to make a response to some of the issues that Senator Vanstone has raised—I am interested myself in knowing what the department would say on some of the points that she has raised—I have asked whether it is possible for a new advice to be prepared which will deal as systematically and as comprehensively as possible in the relatively short time available with some of these issues so that we can see where the government is coming from and what the basis of our confidence is on these issues.

That is not an unreasonable request. It is a request that we are happy to try to meet as fast as possible. I cannot give a precise commitment as to when that will be tabled, but hopefully later today and hopefully not too much later today. I hope that clarifies the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am indebted to the minister. I understand the minister to be saying that there is currently no written advice that has been proffered since Mr Orr's letter of 8 December.
—That is my understanding.
—I understand what is forthcoming. To the extent that that general constitutional advice to which the minister referred contains a reference to clause 11—
—I am just not sure about that.

—I put the proposition that, to the extent that it does, why could he not make available that portion of that advice so that we would then not have any concerns that what might come forward later might be a watered down, bland translation of an earlier solid advice offered?
—by leave—That was my first thought. I am advised that there was not much specifically on this issue in that original advice. It mainly dealt with other matters.
—To the extent that it does, as you seem to be indicating—

—There is no point in pushing and probing and pulling this out. I am not going to identify, in an advice that may come back this afternoon, with any more precision than I am now and the source of any particular lines in it.
—First you tell us there is advice and then you say there is not.
—Pipe down. Senator Bishop has got nothing to contribute of any substance—she never has and never will in this place or anywhere else. It is about time she woke up to that.
—Mind your tongue.

—Can I get back to the substantive issues without the chirruping from the sidelines and simply say that there is a legitimate question that is being asked here about the government's confidence about the constitutionality of this particular clause. We are confident about it. I have not heard a skerrick of a suggestion anywhere within our system at any stage that there is any difficulty about this. There is ample precedent we think for this kind of clause. I do not know whether there has been a precise drafting precedent. We will have to sort that out and respond further on that. But we are confident about it and the grounds for that confidence will be spelt out. That is the best I can say at this stage.

—by leave—When we boil it down, the minister seems to be saying that in that general constitutional advice there may well be some references to clause 11 but he is still not prepared to make those available to the committee. He would prefer to come up with a new document. If he expects the chamber to have any confidence that this is not just—
—by leave—Can I just respond by saying that, at the point the advice to which I was referring was drafted, there was no provision in the bill relating to state laws of general application.
—Clause 11 must have been there.
—Clause 11 was there but the issue of state laws of general application was not.
—God, you're making a fool of yourself.
—There is some material in that advice about clause 11. No doubt that will be utilised in the material. I am not in the business of quoting from particular documents, and I do not propose to do so.
—You're not in the business of telling the truth.

—Government legal advice prepared for the possible defence of legal challenge is a quintessential example of an executive privileged document. I have not looked at it and I have no idea what its content is, how interesting, uninteresting, detailed, undetailed, plausible or implausible it may be. I have no idea whatsoever.
—Make up your mind.

—I am not responding in any defensive way about this; I am just making a point of principle, notwithstanding the chirrups from the gallery on the other side, that that kind of document prepared for that purpose is not and never was by the opposition's governments in the distant past, nor will it ever by its governments if they should ever come into office in the distant future. It is a basic point of principle. But what we are prepared to do—because a legitimate public interest issue has been raised—
—I think there is.
—As Senator Vanstone says, it is in our own interests to put the most credible foot forward.
—Otherwise you lose the lot.
—That is as much as I can possibly say.

—by leave—Does it boil down to this? Both Senator Evans and I know that there are innumerable precedents for releasing advice when it suits his purposes. He can always claim professional privilege, if necessary, but there is nothing to stop him releasing advice that is helpful to his cause. Governments of both persuasions do that on a regular basis.

PARA.TAB: Does it therefore follow that, if he declines to release that portion of the advice that relates to clause 11, we would be perfectly entitled to assume that there is some doubt about the matter? If there is not, what has he got to lose? Everyone knows that, in going to the High Court, the government is going to argue that it is valid, so he is not exactly going to take anyone by surprise if he tables advice saying that it is valid.

In those circumstances, why would it not be in everyone's interest, including the minister's, to clarify the matter at this stage and not come up with some subsequent document that may well be categorised, by some who are less charitably inclined, as a whitewash?

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am perfectly capable of seeing that point for myself without the assistance of this cut-rate Rumpole over there, who makes this sort of point. It is often in the government's interest to respond to mad security allegations that have no substance whatever; the government is forced to say `no confirm or deny' as much as it would like to in a particular case, because there is a larger issue of principle applied—
—You did recently in SA, as I recall, because it suited you.

—Not in the way I am suggesting at the moment where a basic issue of principle is involved, and it is here. Government legal advice can be prepared for all sorts of purposes—but anticipating the possibility of litigation and identifying issues in which it might be necessary to respond in litigation is not one of those areas where it has ever been thought appropriate in principle to deal with it. I will give consideration to what Rumpole over there has to say about this issue, but it is a political point he is making; it is not a legal one. I do suggest that it is in everybody's interests, since we have now wasted 2 1/4 hours this morning on this skirmishing—
—I am not wasting time; I resent that. I am raising a sensible way to deal with clause 11.

—Senator Vanstone has spent only about five minutes of the 2 1/4 hours and I have had no particular quarrel with anything she has said, but I cannot say the same for all her mates, I am afraid, particularly not the one sitting behind her, who is a real charmer—now as always.

—by leave—The fact is that if that advice was available to the minister prior to this legislation coming into the chamber, I would have thought a matter of very high principle would be that he would not proceed with the clause and hold it out as utterly valid if he had any advice to the contrary. If that is the case, why will not he make that advice available?
—I have no further comment.

—by leave—I think it is a function of lack of sleep and actually remembering a name from a variation of a name that appears later in the papers I was reading. The case I was referring to was Jackson and Gambol, not re Uren. That is a version of re Enhill, which has nothing to do with all of this. It is Jackson and Gambol, which the minister's people know; I have told them that. I only raise this now in case someone is furtively running through the library trying to find—
—Furtively or fervently?
—Probably both, looking for the wrong thing. It is Jackson and Gambol they should be looking for.
—I am indebted to Senator Vanstone for that clarification. No doubt the officers of the Attorney-General's department will be, too.

PARA.TAB: Clause 24 agreed to.
Clauses 25 to 39.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some questions with respect to clause 25. As I understand it, clause 25(1) under subdivision B applies if a `government party', after commencement of the subdivision, proposes to do any permissible future act under clause 25(2) in relation to an onshore place. I want to make a number of points about this. Firstly, a government party presumably includes a state. As a consequence of this, the Commonwealth law imposes a restriction on the ability of states to do permissible future acts.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, to find out what is a permissible future act—departmental officials may be able to advise the minister if I have this comprehensively right—one would have to look at clauses 220, 218, 219, 211, 212 and 227. That surely highlights one aspect of the complexity of this bill; that is, it is necessary to understand at least six other clauses of definitions, totalling almost three pages, in order to understand the term `permissible future act' in clause 25(1). Do I misunderstand, or is it the situation that some poor soul who is trying to get to the bottom of what can be done vis-a-vis clause 25(1) has to look at all of the clauses I mentioned?

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give Senator Vanstone an answer to that. I do not contest the basic analysis that is there involved. We are talking here about one of the central, pivotal clauses of the whole bill defining as it does the acts that are covered. Yes, it is the case that, in order to get a full understanding of how those acts are defined, one does need to go to all those other definitional provisions to which Senator Vanstone referred. That is in the nature of any complex piece of legislation. Try a tax act on some of these sorts of issues and see how complex that gets. At least I think one can wend one's way through the map once one understands the basic structure of the bill, as I am sure Senator Vanstone does.

—`Onshore place' is defined in clause 238 on page 113 as being a place within the limits of a state; that includes bays, gulfs, sounds, harbours, inlets, estuaries, rivers and channels. That would mean that the waters of St Vincent's Gulf in my state are considered onshore, as are the waters of Shark Bay and Exmouth Gulf.

—It depends on the actual width of the points of the estuary. I do not know off-hand whether Spencer Gulf—Senator Vanstone, as a South Australian, ought to know—is within the onshore part of South Australia. I think it probably is. It depends entirely on all the other law, which is simply incorporated by reference here, about what the limits of a state actually are. I am working on the assumption that Senator Vanstone is probably right about that, but when the arms of a gulf are sufficiently wide, then there is a point at which the principle does not apply, but I cannot tell her offhand what it is. Her own state government undoubtedly would know.

—We have the wording, `after the commencement of this subdivision'. Clause 2 on page 4 gives an indication of commencement on proclamation or within nine months after assent. I think this means, in effect, that the rapid passage of the bill will not achieve anything; and, that states will be able to grant mining leases, et cetera, without regard to the right to negotiate procedure for up to nine months after the bill is passed. It is unlikely to be proclaimed before regulations are ready—perhaps the minister might like to answer with respect to that matter—and before the tribunal has been established.

PARA.TAB: As a consequence of what we have dealt with so far, it follows—this is the situation I am putting to the minister—that states will be able to grant mining leases, et cetera, for up to nine months after the bill is passed without regard to the right to negotiate procedure and that it is unlikely to be proclaimed before regulations are ready and the tribunal has been established. I understand what the minister is saying about Christmas and this fragile consensus. The minister knows that I think that that is a fragile foundation and that we should not be proceeding anyway. But, irrespective of Christmas, we have this problem. Why does the minister then say that we should now proceed when this aspect will not take effect for another nine months? What happens if there are no regulations in place by then? I sense the minister's frustration—

TALK.START.PARA: —I'm not frustrated.

—I am trying not to take any longer with this than necessary, but if I do not babble it all out now I will have to come back to it again and again. If the minister were a little tolerant and with a little generosity on both sides, we might get to the point. What are the consequences if the regulations are not drafted? An enormous amount of detail has to be dealt with in these regulations and that will not necessarily be easy. For example, does the minister have a draft of regulations now? Has drafting commenced? Can we see what they are? What are the consequences if the minister does not have them settled? Is what I have said with respect to the state's capacity to grant mining leases within that time correct? If it is not correct, can the minister please slowly take me through why it is not?

—I am advised that the drafting of regulations has been proceeding ever since the draughtsmen put down their pens on the Native Title Bill and that quite an advanced condition has been reached with those regulations. It is not inconceivable that the whole of the bill could be proclaimed into effect as early as 1 January. It is not inconceivable, but it is unlikely.
—Without regulations?

—The honourable senator may not have been listening. I am advised that a great deal of work has been done on the drafting of the regulations already. The draughtsmen have been, in effect, working solidly on that since the conclusion of the drafting of the bill. It may be possible to have all the relevant regulations in place by 1 January, including those for the creation of the tribunal itself. Any amendments to this bill—there have been a few of them and there are a few more to come—that bear upon those regulations will require reconsideration and redrafting of those regulations. It is probably unlikely that the 1 January deadline can be met.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) indicated as much in a very early stage of the discussions with the states about this legislation. With particular regard to clause 25, which bears upon permissible future acts and which is at the heart of the whole future operation of the bill as distinct from the past operation, he has said that proclamation may well be delayed. We certainly would not envisage that delay being anything like the full nine months for which the bill makes provision. I am advised that there is still a chance that the bill as a whole could be proclaimed, but I do not over-emphasise that because there are obviously quite a few hurdles yet to jump over. Any notion that there is no possibility whatever of having all this complex stuff ready, and therefore no need to debate it now, is a conclusion that we simply would not draw from the state of play at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the minister saying that he hopes to have everything operational by 1 January? He hoped that the Native Title Bill would be passed last week, so we have some idea that he will be whistling dixie to get it done by 1 January. I am not trying to be rude, but I think they are his chances.

—That may be. Nonetheless, it is that kind of very early time frame we are presently looking at, rather than a much extended March-or-beyond sort of time frame—let alone a September time frame which would almost involve the whole nine months. We are trying to do this as soon as possible. Whether we can do it remains to be seen.

PARA.TAB: We also need to take into account what Senator Harradine said in his contribution earlier today about the possible virtue of reconsidering some of these issues in the New Year before particular clauses are proclaimed. But that point could apply equally well after the clauses are proclaimed into effect. A lot will depend on machinery sorts of issues and the speed with which tribunals can be established and people put in place and so on. We have always anticipated that that would take some time, but it is in everybody's interests, if we want certainty, to get these outstanding issues resolved and to have it done sooner rather than later. That certainly is what we are trying to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the best will in the world, that 1 January time frame is not a possibility. If the regulations are not finalised until the end of January some time, which is a foreseeable and reasonable option to bet on, and if the Native Title Bill is not proclaimed until then, the states can still proceed to grant mining leases, et cetera; is that right?
—Yes.

—If the regulations were not done until, say, the end of January, we would be in the situation where some people in here would have decided that this bill must be passed by Christmas to stop the states from proceeding with a variety of acts. Even though a lot of work has been done on the regulations—and unless we get this bill proclaimed without the regulations, which, with the greatest respect, would be a bit rich because the way the regulations interact with the bill is important—unless we have the regulations ready by 1 January, then come 1 February we will be in the same position that we might have been in had we spent January giving the detail of these clauses to a committee genuinely interested in approving the bill. That is despite the fact that we think it is the wrong way to go in any event. We are not going to be much better off, are we?

—That is not quite true. Even if clause 25—the clause that creates the right to negotiate, the tribunal structure and other things—is not proclaimed into effect at the beginning of January, we would certainly want to proclaim into effect other basic clauses of the Native Title Bill, including, for example, clauses 21 and 22 which establish the non-discrimination principle, the freehold test and so on as applies to the grant of various kinds of interest. For example, with clauses 21 and 22 in place, any mining or other relevant interest that was granted after 1 January would have to be granted on the principle that it could be done only in relation to native title if it could be done in respect to freehold title. That is a very important protective provision, and that would be in place. Obviously, we want to get that in place as soon as possible. That is one of the many aspects of the bill that could bite immediately and we think should bite immediately. That is one of the reasons why we are trying to get the bill in place and those basic principles laid down.

PARA.TAB: Senator Vanstone has been focusing her questions on clause 25, permissible future acts and the process under clause 25. While it is perfectly true that all that mechanism would have to await proclamation—proclamation in turn would have to await the regulations and everything else being ready, and that may take a little longer than 1 January—nonetheless, there is a lot else in the bill bearing on some of those subject matters which can and which we want to have biting earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what that says about certainty and the chance of people affected by the law having any understanding of what it is. Is the minister saying that he thinks different sections can be proclaimed at different times and that if he finds that the regulations are not ready, that is what will be done?
—That is the sort of thing that happens every day of the week with legislation.
—Does the minister think that the whole of the Native Title Bill can commence before the regulations are settled and before the tribunal is established?

—No, that is not what I am saying. Those clauses which depend for their practical operation on regulations being in place obviously cannot commence operation and cannot be proclaimed into effect until that substructure is ready. But there are many other clauses of the Native Title Bill which do not depend on having regulations and so on in place in order for them to have rational and immediate effectiveness. That is the path that we certainly intend to go down.

—I understand that. I am saying that it is somewhat regrettable, which is an understatement. Although we are doing our best to give this bill proper consideration, it is being rushed through. The minister has said that we may well end up with a situation in January where those people who think this is the best response to Mabo No. 2 will go away thinking they have done their job and the poor suckers—which is what they will be—whose rights and interests will be affected will have to hews this bill to get something out of it or protect something they have from being taken from them—or whatever. They will have hell's own job of finding out what the law is because it may be proclaimed in an itty-bitty piecemeal fashion. That is as true for the Aboriginal interests presumably as it is for the mining interests, the fishing interests or whatever.

PARA.TAB: We spend a lot money in this place talking about how to run the country. I know the minister is busy with higher things but I ask him whether he might like to—in his holiday reading when he has nothing better to do than read a comic or whatever—turn his mind to the second report of the cost of justice inquiry by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. He should turn his attention to the chapter which points out the high contribution that government makes to increasing the cost of justice and reducing access by not passing legislation in this place in a proper form. By proper form I mean a form that will not come back as being completely invalid—and so all the money is wasted. If it is not in a proper form, all the debating time has been wasted. We waste the costs associated with the Hansard staff, the clerks and all of us sitting here. When we get it all wrong, we say, `That was a mistake. The High Court said we've mucked it up. Chuck it all out and start again', which is at vast expense to me, as a taxpayer, and to every taxpayer. This Commonwealth money is not somebody else's money that we are not worried about—it is taxpayers' money that is being spent.

The more substantive point is access—access to justice and access to knowing what the law is at any one time. It is a disgrace. The minister has said that, if we cannot get our act together, we will do this bit by bit. I ask: how can people possibly understand what the law is when the minister is already saying that this might be proclaimed in a piecemeal fashion? The minister says that the drafting is well under way. Is that because of the goodwill of those who have to draft the regulations, or has a set of drafting instructions for the regulations already been issued? If so, what are those instructions? Can we have a copy of them?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the principle of making available drafting instructions is one that has been the subject of debate in this place before. That is not something the government is prepared to do.
—Have they been issued?

—Yes. Some of them, if not necessarily all, have been—and a lot of drafting has proceeded. But I am not in a position to give Senator Vanstone a blow by blow account of that. It is happening right now as we speak. A lot of effort is being made to get them completed by the new year. But it is a moveable feast at the moment. Those involved are immersed in doing the job. Those opposite will have ample opportunity under the ordinary procedures of this place to consider those regulations as early as 1 February. I imagine they would be in place by then. So perhaps the Senate could defer further consideration of those regulations until, in the ordinary way, it gets the opportunity to do so.
—What work has gone on so far into the establishment of the tribunal? When will the government have that operating?
—I'll take some advice on that.

—While the minister is taking advice I make the point that it is all very well for people such as Senator Spindler to come in here with his heart on his sleeve and announce to the world that Aboriginal people have waited too long. That may well be the case but we do them no service by rushing through by Christmas a bill that ends up being unconstitutional or that they cannot work anyway because the rest of the things involved are not in place.

PARA.TAB: I would like to make the point—now that I have thought of it, I am slightly annoyed—that a certain type of sanctimony has been engaged in throughout this debate by parties all over the place—in particular, from the Australian Democrats who regularly say in their speeches, `Those of us who care about the rights of indigenous Australians'. The clear inference they are trying to make on a broadcast day is that others who do not agree with them—

TALK.START.PARA: —It wasn't said on a broadcast day, actually.

—I am sorry, but the sign said `broadcast' and I assumed therefore that it was a broadcast day. Senator Kernot said it today, as she did the other day, in the hope it would be repeated. The Democrats can wear their hearts on their sleeves and run around saying, `We care about indigenous Australians, so it follows from that that everything we say is correct, everything we say is going to be held in place, everything we do is going to be constitutional and all the trappings to make this bill work will do so'. We are not talking about just getting a bit of coverage here and being the people who passed or did not pass the Native Title Bill. In the end this bill will go out into the legal marketplace and be used by people—and they have to have some idea how to go about it.

PARA.TAB: So it is important for us to know whether the regulations, the tribunal and all these other things are ready. Otherwise, all the Democrats' wearing their hearts on their sleeves looks horribly shallow. It is just an opportunity to get themselves a bit of media coverage and make a few digs at people who happen to have a different view from them as to the way things ought to proceed. Rather than puffing a whole lot of air about their good intentions, they would be better extending their minds to a bit of detail on the bill and contributing to the detailed discussion of it to try to tease out the problems, giving people an opportunity to fix them. That is why I asked the question: what work has gone into the establishment of the tribunal? Without it, obviously, there will be consequences for people using the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to that is lots and, with a bit of luck, the tribunal will be put in place on 1 January. One cannot give an absolute assurance about this because a number of procedural hurdles and so on need to be jumped over. But the hope is that it will be possible to announce the establishment of the tribunal as early as 1 January. This is not an absolute assurance—life is like that—but that is what we are targeting. I understand the force of the points Senator Vanstone is making. They are strong points. It is for that reason that we are moving heaven and earth to try to get the tribunal ready and in place.

—The minister says the tribunal will be in place with a bit of hope and luck and that the short answer to my question is lots. Perhaps we could tease that out with a bit more detail. Could the minister give us a little more detail than that in his short answer? For example, how many presidential members will there be? Has the government made that decision? How many other members, assessors and deputy registrars will there be? Let us go through these and see what thought the government has given to this.
—You are trying to make vulgar political points.

—I am not trying to make vulgar political points. A former senator in this place—on my side, actually—indicated that I would always choose the vulgar presentation rather than the other. I make the point that he is no longer here.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—Senator Vanstone, could you proceed with your question?

TALK.START.PARA: —I was picking up an interjection of a very unkind nature. It is especially unkind, Madam Temporary Chairman, since it came from someone in a party whose Prime Minister uses the kind of language he does.
—Let us get back to Mabo.

—I am trying to get back to Mabo. The vulgarity of what comes out of that man's mouth is amazing. It is really quite extraordinary. Perhaps the minister could tell us the answer to those questions that I put to him in relation to presidential members, other members and assessors.

—It is not envisaged that we will be able to have the whole panoply of members—presidential and otherwise, and assessors—in place by 1 January. Part of the problem is that we cannot move to appoint anybody until the bill is passed. But we hope that it will be possible at least to achieve the formal establishment of the tribunal on that day. It will probably have the skeleton structure necessary to begin the process of putting it together.

PARA.TAB: Obviously, creating a new institutional body is a substantial administrative task. All I am indicating from that time frame I have offered Senator Vanstone is that this is a task that we really hope will begin running as early as 1 January, even though there will still be a lot more to do. It is not as if even the target date for formal commencement is March, April, May or something. We are making the target date 1 January, and we hope to be able to meet that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take about 20 seconds to make a point. How many district registries will be operational from 1 January? Or will there be one registry located somewhere with a skeleton staff so the minister can hold a big media conference saying, `Here we are, we have established all of this' when the practical impact will be that people in other areas in which there may be other registries later will not have that access; but the minister will be out there pretending that those people have that access because the government has this little registry with a skeleton staff somewhere? Could the minister provide the committee with details on the district registries?
—Shorn of all the rhetorical flourish, it probably is the case that we will have one registry to start with and it will probably be here in the ACT. I am not privy to the details.
—That's very useful!
—It is not a bad start, and provided Senator Vanstone does not continue on in perpetuity—
—How many mines and pastoral leases are there in the ACT?

—Do not get distracted by these side issues. The truth of the matter is that a full-scale institutional structure as proposed in the bill will be established as soon as possible and certainly earlier rather than later and, certainly, we are hoping that something will happen to formalise it on 1 January. No doubt we will be making a press statement about it; but I do not think anyone will be fooled into believing that the whole structure will be there and ready to go. They will just regard it, I hope, as a demonstration of the seriousness of purpose that we continue to bring to this legislative exercise and our determination to get it up and running as soon as possible. Senator Vanstone said that that was her last 20 seconds.
—She changed her mind.

—I actually thought that we were adjourning at 12.45 and I was looking at the clock. I have no intention of dragging this out until one o'clock. Senator Chamarette is holding her head as though she has a headache which is nothing like the one she will have at 12 o'clock tonight or four o'clock tomorrow morning.

PARA.TAB: The minister has further underlined that this is a political point. The minister gave me the information I wanted but I am not happy about that information. The minister simply told us that he wanted to shove this bill through and that the regulations might be in place by 1 January.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not want to shove the bill through; we want to debate it till the end.
—Coming from senator sanctimonious—

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—Senator Vanstone, would you please address your remarks through the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman, I am happy to address the Chair but when I am baited by interjections, which you allow to continue, you must only expect me to respond.
—I can only hear you.
—You can only hear me?
—Yes. Please proceed.
—We have the best ear specialist in Australia in my state, so you can perhaps come to Western Australia and we will fix you up.
—Most people can only hear you—you are very clear!

—When there are interjections, I do have to raise my voice. If honourable senators would just pipe down, I would not have to yell. The minister told us—in my words, not endorsed by Senator Kernot—that he wanted to shove this bill through; the government must have it by Christmas. The minister said that the regulations might not be ready and that, if those regulations were not ready, certain parts of the bill would not apply which means that, until those regulations are ready, states will be able to grant mining leases until the government gets its act together. The functional aspect of the bill, which does not affect the political kudos in this place, is that the government will set up a registry in Canberra, followed by one in Perth. Is that what the minister said?
—No, I did not say that.

—I am sorry—in Canberra, the central place of Australia. Bad luck about the people in Western Australia, the Northern Territory, Queensland and South Australia; they can all wait. It further highlights that people will be a long time waiting for the practical impact of this and all the sanctimony in this place does not change that.
—I would like to move an amendment to clause 36.
—Madam Temporary Chairman, on a point of order: I was happy to accede to Senator Chamarette because I thought she wanted to discuss this point. Other points need to be made on this.
—I am happy to defer it till later.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, on the point of order: clauses 25 to 39 are at large—it is a cognate debate on those 14 clauses. Senator Chamarette is procedurally entitled, but she might be willing to defer to Senator Vanstone if she has some other substantive issues to raise—not just repetitive ones.
—I am happy to defer moving my amendment to clause 36. I just want to make it known that I am waiting to do that.

—In relation to applications to the tribunal for determinations of native title, under Division 2, validation of past acts only applies where native title exists and where a past act is invalid. How can this possibly be ascertained before the tribunal is established? Will everyone have to come over to this tin-pot registry the government will have running in Canberra?

—This is an issue we have debated already. The whole point of this particular provision about validation of past invalid acts is to, with a sweep of the legislative pen, validate any past act that may be invalid for the particular reason spelt out in the legislation, namely, the interaction of the existence of native title with some other law.

PARA.TAB: The whole point of this is to give certainty right now, instantly, to anyone who believes it is conceivably possible that their particular interest might have been invalidated perhaps because it was granted after 1975 and in an area where there was very likely to be native title but no attention was paid to that possibility, as indeed it could not have been realistically because native title, of course, had not been identified by the High Court as being there. But there is just that question mark which exists—we have talked about it often enough in this chamber in question time; we have talked about it earlier in this debate. That is the reason. It does not depend upon any prior determination of invalidity or the non-existence of native title by the tribunal or anyone else, and that is the reason for it. It is a clarifying provision saying, `Anything which might be invalid is hereby validated'. The Commonwealth does that; it makes it possible for the states to do that in each of their own areas and that is one of the central themes of the legislation—to clarify that particular issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister is obviously saying that he is quite sure that all of Division 2 can `get up' before the tribunal is established. If the minister is not saying that, what parts of Division 2 can `get up' and operate before the tribunal is established? Would the minister later table a schedule about that?

—The validation impact of Division 2 can certainly apply straight away without the tribunal getting up, for the reasons that I have said. To the extent that someone wants to pursue a compensation claim arising out of that—and a compensation claim will depend on a determination of actual invalidity before one can get started—then the tribunal will have to be in effect. Realistically, the pursuit of a claim of that kind is some little time away, some months away, and certainly by then the tribunal would be in effect. So the basic force of these provisions can apply without the tribunal; but some of the consequential implications of those provisions, namely, the pursuit of a compensation claim, would depend upon the tribunal being in force.

PARA.TAB: We want to remove, as soon as possible, any of this sense of lingering uncertainty about the potential impact of native title in certain sorts of areas. One of the best ways of removing that lingering sense of uncertainty is to pass this bill as soon as possible and to proclaim into effect those many clauses of it which are designed to do just that and which do not depend for their operation in that sense on the existence of the tribunal. But I also say that it is our intention and hope that we have the tribunal in place anyway, even if not in full working order until some little time later.

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the minister's comment that this bill is designed to give certainty, on his own answers to questions this morning he has proven that this bill will not give certainty. Over the last few days of this debate, for instance, on the question of definition, he said that he personally does not understand the meaning of the word `lease' in the operation of subdivision B. Senator Vanstone pointed out to the minister that, to get a definition of permissible future acts, we had to look at clauses 220, 218, defining respectively, `Permissible future act' and `Future acts'; 219, `Low impact future act'; 211, `Act'; 212, `Act affecting native title'; and 227 being a `lease' as set out in clause 219, the meaning of a `low impact future act'.

PARA.TAB: In his answers to Senator Alston's questions a day or two ago, Senator Evans indicated that he had no comprehension at all of what is meant by the term `lease'. He told Senator Alston that a low impact act dealing with the question of lease would perhaps be a licence or a permit so that it would still be a low impact future act. Senator Alston then pointed out to Senator Evans quite clearly that subclause 227(c) on page 106 specifically says that anything described as a lease is deemed to be a lease whether it is the legal effect of the lease or not. In saying that this act gives certainty, the minister in charge, has again misled us—I have a whole list of instances where he has misled us in his answers—and has indicated that he does not comprehend or understand the act itself. That is not surprising.

We in this parliament are required to make laws for all Australians, and this will have an impact on all Australians. The legislation is highly complex; it is complicated. The nature of the drafting means that ordinary Australians do not have a hope in blazes of understanding it. When it comes to a small exploration company wanting to operate under subclause 25(2)—we are not talking about the BHPs or the huge multinationals; we are talking about small companies that may have a capital of $5 million or $10 million—they do not have the money or the ability to employ teams of lawyers to tell them what the provisions mean so that they can comply with this highly complex law. The minister—an aspirant for a seat on the High Court—does not understand what it means either. I withdraw the word `aspirant'—he said he was not aspiring; simply `willing to accept'. We will settle for that definition. Let us take a look at subclause 25(2).

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be a change if you got on to a matter of substance rather than vulgar posturing.
—The minister's rhetoric becomes tiresome, as does his attitude. When I have said on a previous occasion that from time to time I think he needs psychiatric help, I mean it.

—On a point of order: with the utmost respect, to say I `need psychiatric help' I think usually counts as an offensive remark. It might be a constructive contribution about my health, but I think it is intended offensively. I take it as such and ask for it to be withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—Senator Bishop, would you please withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I will not withdraw it. But I will place it in context. I said it in response to when Senator Evans said he would garrotte me. Was that unparliamentary?
—Senator Bishop, please let us not revisit something that is old history. The minister has taken offence at what you have said and has asked that you withdraw it, please.
—Madam Chair, I took offence at his threat to garrotte me. Would he retrospectively withdraw that?
—Senator Bishop, it is unparliamentary. Would you please withdraw.
—Madam Chair, where is the precedent for someone requiring psychiatric help?
—Senator Bishop, you are being asked to withdraw the comment that you just made to Senator Evans. We are not going to visit past history. You are asked to withdraw.
—Madam Chair, perhaps you can tell me precisely what it is you want me to withdraw so that it can be clear.
—Senator Bishop, I am sure you are aware of what you have said. Would you please withdraw that which is unparliamentary.

—On the point of order, Madam Chair. I have no idea what you want Senator Bishop to withdraw. There has been a number of comments passed backwards and forwards and I think it is incumbent upon you to inform the chamber.

—On the point of order, I clarify the matter by saying that the particular reference of Senator Bishop's to which I take offence is the reference to my needing psychiatric assistance. I think that would be accepted reasonably objectively as being offensive. I acknowledge there may be competing views about this—there often are about matters that are offensive that are cast across the chamber. But, on balance, I do take offence and ask for it to be withdrawn.

—On the point of order, Madam Chair. I have to seek your wise guidance, which I seek on this basis. When Senator Evans threatened to cross the floor and slowly garrotte me, I used the comment that he needed psychiatric help. He did not object at the time, so perhaps you could deliberate as to why it is offensive now and it was not then.

—Senator Bishop, that is ancient history. Presumably, the President chose to ignore that because there was other unseemly behaviour happening at the time. I want this to be withdrawn now because it relates to what has been considered offensive by the minister. I ask you to withdraw.
—On the point of order, Madam Chair. The taking of offence has gained a lot more importance in the last few weeks.
—What is your point of order, Senator Panizza?

—My point of order is about the degree of offence being taken. I said last week that it all depends on the degree of offence taken. I could find a lot of things offensive, and so could Senator Evans. Of course, it is up to you to make a ruling, Madam Chair, but this degree of offence argument is getting thinner and thinner. I think this taking of offence caper is wearing pretty thin, especially at this time of the year when everyone's nerves are strung out. We might all need help from psychologists rather than psychiatrists. I think the taking offence excuse is wearing pretty thin.
—It is unparliamentary to accuse another member of parliament of being mad or insane, Senator Bishop, so would you please withdraw.
—Madam Chair, on the basis of your definition of what I said about Senator Evans, I withdraw.
—Unconditionally please, Senator; on no basis.
—Unconditionally, Madam Chair. You did us all such a great service.
—The Greens wish to move an amendment to subclause 36(2), namely amendment No. 9A, which has been circulated.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. Prior to the lunch break, I was in continuum and we were discussing clause 25. I was on my feet when you took the chair, having been in the chamber prior to Senator Chamarette coming in. I do not know why you gave her the call before you gave it to me, because as I said I was in continuum.
—I understand that there is no in continuance—
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order.

—I am dealing with a point of order and I will rule on that first. There is no in continuance in committee. As Senator Bishop had not finished what she wanted to say, perhaps Senator Chamarette will yield to Senator Bishop and move her amendment later.

—I will yield, but I would like to state, firstly, that I had risen prior to Senator Bishop first seeking leave to speak. Senator Vanstone had indicated that she would allow me to present my amendment after she had completed speaking. A series of conversations then ensued across the chamber, which I understood were by leave, and which is why I understood also that it was appropriate for me to move my amendment. I am happy to defer to Senator Bishop. That was the reason why I did not feel it was appropriate.
—I will come back to the honourable senator next.

—by leave—I would like to ask the minister whether he intends, in his contemplation of an orderly process, to discuss the substantive issues that relate to clause 25 and then consider amendments to clause 36? It will take the cooperation of all honourable senators here if we want to create an orderly process and not have it imposed upon us by a rolling guillotine. I think it is important that we do understand, with goodwill between all of us, that there is some orderly process going on here. If we jump from a consideration of the substantive issues relating to clause 25, and then—because Senator Chamarette gets the call—move an amendment to clause 36, the whole process will break down and we will be here a lot longer than we would like to be. I seek the minister's response.
—The committee will follow the running sheet which says that clauses 25 to 39 will be dealt with together.

—The practical matter is that, if there are substantive issues to resolve in relation to one clause, and we are in the middle of debating that clause, that is fine and it makes sense to get that out of the way before we move on to the amendment. I remind the committee that we have been debating in a generalised way clause 25 and related matters for three-quarters of an hour or so before the lunch break. Given the job ahead of us, and the fact that this is a cognate debate, I really do think it would be appropriate to move on to the only substantive amendment that is about to be moved for this cognate group. If Senator Bishop has a further specific matter that she wants to raise in relation to clause 25, it might be sensible to get that out of the way before we move on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Just because a clause is not subject to an amendment does not mean that the issues contained within that clause are substantive. In each clause that we deal with, and have in-depth debate upon, it is necessary to demonstrate, for the benefit of the chamber and the Australian people, just how fundamentally this bill is lacking.

PARA.TAB: The guillotine was applied in the House of Representatives. No proper discourse or investigation of the bill took place there. It is in this chamber where clause by clause we are showing the pitfalls, confusion, complexity and total inadequacy of this bill we are opposing. We do not oppose for the sake of opposing. We are opposing this bill because it is bad law. Each and every clause that we debate demonstrates how bad that law is.

If I can now go on and debate clause 25 and point out just how bad it is, before lunch we were highlighting the ineptitude of the manner of drafting—evidenced by the use of a term such as `permissible future act'. Presumably, the word `permissible' has been used because the draftsman is attempting to indicate that what is permissible with regard to native title is similar to what is permissible with regard to holders of freehold title. But that proves not to be the case at all.

Clause 25, via clause 25(2), applies basically to mining and compulsory acquisition. It describes the types of acts that will have to go to a tribunal. As Senator Vanstone so adequately pointed out before lunch, that tribunal is not established. We do not have the criteria, as set out, as to who shall people it and how it shall operate. We are now told that on and by 1 January—the minister said, `With a bit of hope and luck, life is like that'; near enough is good enough—we might have one registry operating in Canberra. Canberra is pretty remote from the rest of Australia, but with a bit of hope and luck—that is what he said—we might have it.

Many Australians think that is totally inadequate, just as they think that a `permissible future act' has to be defined by reference to no less than six other sections is inadequate. A thorough working knowledge of what is meant by a lease is required by—the minister has already demonstrated that he does not understand it—and is the responsibility of every person who wants to operate in areas of exploration and to add to the wealth of this country in a way in which all Australians can share.

Clause 25(2) states that, subject to subsection 3, the acts which are permissible future acts—which are retrospective—are in respect of, firstly, the creation of a right to mine. That seems to be a pretty straightforward statement until the definition of `mine' in the definition section is read. The definition of `mine' is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . includes:
(a) explore or prospect for things that may be mined (including things covered by that expression because of paragraphs (b) and (c); or
(b)extract petroleum or gas from land or from the bed, subsoil under waters; or
(c) quarry.

That seems straightforward enough until one looks at the amendments. One then has to proceed via the amendments to define what is meant by the term `explore'. In other words, this is yet another example of what appears to be a straightforward use of language requiring a reference to other sections of the bill. Even then, the government could not get it right. It had to bring in amendments to say what that means.

TALK.START.PARA: —An amendment requested by the Victorian government in that instance.
—That is not the point. The government is rushing this legislation through. In the ordinary course of events, discussions would take place—
—Would that we were rushing it through.

—The proper way to deal with complex legislation of this nature is to introduce the bill and let it lie on the table. All those who will be affected by it can then consider it and make submissions. They would then be considered in a timely and orderly way—not in accordance with the desperate timetable of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to hold together what the minister has called the fragile consensus. That consensus has already gone. Those opposite being the sort of people they are, they will not pay heed to that. They are determined to foist this on the Australian people with all the consequences, both known and unknown, that flow from it.

PARA.TAB: This sad and sorry bill will be a sad and sorry epitaph to the minister's years in the Senate. He thinks he will have a lovely day when he sits on the High Court interpreting what he thought it meant. We think the court is adventuresome now—try it then.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you get on with some substance instead of this empty, vapid, posturing rhetoric.

—Senator Evans is going to have to increase his vocabulary. The word vapid has had vast overuse over the years by him. If the minister is going on to the bench he will have to learn some judicial terms, which means that his behaviour is going to have to change too.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—Order! Please return to the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us take a look at the terms of the bill, the way in which it is meant to operate and who is going to be affected by it. The bill refers to the creation of a right to mine. We have already looked at the word `mine' and we have found that we have to make reference to several other parts of the bill to determine what that might or might not mean.

PARA.TAB: What do we mean by `creation'? What is the meaning of `creation of a right'? There is no definition of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't like it when there is a definition. You're being a trifle unreasonable, aren't you?

—I like straightforward definitions. When an act says something, I like the prospect that an ordinary Australian, who is going to be affected by the law, might just be able to understand it. But the way this government operates is to make the law obtuse, difficult and complex so that ordinary folk cannot understand it. That way they become more dependent on government because of it. That is not my idea of a working democracy.
—I can't wait till you win so I can judge how you go.

—Now we have Senator Apologia, the senator who is leading the fourth faction of the Labor Party. I asked the minister earlier if he would disclose the deals that have been done for this de facto coalition consisting of the Democrats, the Greens and the minister. We are no doubt waiting for the precise time when we will hear from Senator Kernot what time she has agreed to apply the guillotine. Shall we run a book on it? We could probably take guesses about the time it will be introduced. We could have a prize for who can guess when the Democrats will cave in.

PARA.TAB: The right to negotiate applies in the area where there is a creation of a right to mine, whether by the grant of a mining lease or otherwise. As I said, there is a definition of the word `mine' which is complicated but we have no definition of the `creation of a right'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you need one?

—Why do we need one? That is a simple question from the minister. Let us take an example. Supposing the Civil Aviation Authority chops and changes yet again, as it does from time to time, and it has a requirement that if there are aeroplanes that want to do exploration flights, they must file a flight plan. Does the filing of a flight plan then constitute the creation of a right to mine? Because exploration by aeroplane, by photograph, by seismic techniques is covered by the term `mine' within the meaning of the act.

PARA.TAB: What we have yet to determine is what is the meaning of a `creation of a right'. I have just given the minister an example of a creation of a right. I ask the minister now to explain whether that would indeed constitute the creation of a right.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, because quite apart from anything else it would not affect native titleholders having a plane fly over them.
—Would the minister mind standing up to speak. Mr Temporary Chairman, would you mind asking the minister to respond in a proper manner.

—I am perfectly happy to respond to questions properly asked. I am perfectly happy to get one point of substance after 10 minutes of utterly insubstantial waffle. That is par for the course from Senator Bishop. The language used here is very straightforward—`the creation of a right to mine, whether by grant of a mining lease or otherwise'. There are various ways in which these interests, whether they be formal mining leases or whether they be exploration licences or permits of various kinds, can be granted. Sometimes a full-scale mining right, for example, can be granted by way of legislation, with some specific purpose legislation for a particular mine in a particular location. All of these things are perfectly, readily ascertainable as a matter of straight commonsense statutory interpretation. There is hardly any need to spell that out. That would add, if we did spell that out, very considerably to the length of what is already rather long and complex legislation.

PARA.TAB: Simply to make the point, as Senator Bishop spent the first 10 minutes of her question doing, that this is complex legislation which involves a number of definitions which have to be read in conjunction with particular substantive clauses is to make a point which is true of most substantial complex legislation, including tax legislation for example, and is simply a necessary characteristic of legislative drafting when we are dealing with complex matters such as this. It is a point that is of no particular utility to make, other than for posturing purposes, but then we are familiar with that. As to Senator Bishop's point about an aircraft flight plan, the exploration permit, if one were necessary to proceed by—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the question.

—I am just dealing with it in a systematic way, as I have tried to do with every substantive point that has been raised during this debate. If airborne exploration involved a specific permit to be conducted, presumably that particular permit would come within the scope of the act as a prima facie matter. But, if an activity involves merely airborne activity and not on the ground seismic activity or things of that kind, even the impairment of the native rights would be so comprehensively insignificant, so insubstantial and so totally marginal in their obvious impact that, for that reason alone, they would be excluded from the operation of the legislation the way it is drafted.

PARA.TAB: Certainly, an act at a couple of removes from the act of exploring, such as the simple obtaining of a flight plan for a particular flight pursuant to an exploration exercise, would be at so many removes from the notion of the creation of a right to engage in what is defined broadly as a mining activity that it is inconceivable that that would come within the scope of the legislation. Senator Bishop asked a question and that is the answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a pity the minister did not answer the question I asked. I will restate my question to the minister, and perhaps I will explain the legislation to him so that he can understand it. This part of the bill, as I said right at the beginning, describes the types of acts that have to go through a tribunal—the one we are yet to get. I will wait until the minister finishes getting his advice so that he can listen to the question, because he did not answer the question I asked before.
—I have good antennae for something substantive. Senator Bishop was not saying anything substantive. I will listen when she does.

—The minister sounds like a broken record and what he says is about as interesting and as relevant. I will wait until the minister can listen to the question, because he did not understand before, the poor chap. I will ask the question again. As I said to the minister earlier, the purpose of this subdivision of the act is to describe the types of acts that have to go through a tribunal—the one we do not have yet. It then describes the creation of a right to mine, whether by the grant of a mining lease or otherwise, as being one of those types of acts. We then go to the definitional section and we see that the definition of `mine', about which a right would be created, includes exploration. It includes acts to `explore or prospect for things that may be mined', as I explained to the minister. I then explained to the minister his own amendment, which specifically defined `exploration' so that aerial exploration is included. I then put to the minister the question, not whether or not a permit to mine was required—is the minister ready for the question again?
—I have been ready for the last 22 hours for Senator Bishop to ask me a substantive question and I have not heard one yet.

—That is because the minister is deaf when it comes to listening to things that matter. Try again; concentrate this time. I said that I was not asking the minister about a permit to mine or to explore; I was asking him about the Civil Aviation Authority creating a regulation which required that a flight plan be registered for any aircraft engaging in aerial exploration. That is something not covered by this act, and I am sure the minister can understand that. I then asked the minister—we have to wait for him again.

—With respect, I have been sitting here for 22 hours. I have been dealing with many questions that have been put to me by many people around the chamber. While I am listening to the question, I am also often taking advice. I am perfectly capable of doing both things simultaneously and it is not necessary for Senator Bishop to break off and posture every time I lean across the aisle. That is the nature of the exercise.
