I can do without Senator Bishop doing that. Senator Bishop will get her answer once she asks an intelligible question. I am still waiting to hear it. If Senator Bishop is putting together the building blocks for a question and is not just repeating what she said earlier, I am listening.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, is he speaking to a point of order?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—Senator Bishop, you should continue with your questioning, and when that is completed it is up to the minister to give an answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think he jumped to his feet in the middle of a question; he does have difficulty following.
—The minister may answer in any way he chooses.

—Thank you. The point is, as the minister pointed out, he has been here for many hours coping with a bad brief. He does not understand the legislation; he has demonstrated that quite well. At an opportune time I will go through several pages where his answers to questions have just been plain ill-informed and wrong. Therefore I want to get this point right.

PARA.TAB: I am not talking about a permit to explore or a permit to mine; I am asking about another regulation—for instance, the example I just gave of the Civil Aviation Authority. Does the registration of that flight plan constitute a creation of a right to mine—yes or no?

TALK.START.PARA: —The very short point, and I have made it already before, is that a future act to come within the scope of this legislation has to, within the meaning of 218(1)(c)(i), affect native title. It has to affect native title before the legislation even begins to bite upon the act in question and before anyone has to make any judgment at all about the nature and extent of that impact which would have been, as I have already said, negligible. But here it cannot be construed by itself, from any rational perspective, as amounting to affecting native title.

PARA.TAB: That is quite different from a situation where a mining lease is granted or where an exploration permit even is granted which involves perhaps very substantial physical intrusion into the area of the native title and some significant impact in that respect on the enjoyment of that title. When Senator Bishop talks simply of aerial surveying, it is only in the loosest terms that that would be regarded as being included in the definition.

My definition that I will be moving in clause 71 does introduce some content to the notion of `explore'. We did that at the request of the state government of Victoria. It says that `explore' means to conduct a geological, geophysical or geochemical survey or take samples for the purpose of analysis. There are some forms of geophysical surveys, as well as geological and geochemical ones, that would involve an impact or an effect on native title. There are other kinds—purely aerial surveys and so on—that would not be construed by any reasonable observer, or certainly any reasonable court or tribunal, as having that impact. A filing of a flight plan pursuant to some regulatory arrangement by the CAA is an example of drawing an absurdly long bow. It might give the honourable senator something to occupy the time of the chamber with for yet another few minutes, but it is not something that could rationally be regarded as impacting on native title, and therefore not rationally within the scope of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has just contradicted himself in his own answer and contradicted the statement he made in his diatribe a little earlier. He said that whatever the nature of aerial survey it would be intrusive to native title; therefore the bill is attracted.
—What?

—Yes, he did, and the Hansard will show it. So let us be very precise: seismic studies are also done by aircraft and are certainly intrusive even under the minister's secondary definition. The Civil Aviation Authority is in fact bouncing waves off the surface, and it fits within the government's definition of `geophysical'. It is the government's definition and the government's bill. Senator Evans is the one who says, on the one hand, that any survey at all is in fact intrusive. Then on the other hand he says some are a little less intrusive, so maybe they are not covered by the bill.

PARA.TAB: The question I asked Senator Evans was: would such a regulation in fact create a right to mine? I asked him to answer yes or no. The answer is that he cannot, and it is just another example of the poor drafting, the complexity, the confusion and the cost which will be borne by people who want to add to the wealth of this nation.

Let us move on. Future acts also covers `the variation of such a right'; the nature of which we have not quite been able to establish. So that is indeterminate. Another uncertainty is `the extension of the period for which such a right has effect'. We then move on to paragraphs (d) and (e) which state:

SPEECH.PARA: (d)the compulsory acquisition of native title rights and interests under a Compulsory Acquisition Act, where the purpose of the acquisition is to confer rights or interests in relation to the land or waters concerned on persons other than a Government party;
(e)or any other act approved by the minister, the Commonwealth minister, in writing for the purposes of this paragraph.

That is a pretty wide ambit. I want to ask the minister in that context with regard to infrastructure rights that necessarily accompany the right to mine: where is the provision in the bill that allows a mining company, which has obtained a right to mine, the right to establish infrastructure to support that mine, including access to that mine?

TALK.START.PARA: —Each separate component of the infrastructure has its own regime applicable to it. If we are talking about something in the nature of a public work—a road or an access provision of that kind—other provisions govern that, if it is to be supplied by the government on behalf of the particular exercise. If it is infrastructure to be developed by the mining operation itself, it would either be within the scope of the original activity the subject of the discussion in question, or it would be a separate future act and dealt with as such under the regime of the legislation.

PARA.TAB: Future acts encompass a whole variety of different forms of activity. In one way or another the development of infrastructure in a way that impacted upon native titleholders—that is always the threshold requirement—is picked up so far as mining operations are concerned. I will see whether there is any further information that the advisers wish to add to that. Essentially, they confirm what I am saying.

If something is to occur on or about the environs of the mine site or in order to give access to it, the activity in question has to be covered by the terms of the mining lease. It would have to be covered either by some additional form of government proprietary right being vested in the mining company to enable it to embark upon the work in question, or by something in the nature of a government public work activity. Each one of those situations are provided for in various parts of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem with that explanation is that the term `right to mine' includes `explore', `prospect' and `extract petroleum and gas'. Many of those things require infrastructure, such as access roads—which we just discussed—airstrips, waste dumps, administration buildings or camps. When it comes down to more specific ways of getting out that which might be discovered, there may be need for pipelines, tailing mines or treatment plants. Where is the provision in this bill for those things to occur as of right?

—I have answered Senator Bishop's question. She is simply repeating it. They do not occur as of right in the sense that they can occur without regard being had to their impact on native titleholders. If there are native titleholders in the area in question and any one of these forms of activity impacts on them, the consequences that are spelt out in this part of the legislation follow from that. That is part of the scheme of the legislation. Any form of activity which is within the definition of `future acts' but affects native title within the meaning of clause 238(c) is something that must be subject to the processes of the legislation. That is proper and appropriate.

PARA.TAB: That is the very interest that has not been recognised in the past—the existence of Aboriginal titleholders. They have just been regarded as being as non-existent as the terra nullius principle itself. They do not exist; they do exist. They have rights; they have legitimate positions to put and legitimate claims for compensation to make when those rights are impaired. This is what the bill is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not answer the question. The fact of the matter is that it is uncertain. I ask the minister, very specifically, the following three questions: are those ancillary rights included within the meaning of `right to mine'; are they permissible acts within the meaning of the legislation; and are they subject to the right to negotiations provisions? Let the minister answer them one at a time: are they included in the right to mine?

—Not necessarily. They may be, given the terms of the particular mining lease, which are often quite inclusive of provisions of that kind. But there are other ways in which these rights can be granted. For a start, the concept of permissible future acts is of course a reference to those acts which are able to be set in train in relation to freehold land, applying the freehold test: if freehold land can be the subject without more activity by state, territory or Commonwealth governments, equally that activity can occur over land which is the subject of native title.

PARA.TAB: I also add that state mining acts do provide the detailed rights which tend to be associated with the granting of mining leases or different kinds of lesser interests in land that are associated with mining or pre-mining activity. Our legislation does not intrude into that particular domain at all. It is meant to be no more than a reference to it. I am reminded further that the definition of `mine' is itself inclusive rather than exclusive. It does not purport to cover the whole field of possible scope of mine activity. To the extent that state mining legislation has something to say on that subject, that would also no doubt be taken into account by any court or tribunal where this matter came as an issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —That of course invokes the provisions of clause 11, about which we are still to have debate. But, nonetheless, I had a reason for mentioning right at the beginning the concept that a permissible future act was meant to denote that the same sorts of things could be done with respect to native title as could be done with respect to freehold title. That is a misnomer because Aboriginal title will give the proprietors of that land the right to exclude people from that land. That is the whole point we are discussing in clause 11. Despite clause 11, they will still have the right to exclude people from their land. That means that, although under this legislation we may be given the right to mine, under the minister's very explanation to me minutes ago, we do not necessarily have the right to the ancillary requirements of that mine. So, in other words, the minister says that there will be no impediment to the development of future mines—but, by his own admission, that is not true.

PARA.TAB: My colleague Senator Campbell has a very specific point he wants to take up with the minister with regard to the minister's comment—or throwaway line—about the government building roads, including access roads. When the minister has answered the question as to why there is no amendment to provide for those ancillary requirements, Senator Campbell wishes to raise those other points with the minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point in saying, with a great sense of triumph, that clause 25 does not necessarily cover the whole field in describing the things that are future acts that may impact upon mining or be necessary to take place in order that a mining venture can go forward. It may well be the case that something more than the particular acts set out here is required.

PARA.TAB: It is the case, which Senator Bishop is not sufficiently acknowledging, that most grants of mining leases do make provision simultaneously for all the appropriate infrastructure to go with them. But to the extent that they do not, there is plenty of opportunity for other forms of permissible activity to occur.

So far as government activity is concerned, the acquisition of land, be it ever so strongly held in native title terms, for a public works purpose—classically a road, I guess, into a particular site—can of course take place pursuant to the compulsory acquisition provisions that run through the legislation. Clause 22, in particular, bears upon that question. The further point needs to be made that while native title rights may involve exclusive occupancy and a right to exclude, that is not necessarily always the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say it was.

—No. Just in case there is any misunderstanding about that—I do not wish to misstate what Senator Bishop says in the way that she regularly misstates what I say for some triumphant, forensic reason after I have sat down. If I sought to correct Senator Bishop's misrepresentations or missummaries of what I say, I would be here all day, and I do not want to waste that degree of time. Let the record speak for itself.

PARA.TAB: I simply make the point that it is not to be assumed that native title will involve exclusive occupancy; that will depend on the circumstances of the particular native title in question. That is ultimately a matter for determination by tribunals.

One way or another, it is perfectly possible for all the ancillary activity that may need to go on in association with a mining development to occur. Of course, the legislation has anticipated the necessity for some flexibility in this respect and, one way or another, by the different legislative routes that are mapped here and that are available under state legislation and so on, that can be achieved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the fact that I said that Senator Campbell wanted to take up that point, I will address one point that just arose from what the minister had to say. He said that this legislation covered the field. I think he used that term, did he not?
—Not in a technical way.

—Not in the technical field; it was section 109. Nonetheless, the minister was indicating in his answer to me that the things that I was dealing with were merely included as things which may be included, and that is not so. Clause 25 of the bill says:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to subsection (3), the acts are as follows:

TALK.START.PARA: —I was referring to the definition of `mine'.
—We have already dealt with that.
—That is what I was referring to when I said it was inclusive rather than exclusive.
—The definition of `mine' does not help with the ancillary matters.
—But it is inclusive rather than exclusive. I was making that point in that context and, please, do not misrepresent me again. You have done it often enough so far. I do not wish it to recur.

—The minister always pleads misrepresentation when he has given an answer which can only be described as obtuse, messy, ill-informed or just plain wrong. So we are quite used to Senator Evans using the term `misquote' in that way. It is not unknown in politics. But the term `mine' specifically does not include those ancillary things. If the minister chooses to bring in yet another amendment—indeed his advisers could be writing one as we speak—then we may have the matter cleared up. In fact, I ask the minister: are his advisers suggesting a further amendment?
—No, not a chance. Not necessary. Press on.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Can that remark be withdrawn?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—What do you wish to be withdrawn?

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Evans just said then.
—I said, `No. Not necessary. Press on'. What is the problem?
—I misheard you.
—It must have been pretty good. Can you share it with us? What do you think I said? Come out the back and tell me privately.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—Could we then `press on', minister, using your words?

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly sounded like something else to me.

—Mr Chairman, I know that the minister is a schoolboy who has not yet grown up, but could he come back and attend to the matter. Unfortunately, he is necessary to the process. Before we indulged in this little hilarity, I asked the minister whether or not the provision for ancillary infrastructure could be included within the term `right to mine'. The answer to that was: no. I still do not have an answer to the question: are they permissible acts within the meaning of the act?
—I have already answered that and I have no need to go into repetition. Senator Bishop should check the Hansard.
—To save me doing that, can the minister remember what he said? Was it yes or no?

—I have just been reminded that it is exactly as I said: if a grant of that kind can be made over freehold land, those infrastructure provisions would be covered under the freehold equivalence principle. Otherwise we would go back to the compulsory acquisition rights of the states in order to acquire land from the native titleholders compulsorily for the purposes of the further infrastructure that is concerned.

PARA.TAB: There might be some other form of proprietary right other than a strictly mining related right by way of lease or licence—an easement or something—that might be sought by the mining operation, particularly in the context of creating a pipeline, a slurry line or something like that, which might require an easement to be granted over a succession of native title occupied properties. Under those circumstances, permissible acts, including the granting of easements of that kind through other ordinary proprietary processes, may not be directly subsumed in all cases within the definition of `mine', but may need to be addressed.

Very often in mining projects there are many different kinds of proprietary rights in issue at various stages of the process so that the thing can move from the initial exploration stage through to development and subsequent extraction. That is a familiar part of the whole process. One way or another, different parts of the legislation make it possible for each one of those relevant stages of development to take place, notwithstanding the competing interests of native titleholders. They are not all subsumed in the particular section we are dealing with here but they are to be found in the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will put down the answer to my specific question of whether they are permissible acts as: perhaps. The third question I ask is: are they subject to the right to negotiate provisions?

—Again, confirming my understanding of this, if they are properly described as or limited to a right to mine—sometimes they will be and sometimes they will not—they come within the framework of the requirement of negotiation. If they are not part of the mining interest as such, as defined in the legislation, the right to negotiate does not arise. But there are many different kinds of proprietary right or interest that can be involved vis a vis native title, and the capacity of the native titleholders to enforce a right to negotiation or anything else depends on the kind of right it is.
—So again I can put down: perhaps. The `perhaps' is determined by the minister saying that the right to negotiate provisions is tied to the right to mine provisions. Is that correct?

—The right to negotiate is really confined to two situations. One is mining leases as such and whatever is involved in that particular mining interest grant. The other particular context in which the right to negotiation is involved is compulsory acquisition for third parties at the request of third parties, which is provided for in clause 25(2)(d). They are the only particular contexts where that right is involved, in my understanding.
—We have a further qualification to that. Out of those three questions we get a no and two perhapses. Could the minister give me an example of a compulsory acquisition on behalf of a third party.

—If Senator Bishop had been in the chamber when we debated this—we are starting to get into rather repetitive territory, I am afraid, which I fear will be the case for a lot of the rest of this debate if we do not focus sharply on issues and if people do not listen to the debate when they are not in the chamber—she would know that different forms of state and territory compulsory acquisition legislation exist in some states, not in all.

PARA.TAB: It is possible to apply the compulsory acquisition provisions of state or territory legislation for the purpose of acquiring land which is then vested in third parties as part of some development exercise. Whether it is rural or agricultural development, whether it is a tourism sort of operation or whether it is even a residential operation will vary according to circumstances and what is permissible in the state legislation. But other states and territories are less broad in the scope for compulsory acquisitions. In some other states and territories it has to be, for a public purpose, quite narrowly defined. In some states it can be done more broadly. It is to cover those sorts of situations that this particular clause is drafted in the way it is. We have dealt elsewhere with other language on the compulsory acquisition provisions which there is no need to repeat here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just so that people understand, in other words what the minister has described is yet another example of where the Commonwealth is usurping the function of the state governments and saying that the only way their legislation can be valid is by the operation of this act. Is that correct?

—I am not going to go on responding to those cartoon-like capsule summaries of quite complex answers that I give. When I give Senator Bishop a carefully crafted answer which deals in detail with something, she keeps on getting up and saying, `May I then put that down as a perhaps. Answer yes or no'. I am not going to put that down as a perhaps. I am going to put it down as the answer I have given. Senator Bishop can characterise my answer any way she likes. I have given it and she can deal with it as she likes.
—Was that meant to tell me that the minister did not know the answer to the question or was that meant to tell me that, yes, it is true?
—I am not answering that sort of question; move on.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—The minister has indicated that he has given his answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the example the minister gave me constitute an example of the Commonwealth saying, by this legislation, that certain state acts cannot operate unless the Commonwealth act is affected? Is that the case?

—I do not know quite what Senator Bishop means by the way she puts these things. It is always so crude and highly summarised. The state compulsory acquisition law can operate on its own terms subject to a limitation that is imposed by the Commonwealth legislation; namely, where that compulsory acquisition for a third party, to take a current instance, applies in a way that impacts upon a native titleholder, then that does give rise to right to negotiation under the legislation. That is the answer I gave, and I really do not want to be taken as characterising it in any other way.

—The minister seems to have a problem with language, which we have observed before. He does not seem to know the meaning of words, particularly the word `crude'—which I let go through to the keeper. I have asked the attendant to bring me the Macquarie Dictionary. I will send it over to Senator Evans—he has a problem with language—so that he will be able to better understand the language. I know that I am running the risk of giving him a tome that he might throw, but I think the dictionary is sufficiently heavy as to not quite reach across the chamber. I suggest to Senator Gareth Evans that if he is stuck for a word to use to express a precise answer to decent questions, he could use the Macquarie Dictionary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 36, page 20, line 36, omit "must not", substitute "may".

As I understand it, we are debating cognately clauses 25 to 39. If there are other matters on other clauses, I am sure there will be time left for people to discuss them. This amendment refers to subclause 36(2). The Greens have always held the position that the Native Title Bill should not bring Aboriginal rights lower than those granted under the High Court decision, nor should it close off avenues that the High Court may decide in the future. The legislation is already doing just that, particularly in the area of mineral rights.

PARA.TAB: In the United States of America and Canada, mineral ownership has often been found to be an integral part of native title and native title confers the right to control overdevelopment on native title land. This bill, and particularly this clause, closes off those options for Aboriginal people. This clause closes those doors by preventing native titleholders from sharing in any resource profits from their native title land. This will deprive many Aboriginal groups of their right to economic independence.

Australia is a signatory to international treaties that protect human rights and the cultures of indigenous people. The preamble to this legislation specifically states that the bill is intended to be consistent with those international conventions—such as the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Racial Discrimination, the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Shortly we will be asked to sign the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples. But to survive culturally, Aboriginal people require a strong economic base. This clause reduces the economic rights of Aboriginal people. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The arbitral body must not determine a condition under paragraph (1)(c) that has the effect that native title parties are to be entitled to payments worked out by reference to:
(a) the amount of profits made; or
(b) any income derived; or
(c) any things produced;
by any grantee party as a result of doing anything in relation to the land or waters concerned after the act is done.

Mark that well, because whatever development is occurring on that land is being done on native title land. Yet here we have in this bill, which is aimed at preserving native title rights—at least to the extent which they were given by the High Court and not undermining them—a clause that specifically writes out any basis for which Aboriginal people may receive advantage from the usage to which their native title land is put.

PARA.TAB: This clause puts the bill in complete contradiction to the Northern Territory Land Rights Act and the New South Wales Land Rights Act, both of which allow control over development and royalty sharing of some sort. The Northern Territory government has already indicated that it intends to use this clause as a lever to change the Northern Territory Land Rights Act so that Northern Territory Aborigines will lose the right of veto. Is it the intention of this clause to open a pathway for erosion of the rights of Northern Territory Aboriginal people?

Because of these factors, and the fact that this clause specifically goes against the draft UN declaration of the rights of indigenous people, the Greens are opposed to it as it stands and are proposing an amendment. The amendment simply leaves it open. It does not decide the matter but neither does it explicitly exclude the possibility that some form of negotiation may be entered into. It may well be in the interests of mining companies and those developers that seek to gain access to native title land that they have the freedom to be able to negotiate; and that some of the royalty benefits may accrue to the rightful traditional owners of that land.

That is why I have presented and moved this amendment. I hope that the opposition is listening because, in the interests of justice, Aboriginal people have an entitlement not to be specifically excluded from this measure. As I understand it, the government is not prepared to support it. However, I would very much like to hear the minister's reasons for not supporting such a change or even for including such a clause which I believe is a discriminatory one within the confines of this legislation which is supposed to be preserving the rights of native title owners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to try to explain to Senator Chamarette why the government does not feel it is able to go down this path. I have already done so to some extent on an earlier amendment that was moved. In a sense, this is a second bite of the cherry. Maybe I can be a little more explicit the second time around on the problems that this gives rise to.

PARA.TAB: For a start, I think it needs to be appreciated that other property owners—apart from the situation that may exist in relation to Aboriginal title—are not entitled in any way to profit related payments when they do not have title to the minerals. The generally understood situation in this country is that ownership of minerals is reserved to the Crown.

The High Court judgment made no mention of native titleholders owning minerals. It is unresolved as to whether it is possible for them to do so. It seems unlikely to the government that a decision of that kind would be made, not least because modern methods of extraction which are necessary to get to most ore bodies and to produce returns from most kinds of mining activity are clearly rather beyond the kinds of interests that were referred to in the High Court judgment. Our position is that it would be very difficult to justify making potentially available profit related payments to native titleholders when holders of other kinds of property interests which may be comparable in all sorts of ways simply do not get such payments.

By way of parenthesis, if it were the case that the High Court held at some time in the future that native title does extend to minerals, the bill provides for just terms to be paid for any acquisition that would then take place. That is in clause 51 of the bill. So native titleholders would become able, in appropriate cases, to make that claim for compensation.
The bill does not in any way conclude the question as to whether native titleholders do own minerals. It is silent on that issue. Clause 197 of the bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to this Act, a law of the Commonwealth, a State or Territory may confirm:

PARA.TAB: (a) any existing ownership of natural resources by the Crown . . .

SPEECH.PARA: But that is only a right to confirm by legislation existing ownership of resources as that ownership is now enjoyed. If the High Court were, for some reason, to hold that the ownership of certain mineral resources is vested in native titleholders, of course those rights would be able to be enjoyed to the full.

TALK.START.PARA: —But not other Australians.

—I said before that the general provision in Australian law is that ordinary titleholders do not own the minerals under law. That is certainly the common law position. Under statute in some states—I have just been reminded of that; Western Australia is one example—notwithstanding that general law that is applicable, it is the case that certain types of freeholders do own the mineral rights under the law. It would not, for that reason, be a totally unique occurrence for the court at some stage in the future to hold that, in certain situations, mineral rights were held.
—That is outrageous. You were here when Senator Crichton-Browne explained that to the Senate two days ago.

—It is not an outrageous argument. I am just trying to make the point that each one of these situations is different. I am trying to explain, for the benefit of Senator Chamarette and those who are concerned not to exclude the possibility of some claim being made in some situations in the future by Aboriginal and native title holders in relation to minerals, that the bill does not exclude that. It is our belief that the law would not ever be likely to be interpreted in such a way as to vest mineral rights in them; but, if the law were to be, through some future litigation and some future decision—implausibly, in my judgment—then under those circumstances there is nothing in the bill that would stop that, and I think it is important to appreciate that.
—Don't we represent the people? Why do we have to leave it to the High Court?

—I do not want to give Senator Boswell a civics lesson, but the High Court does sit up there at the top of the tree and interprets the constitution and we are all subject to it. As grumpy as that might make Senator Boswell on occasion, that is the constitutional reality, so he had better start getting used to it. It has been around for 93 years so far.
—I thought the parliament of Australia sat over everything.

—Not true, old son; it is the constitution that does and it is the High Court that interprets that. It is back to school, I am afraid. The government's view has always been that, while the parties are free to negotiate profit-sharing arrangements, such arrangements should not be imposed by tribunals, which would have to make—
—So unelected people make the laws of the land. That's terrific!

—I will not respond. I am pondering the interjections I am getting when I am actually rejecting the Greens' amendment. I am just looking forward to what I will get later on when I start accepting a few of them! I repeat: the view of the government has always been that, while the parties are free to negotiate profit-sharing arrangements, such arrangements should not be imposed by tribunals. I made that point before when we were debating clause 36.

PARA.TAB: Part of the problem here, quite apart from basic issues of principle, is that the tribunals in this context would have to make a commercial assessment as to whether a percentage of projected profits would amount to greater or lesser compensation than was otherwise available under the other provisions for up-front payments that are provided for under the legislation. It would be a very difficult task for anyone in those circumstances to undertake the task effectively.

The final point I make, again from the perspective of justice to Aboriginal people who might feel that their rights are being eroded by this process—I think wrongly because it is really a pretty large assumption that anything in the nature of mineral rights would ever be recognised as a matter of law—is that the government's proposed social justice package could provide for royalty equivalent payments to be made by government in certain circumstances, rather than have royalty or profit based payments imposed on mining companies.

The government's discussion paper, which was released last June, did canvass those options in detail. We are committed to further consultations with Aboriginal groups, as we have said many times, on the content of the social justice package. And it may be in that context that there is scope for developing that notion of royalty equivalents.

That is a rather detailed answer, Mr Temporary Chairman, but I thought it was necessary to explain in some detail why we are responding negatively to this particular amendment. It is not because of any instant dismissal of the ideas behind the amendment. It is really because of the rather careful balance of considerations that I have tried to retail.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened very carefully to the amendment proposed by the Greens and to the answer given by Senator Evans. Again, it confirms my very real concerns that we are setting up in this nation two laws: a set of laws which apply to one group of people and another set of laws which apply to another. In relation to the proposal put by Senator Chamarette, in reality she is asking for rights to apply to native title and the owners of native title which do not apply to any other Australians in relation to minerals.
—Yes they do.

—No, they do not—only in very rare, exceptional cases. The vast number of Australians are not entitled to this right and Senator Chamarette stood up in this parliament and said, `We want to apply a special series of rights to people who can claim native title'. One of the reasons why there is such widespread concern in the community about this bill and why support for this bill is eroding is that it severely compromises the great Australian value of one law for our people.

PARA.TAB: In justification of this amendment, Senator Chamarette referred to a UN treaty. It seems to me that if we wish to advance the rights of all of our people—of course we do; we wish to advance all our people, not just special groups, in the appropriate march of democracy through the institutions of this country—we should do so by passing laws through this parliament, not by allowing Senator Evans to go off to the UN and sign treaties and provide constitutional heads of power. It is bad enough to refer to a treaty which we have already signed—not passed by this parliament—but it is now being said that we should adjust our laws to come into conformity with treaties which we have not even signed and which we do not even know the precise wording of.

I put it to Senator Chamarette that that sort of thinking is very dangerous thinking. I ask Senator Chamarette and her colleagues to think very carefully before they start referring to UN treaties. If they want to change the rights of people in this country, they should do what democrats do—I say that in a broad sense, not a party political sense—and put a law through this parliament and convince our people of it. But do not run off to the UN and try to acquire constitutional heads of power to alter the laws of this country.

Senator Evans opened up another great area of uncertainty when he spoke. I listened to his remarks very carefully and it seems to me that people will interpret his statement as being an invitation to Aboriginal people to go to the High Court and seek a ruling that they are entitled to the ownership of minerals and the rights which would flow from it. I was rather hoping that Senator Evans would make a clear statement, but he said in a simplistic manner that the High Court is above us all. Of course, it is not.

The parliament has the right to change laws, to make laws which suit our people, provided that they are in conformity with our constitution. We are quite entitled on matters of law, as Senator Evans knows, to override rulings of the High Court, provided that it is within our constitution. So the statement that Senator Evans made is simply not a correct statement. I believe it was an invitation to people to apply to the High Court to obtain these rights.

The other matter which raised very great concern—again I have to say to Senator Evans that this is why support for this bill is eroding—is that the government is setting up special rights for particular groups of people. Senator Evans said, `Well, you may not get the rights to mining profits and royalties through the normal processes of the law, but you may be able to get them through a social justice package paid for by all taxpayers'. The rest of us are not entitled to these things but, in answer to Senator Chamarette's question, Senator Evans said that it may be that if those native titleholders do not get it through a High Court decision—the way he has worded it, a lot of them may well be inclined to do so—they could perhaps get it through the government's social justice package. Of course, that would be paid for by all taxpayers.

Not all taxpayers would have the right to make a claim. That is why I put it to Senator Evans that he has raised further great uncertainties. He has not done anything to console the view that lots of Australians are starting to feel that we are setting up two laws for particular people. Could Senator Evans stop having a good little giggle with Senator Bolkus? This is a serious matter. Could he come back to his seat and take it seriously?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I'll do whatever I choose to do.
—We are debating a very serious bill. Senator Evans walks off to the side and has a little giggle with Senator Bolkus.
—Perhaps you should wait and not speak until he is ready to listen again.
—I'll listen as soon as you say something substantial.

—Senator Evans is not listening. He is laughing and giggling with Senator Bolkus who has made not one contribution to this debate. That he is even in the chamber is beyond belief. Senator Evans may not feel this, but I feel that I am making an important point. I would prefer it if he would do the chamber the courtesy—if he is not prepared to do me the courtesy—of listening to what I say.
—I am all agog. It had better be good, after all that.

—Senator Evans would not know whether what I said was good or indifferent because he is off having a little joke with Senator Bolkus. Could he explain to me why under the government's social justice package compensatory arrangements should be made for Aboriginal people for the share of profits on mining, or whatever, when there is no such provision for the majority of other people?
—I would like to answer some of the questions that Senator Kemp raised about what I was saying.
—The minister is the one to answer.

—I did gain the call. The questions that I wanted to put follow from the reply of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) to me and were raised in part by Senator Kemp. The minister said that there were no other instances where Aboriginal people could benefit from the minerals in their land. Yet I have it on good authority that the Bjelke-Petersen government's Aborigines act allowed for mining royalties to be payable on Aboriginal land. I have already mentioned the Northern Territory Land Rights Act and the New South Wales act. That indicates that this government, and the legislation it is presenting, is not even willing to leave open the option for that. That is my concern: not that it be written in, but that it not be written out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse what Senator Chamarette said about the existence in the Northern Territory, Queensland, Western Australia and South Australia of provision for access to Aboriginal land-holders with royalty equivalents. That is one of the points made in the June discussion paper when this issue was canvassed. As well as canvassing the various attractions of mining royalty equivalents, that discussion paper also canvassed the downside arguments. One of those downside arguments was the one put by Senator Kemp. It stated:

PARA.TAB: .non-Aboriginal land holders could react negatively to what would be seen as discrimination (as other land holders are not entitled to a royalty equivalent);

SPEECH.PARA: Also canvassed as a downside issue was the equity issue created because those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders without native title, or without conceivable capacity to begin to claim it, would not have the same access to these kinds of payments as other Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

PARA.TAB: So the argument will go on. It is not an argument that I am seeking to resolve today. I am simply making the point that there are more ways to produce a result than by the route down which the Greens are now proposing to go. The issue is still a live one as far as the government is concerned; we have not closed it off. While that might not persuade them to withdraw their amendment, it may be relevant to their understanding of why the government cannot support it. It might be helpful if I were to incorporate in Hansard paragraphs 9.10 to 9.18 of the discussion paper which bears upon this question. I think it might be a useful addition to the Hansard record. I seek leave to incorporate those paragraphs.
Leave granted.
The paragraphs read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: A. A Stake in Industry

9.10 ATSIC has proposed that the Commonwealth legislate to provide for the payment of an amount equal to one third of the royalties raised from particular resource developments on native title land to the native title holders of that land. ATSIC suggests that the payments be made to a corporation which represents the particular native title holders and be utilised for capital infrastructure and/or investment in the resource project or the companies involved in the project. This proposal would not involve additional cost for companies involved in resource development.

9.11 The concept of providing Aboriginal land holders with access to royalty equivalents is well established and operates in different forms in the Northern Territory, Queensland, Western Australia, and South Australia. It is consistent with long-standing Commonwealth Government policy and legislation in relation to resource development on Aboriginal land as evidenced in the Northern Territory. How these existing schemes relate to any new proposal would have to be considered.
9.12 The advantages of the ATSIC proposal include that it:
provides specific native title holders with a significant incentive to support resource development on their particular land;

has the potential to remove the structural conflict between resource developers and native title holders provided the scheme does not leave open the possibility of extra unexpected claims against the resource developer; and

addresses the perception among indigenous people that they do not benefit significantly from resource development of their land, and can provide for economic benefits to flow to the native title holders beyond the term of the resource development lease.
9.13 The scheme would need to—and could—avoid problems perceived by industry with the statutory scheme under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976.
9.14 On the other hand:
the financial cost to governments could be significant over the long term, and arrangements could be complex;
non-Aboriginal land holders could react negatively to what would be seen as discrimination (as other land holders are not entitled to a royalty equivalent);

there could be serious equity issues created because the scheme would not help Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people without native title or who hold native title to land on which there is no resource development; and

while obviously beneficial, a royalty equivalent is an unreliable way of providing a cash flow to finance investments for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as it will fluctuate in line with factors over which the native title holders have no control or influence—including, for example, world commodity prices and the efficiency of individual companies.

9.15 The questions of when such a scheme might start, and over which projects it would operate will need to be carefully considered. Would it, for example, only cover new projects and, if not, what would be the historical cut-off point? Decisions here would impact significantly on the total costs and benefits of the scheme.

9.16 At the same time there is a strong attraction in breaking down the false psychology which sees resource development and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander interests as being at odds, and in designing mechanisms which provide incentives for development. Accordingly, there is merit in canvassing modifications to the ATSIC proposals including:

rather than royalty equivalents, it may be preferable to create a revenue equivalents scheme based on allocation of a proportion of the royalties, taxes, fees, charges and economic rents collected by the community from all resource developments on native title land (i.e. not just mineral developments.) This could be regarded as logically consistent and would in fact broaden the scope for payments to include a share of revenue generated from tourist, fishing, forestry, pastoral interests and the like;

should governments pursue the concept of a land fund (see paras 9.19 to 9.25 below), it would be possible to allocate some of the revenue equivalent payments to the proposed land fund. Such an arrangement would be broadly comparable with the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account (ABTA) which operates in the Northern Territory; and

among the advantages of such a scheme is that the benefits would flow to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who have maintained their connection with the land and those who have been dispossessed;
on the other hand, the less the financial benefits to the native title holders, the less the direct stake in development. Also, the approach raises issues of financial equity between States; and

conceivably, the objective could be achieved without the use of revenue equivalents. For example, resource developers could be encouraged—and possibly facilitated by governments—to seek native titleholder participation through joint ventures.

9.17 A key question in relation to these proposals is cost. The purpose of this discussion paper is to explore concepts—at this stage no costing of schemes has been done. However, an essential point is that the overall cost would be very much in the hands of governments through decisions about the establishment of a scheme and the rates of revenue equivalents to be paid, etc.
9.18 How native title holders might best be encouraged to become stake holders in industry requires further examination.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Greens' amendment. I fail to be convinced by the arguments of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) on this issue. I believe that, in the normal course of events, royalties due to the Crown would obviously have precedence over any other debt owed by a mining operation. I therefore cannot see any reason in equity or in logic to permit payments to the native titleholders with reference to the amount of profits made—or, as the clause states, to `the income derived or things produced'. If we were to take that to its logical conclusion, we would have to prohibit the payment of dividends to people who have shares in a mining operation, because they are worked out by virtue of reference to the—
—It's worked out on the money invested.

—Not on the money invested; that is interest. I understand that shares carry dividends on the basis of profits derived from the enterprise. Senator Boswell can correct me if I am wrong, but I think I am right.

PARA.TAB: One also has to have a closer look at the piecework rates that are being paid to miners, because they are being paid in relation to the iron ore or gold that is produced in a mining operation. If these practices are established and accepted, it seems discriminatory, to my mind, to say that native titleholders, who surely have an interest in the land which will revive or continue on a continuing basis, should not be allowed to have a determination made which gives them some payments in proportion to the benefits derived from the land over which they have native title.

The amendment simply states that the arbitral body may determine. In other words, it simply gives a discretion to that body; it does not direct it to find in this way. It simply leaves the way open for the arbitral body to determine that.

Several honourable senators have been interjecting. I am rather surprised at that, because it seems to me that for the last four hours the majority of topics that have been addressed have been irrelevant, procedural or offensive. The substantive issues that have been addressed in four hours by the opposition or as a result of the opposition's intervention have taken no more than 24 minutes. I may be wrong by half a minute on that, but that is approximately the proportion. So it is somewhat surprising that all of a sudden the opposition is prepared to interject on a substantive issue. I welcome it and trust that the opposition will continue to make substantive contributions rather than irrelevant and abusive ones.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not make a point of order out of it, but for Senator Spindler to say that all the contributions made in the last four hours—
—Except the last four minutes.
—Except for the last four minutes. For him to say that they were insubstantive is most arrogant. But I guess we can expect that. Honourable senators have to respect the view—
—Read the Hansard, Senator.

—I have been in the chamber for the last four hours and have followed the debate very carefully. The issues are crucial. Perhaps Senator Spindler does not understand the issues and perhaps they are not substantive to him, but he should not cast judgment upon those senators who have bothered to be in the chamber and participate in the debate.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that across most of Australia minerals are vested in the Crown, except for a couple of small examples. Last week, Senator Crichton-Browne—I have forgotten what day it was, because the days seem to be flowing one into the other—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's still Thursday.
—I think it is ground hog day. Senator Crichton-Browne referred to that.
—They are only small exceptions, but they are exceptions.

—That is right. That is the case with minerals. A number of other commodities can be either grown or quarried on land. There is no doubt that freehold title owners could derive benefit from, for example, the planting of a forest and the future economic benefit of that or the extraction of sand, limestone or a whole range of other commodities which are not vested in the Crown.

PARA.TAB: It is my belief, and I think it is the view of the Greens, that we could again be breaching the Racial Discrimination Act. There is no doubt that a freehold title owner could reach an agreement to share in the profits from those extractions or other such acts. However, under this legislation native titleholders are specifically excluded from reaching some form of agreement. For example, if a company wants to obtain a grant—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they are not. What clause are you basing that on?

—That was general preamble. I will give the minister an example of this specific issue. Suppose a company wants a grant to establish a forest plantation on native title land and the native titleholders want to negotiate a 50 per cent profit sharing arrangement in relation to that forest plantation some time down the track. The company that wants to establish this plantation is happy to say, `We would rather give you 10 per cent of the profits further down the track.'

PARA.TAB: This legislation says that the tribunal would not be able to resolve that issue. In other words, instead of the tribunal saying that it will arbitrate and give the native titleholders, say, 30 per cent of the future profits, it says that the company that wants to establish the plantation will not be able to establish it; it will not be able to get its 10 per cent and the native titleholders will not get their 50 per cent. This legislation specifically excludes that process from taking place.

That would not be the case if it took place on freehold land. Again we have a fundamental difference—I hope the minister will tell me if I am wrong—between what a person with freehold title over land would do and what native titleholders would do. In my view that is discriminatory.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of points made by the opposition and the minister ought to be addressed. The minister has referred constantly to royalties being based on a profit-sharing arrangement. It must be noted that profit sharing is one method only of calculating royalties. There are a number of methods used in various parts of the country. Royalties are a payment for the use of resources. The way royalties are calculated depends sometimes on the mineral or the resource that is being extracted and sometimes on the nature of the industry. It can vary from place to place and from circumstance to circumstance. It is not simply a profit-sharing arrangement because it is payment for the use of resources.

PARA.TAB: It has been constantly mentioned that there is one rule for Aboriginal people and another rule for everybody else; that does not hold true. Governments forgo such resource payments for a variety of reasons and for a variety of deals. This means that the payment for that resource is forgone for some commercial reasons, which are not necessarily in legislation. It is usually done on a case-by-case basis. Governments, whether state or federal, have the ability to do that.

For example, only 0.56 per cent of the average rate of royalties on mineral sands is collected in Western Australia compared with the rest of Australia. That is because of the number of deals where that royalty is forgone. The royalty is shared with the company that is mining the sand. There are a number of instances where this occurs. It is not a matter of there being one rule for the people extracting, or one rule for landowners and one rule for everybody else.

Certainly in Western Australia, royalty sharing or payments for resources are adjusted, almost on a case-by-case basis, often without the knowledge of anybody until somebody finds the secret records. This practice has involved both political parties. Royalties deals arise constantly, depending on the circumstance and depending on what the companies and government think is just, fair or proper at the time. The government says that this does not apply to land-holders, but we are talking about sharing in the benefits of a resource. It is perfectly clear that if it is seen to be appropriate to share in the benefits of that resource with the company extracting it, even forgoing payment of it for an entire year, then it is perfectly appropriate to share the benefits of those resources with people with native title.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be helpful if I answer Senator Campbell's questions. The important thing to realise about the amendments to section 36 is that they apply only to the right to negotiate provisions of subdivision (b) of clause 25. In turn, in clause 25 it is made clear that the right to negotiate that we are talking about and the arbitral response that is triggered if that negotiation breaks down, applies only to certain limited situations. Those situations are, firstly, mining related situations and, secondly, compulsory acquisition for a third person. That is made clear in clause 25(2).

PARA.TAB: Clause 25(2) is the way into this whole subdivision (b) about the right to negotiate and, eventually, when we get to section 36, arbitral determinations. So forestry development has no application in the context of these provisions. If people want to get agreement with native titleholders about a forestry development of the kind that Senator Campbell was contemplating, that is a reasonably straightforward matter. They can normally get a forestry development going only with the agreement of the freeholder owning the land in question. Then they can negotiate their commercial arrangement to their hearts' content.

The freehold equivalent principle applies here. A forestry company can negotiate with the native titleholders as though they were freeholders. It would get its commercial deal negotiated and bedded down as a result. None of this would involve the application of this arbitral process one way or the other. I hope that has clarified the situation for Senator Campbell because I know there is a bit of confusion around as to the precise context in which this arbitral stuff works and about profit related payments being determined. It is only in the very limited context that I have described that that would be excluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a number of points with respect to what has arisen over the last three quarters of an hour of questioning. I will run through them as quickly as I can. I have no doubt that in respect of a mineral development, if it comes down to the fundamentals of extraction of royalties, Senator Margetts would prefer to see a situation where that process stopped mining in total. The situation of state governments negotiating for a royalty level which would allow the economic development of a mine—whether it be mineral sands or what have you—is quite different from the situation of a claim for profit sharing with respect to royalties. At the end of the day, the requirement is that there must be profitability within the company. If the royalties they have to pay are set too high, companies will make a decision not to go ahead. That is a commercial reality. I refer to a speech made quite some time ago—
—A mining subsidy is what you mean, isn't it?

—I did not hear that interjection, but I will ignore it anyway. I refer to what Senator Gareth Evans had to say some time ago in response to Senator Chamarette's amendment. In a short speech—unfortunately, Senator Boswell has left the chamber—we heard the best and the worst of Senator Gareth Evans. At one stage he was suggesting that Senator Boswell should go back to school. If that is the case, perhaps Senator Evans, because of inconsistencies in his answers and his avoidance of answers, should go back to kindergarten.
—Preschool.
—Preschool, as Senator Panizza said. Is Senator Evans listening to me?
—I listen to every word you drop, Winston. Go for it.

—We have heard Senator Evans at his seductive best with the Greens. In fact, in essence Senator Evans said, `I love you dearly, but you'll have to wait till tomorrow'. Then he went through a whole range of processes—
—I take offence at that and I take offence at the creeping nomenclature that has a sexual connotation. I ask for that remark to be withdrawn.
—Order! Senator Margetts, there is no point of order. As somebody else interjected, it might be a point of irritation but it is not a point of order.
—Is it not, if it is something at which we take offence? The point of order is that I take that form of expression as offensive and sexist, and I would like it to be withdrawn on that basis.
—On a point of order, Mr Chairman, this morning I brought up this matter of taking offence. People's skins are getting thinner and thinner as we go on towards Christmas.
—I'm not getting thinner and thinner.

—No, Senator Collins might not be. Seriously though, on the point of order, I do not believe that the remark has to be withdrawn. Of course, Mr Chairman, you will make up your mind, as always, but we are getting on to pretty thin ice if we have to start withdrawing those sorts of things. I think Senator Collins might agree about getting on thin ice.

—If I could take a point of order, there are two very serious points involved here. The principal one is that Senator Crane described as `seductive' Senator Evans's debating manner as directed at the Greens. He did not name any person. It is a perfectly legitimate use of a figure of speech to describe debating language in that way. There is nothing wrong with that at all. It is outrageous to suggest that the full range of the English language is not available to us in this chamber. Secondly, it is grossly wrong for people to get up and take points of order when they do not have the faintest idea of the standing order under which they are protesting.

—Order! Given the advice and guidance of the chamber, I think that I am now capable of ruling on the matter. The expression is neither disorderly nor unparliamentary. While it may be a term of endearment which some people do not enjoy, to the extent that it does not fall into either of the former two categories, it is not contrary to standing orders.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I simply make the point that it was not intended to be either. I will leave it at that. Perhaps when I come to the point, Senator Margetts and Senator Chamarette will realise what I am getting at. I will try to put it in other words.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans went over a number of grounds. He said, `Let us look at the future; this might happen', et cetera, and that is on the public record. My question to Senator Evans and Senator Chamarette—and now to Senator Margetts—is this: in view of the explanation given by Senator Evans, how do they reconcile what he said here with the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in a press release dated 24 November 1993—I can either incorporate or table this—when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I met this morning with several Aboriginal representatives who put forward various proposals for change to the bill. I made it completely clear that a number of these were simply unacceptable.
It is very clear, straightforward language. He went on:
For example, vesting of mineral rights in native title holders and a right of veto over developments on native title lands cannot be accepted.

This is what I wanted to draw out here. In terms of the answer given by Senator Evans, one has to question who is right in regard to what the Prime Minister was talking about—Senator Evans or Mr Keating. There is still an enormous amount of uncertainty surrounding this particular question. Or is it the case that the government has simply changed its mind? That is the matter to be addressed. I cannot think of a more succinct way of putting it than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot think of a more succinct way of replying than to say there is no foundation whatsoever for suggesting that the government has changed its mind, is considering changing its mind or may change its mind on the question of the specific vesting of mineral rights in native titleholders. That is no part of our thinking, for reasons that have been amply set out by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

PARA.TAB: The only point I made in reply to Senator Chamarette is that the High Court has not passed upon the question as to the extent to which, if at all, mineral rights could be regarded as being associated with native title, or at least some forms of native title. The High Court has not passed upon it. From what it has said, there is no reason whatsoever to think it would conclude that mineral rights are part of native title. The matter simply was not argued before them, so the issue has not been addressed.

All I was saying is that the legislation does not rule out the possibility of that issue being tested at some time in the future. If it was tested in the future, in my own judgment, as the government's judgment, as to what the state of the law is—bearing in mind what the High Court said about the nature of native title and knowing what we do about what is necessary to achieve extraction in most forms of minerals these days other than surface outcrops—the notion of mineral rights below the surface existing as part of native title is a pretty highly implausible one. I do not think anyone should be getting too excited about the possibility of that occurring.

I was just simply saying to Senator Chamarette, as I have said on a number of other occasions—for example, in the context of extinguishment of native title and in the context of valid pastoral leases—that is an issue which simply has not been finally resolved by the High Court and which is left open by the terms of the legislation, and deliberately so.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister should look very carefully at the answer that he gave earlier on. In my view he has canvassed a much wider area than what he canvassed at that particular point. At some time in the future he might like to clarify it a little more.

—Surely the matter is even simpler than Senator Gareth Evans has explained it. This bill is talking about either the restoration of traditional rights to Aboriginals or compensation for them, in the simplest way of describing it. The Aboriginals simply never exercised a mining right. They have never mined silver, gold, lead, zinc or iron. Therefore, there is no traditional right to be re-established. They have not suffered the deprivation of any right or privilege that they exercised. Since they never exercised that privilege, it is therefore quite illogical to depart from the normal course of legal pattern in this country and grant them rights de novo. If they are going to be granted rights de novo, let us go to the North American system and let all landowners have title to what is underneath the soil.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am absolutely surprised that Senator Gareth Evans has said that the parliament is subservient to the High Court. I do not think that would be accepted in the community.
—I know it keeps coming as a terrible surprise to you, but it is true—to the extent that our legislation could be struck down.

—I find it very difficult to understand, and even more difficult to accept, that the rights of the people can be set in place by six or eight unelected people. I would have thought that if the High Court's decision were unacceptable to this parliament then, as long as they were in line with the constitution, this parliament would have the right—in fact, the duty—to override any High Court decision. But that is an academic debate.
—That is true. I do not disagree with that. As long as we are still within the scope of the constitution.

—We are getting agreement on at least one thing. That is contrary to what the minister said. The Greens are asking that Aboriginal native titleholders have mineral rights but are against other sections of Australia having similar rights. If Aboriginal native titleholders have those rights, they would then be able to negotiate. I think Senator Chamarette said they would be similar to the rights of the Northern Territory Aboriginals.
—And New South Wales and Queensland.

—I am not sure about New South Wales. But it is definitely incorrect about Queensland. Native titleholders of DOGIT land may have some rights for quarrying—the extraction of stone—and certainly forestry rights; but I do not believe they do. I am quite sure they do not have mineral rights.

PARA.TAB: I just draw to the Greens' attention the folly of going down this track. I do not have the exact figures in front of me, but in the Northern Territory something like 23 mineral leases have been given out in the last eight or nine years and about 560 have been held up by the right of veto. I put it to Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts that no-one in this parliament wants to see the rights of Aboriginals extinguished—or anything like that.

But what we have to face—and this is something the Greens do not understand—is that to give Aboriginals the benefits, rights and land we are giving them, someone has to provide the overall amount of money. Their particular needs are DOGIT land, schools, hospitals and so on. If we kill the goose that lays the golden egg, not only will our first Australians not benefit but no Australian will benefit. The Greens are trying to kill the right of—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are wasting your time, Boswell.

—This is in hope rather than in expectation, but I will make one final attempt to persuade Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts. To give benefits to people, someone has to raise the necessary money. A piece of paper was being circulated around here today on what the mining veto has cost the government and miners of the Northern Territory. It has cost billions of dollars in wealth not being created; therefore, that wealth has not been able to be passed on to all Australians. If the Greens can tell me how we can meet the needs of people who are on social welfare and other types of benefits by stopping the creation of wealth and jobs, I would very much like to hear their explanation.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that the Greens want the best of both worlds, and they are being totally impractical. They want to be able to pass benefits on to Aboriginal people, people on social welfare and the underprivileged. But, we have to have a society that can create those benefits before we can pass them back. The government does not have a big bucket of money it can go and dip into to pass out to people. I know it is hard to understand—and the Greens might not like or even accept it—but it is a fact of life that, to be able to pass financial benefits on, one has to allow for some wealth creation.

If the Greens stop Australia's mining industry—which employs, I think, about 470,000 people and creates $20 billion in export wealth—they are harming people who live in remote and regional Australia, including our first Australians. They are also hurting people on the lower end of the social scale. The Greens come in here on fairly significant parliamentary salaries—and I am not suggesting that they do not earn them.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the same as yours.
—It is the same as mine.
—Probably a little less.

—Probably a little less; nonetheless, they cannot accept, because they are on that sort of money, that people down the other end of the scale who are less fortunate have to be provided for. The only way they will be provided for is if we not only extract minerals from the ground but also have pastoral companies that produce wealth.

PARA.TAB: What the Greens are trying to do by this amendment is stop that. They are going to give what they would call a right to discuss but, in the end, that becomes a right of veto that is similar to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. That has been nothing more than a disaster for Australia.

I would like the Greens to consider what I have said to them, as friendly advice, when they formulate some of these amendments that they put before the parliament. No-one is suggesting that they do not have the right direction; no-one is suggesting that their hearts are not in the right place. But while their hearts may be in the right place, their minds are not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just happen to have those figures that Senator Boswell was looking for. In relation to this amendment, I do not think the Greens have their hearts in the right place at all. I believe that they are attempting to harvest votes today—just a few extra votes that may help to hold them in this position after the next election round. That is simply the only cynical reason they have moved this amendment. We had a very similar situation last Saturday that was voted down.

PARA.TAB: If it were not for Northern Territory land rights, production of minerals would have been worth $600 million more—I am not saying $600 million in total—in 1993 alone. They also cost 4,480 jobs, which is about six per cent of the current work force in the Northern Territory. Further to that, the most likely estimate of this cost by the Centre for International Economics is that an additional $2,390 million of income could have been generated since the introduction of land rights; in other words, $2.390 billion.

If the situation is not fixed in the Northern Territory, that cost will rise to $8,000 million in the future, which is $8 billion. To give honourable senators an example of how this fits into the context—I am sure Senator Jones is interested in this being next door in Queensland—that $8 billion would be worth four times the annual production of gold in Australia or four wheat crops. Even if the problems with current land rights were rectified, the report indicated that the income forgone would still be a minimum of $2 billion, and that is more than one Australian wool clip a year.

This amendment shows that the Greens attempt to be nice to the Aborigines just for the sake of getting a few extra votes. Senator Chamarette can shake her head as much as she likes. If she is prepared to move an amendment to give all freehold land-holders in Australia mineral rights, I might support her. That would be a very personal and very biased view towards freehold land-holders. But if they want to move this amendment, they should apply it to everyone, not just a few people. As I have said in this place before, I believe that all Australians should be treated the same before the law in Australia, and anywhere else for that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief because I do want to move this amendment, although I know that we do not have the numbers. I want to reply to some of the charges that have been made as to the meaning of this amendment; I believe it needs clarification. The right of veto has not been under discussion; it was simply the capacity to enter into negotiations about profit sharing. It gives the mining companies or the developers an actual bargaining base that could be in their interests as much as in the interests of the native titleholders. It is simply leaving the option open. It is not a discussion of right of veto. That is why Senator Crane's objection is not appropriate. We have not raised that, although we would love to.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that when everybody talks about how the mining veto has been such a disaster in the Northern Territory, they fail to mention that in Western Australia owners of all freehold rural land—be it used for wheat, sheep, wineries, orchards or parkland grazing—have a veto over mining and mining exploration. This does not seem to have impeded the economic progress of Western Australia. That veto is present; we are not discussing it at the moment and the amendment of the Greens has nothing to do with the mining veto. However, it is relevant in the sense that the actual negotiation powers with the companies under consideration are limited if there is an explicit denial of a capacity to set a determination relating to sharing of royalties. It is also a relevant factor in terms of compensation. That is what the Greens are presenting. There is a cut-down of negotiation rights if, within this bill, there is an explicit exclusion of any capacity to discuss terms of profit sharing that would benefit both parties in the discussion, not simply the native titleholders.

I also wanted to correct the impression that we were given by Senator MacGibbon that Aboriginal people have never shown any interest in mining. In fact, the world's oldest mine—the ochre mine at Wilgi-Mia—is 20,000 years old and has been managed on an ecologically sustainable basis for 20,000 years. Repeatedly, Aboriginal people have said that they are not opposed to mining development. They do not have a universal position. They do not necessarily come from the same position as the Greens in relation to mining. We believe that they deserve the right of self-determination in those matters. That is why we want the option left open rather than closed.

I heard Senator Evans's reassurance that this clause is not meant to exclude something. If that is the case, it should not be there. However, I accept the reality of the political numbers here, so I request that we move the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Chamarette wants to talk about the veto situation that operates in Western Australia, she should tell us how it operates fully. It is not an absolute veto. What is more, there is no veto on uncleared crown land. Senator Chamarette can shake her head as much as she wants; I know what I am talking about. Should a mining company not get a freehold land-holder's permission to go on to that land, they can apply to the wardens court.
