The wardens court will hear both sides of the argument and will sometimes grant permission to enter. A company can also do the same when it wants to peg a mineral lease. If the land-holder does not agree, the company can go to the court and the court can give permission for that lease to operate. Furthermore, the court can impose a compensation clause.

PARA.TAB: In the past, rather than having a court decision imposed on them, the mining companies and the freeholders have come to an arrangement between themselves. If one wants to insist on cleared ground on one's veto, the court can give a licence to mine a certain distance below the surface. How they get there remains to be seen. There are different methods. They can mine a small amount of ground or use some other form of access, and then get underneath.

Senator Chamarette should know the facts before she tells us the full story about the situation that exists. If she wants to insist on this measure and if she wants to convince the government to put in this type of royalty for Aborigines or native titleholders, let her do so for all freehold land. If she is going to do that for all freehold land, please do so pretty quickly—for my selfish reasons—such as in the next couple of months.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to return to the forest plantation lease example. I think a fundamental error has been made in the minister's original answer. With things the way they are at the moment, the government cannot grant a forest plantation lease over a piece of freehold land. If the government were to grant a forest plantation lease over native title land, it would have to compulsorily acquire the native title land to establish it.

—Or get the agreement. That is the point I was making. As with an ordinary freehold owner, normally you would expect this thing to be done by negotiation rather than by government grant. Native title right holders would be in the same position as a freeholder in that respect. It would be a negotiated commercial agreement.

—That would presume that a forest plantation could be established on a piece of native title land by negotiation. The real world would say that a forest plantation lease should be established by government, but I guess that is a point of conjecture. If two parties are wanting to negotiate on a profit share, the government, under this bill, is saying that profit share can be negotiated if a person has normal freehold title. But under this legislation the tribunal cannot make a determination. So both the forest plantation company and the native titleholders end up with a situation they do not want.

—The threshold point I was making before and I make again is that there is no jurisdiction for the tribunal to make any determination at all in relation to negotiation over a forestry lease, forestry joint venture or a forestry venture of any kind. That is just not within the tribunal's range of arbitral powers under clause 36. Clause 36 deals with only the situations I have described that come out of clause 25(2); that is, the consequences of the right to negotiate being given in two particular situations: first in relation to mining; and, secondly, in relation to compulsory acquisition on behalf of third persons.

PARA.TAB: If one wanted to go down the path of compulsory acquisition from the native titleholders in order to vest a forestry lease in a third person then, yes, all of this would come into play, but only if one went down that particular path. If one went down any other path, then all one has is a capacity to, as with any other freeholder in the state, enter into a commercial agreement. That is how it works.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to respond to Senator Boswell's contribution. I usually enjoy his earthy and pithy summaries of the issues, but occasionally he gets it wrong and this is one such occasion. A good part of his contribution was directed to the argument that payments could not be afforded by a mining operation. I would have thought that a payment that is related to profits, in other words after profits are made, is a lot less onerous than a payment that is levied on a mine or on a mining operation before any profit is determined and that obligation that is in existence, whether or not a profit is made.
—The fact is that the right to negotiate exists not only for the native titleholders but also for native title claimants. Is that correct?

—The right to negotiate, in the sense in which we are talking about it, does apply to claimants, but only to registered claimants. Again, it is only in these narrow situations—with mining on the one hand and compulsory acquisition and the rights of third parties on the other hand. They have a right to negotiate in that situation.
—We have gone through this before. Just about anyone can register as a native title claimant—that is an exaggeration, of course.

—That will be made clearer when we get to clauses 56 and 57, which deal with this and will be the subject of some amendments which have been circulated. Already there are grounds for striking out frivolous and vexatious claims and so on. There are threshold criteria that have to be satisfied before a person can be registered. There will be a further provision moved whereby a person can seek the right to strike out before a presidential member—that is, a judicial member of the tribunal—in situations where no prima facie right can be established. From the point of view of people worried about vexatious claims being made—which would be a practical inhibition to these sorts of developments—and people being forced into negotiations in frivolous situations, we have covered that pretty well, but we will debate it further when we get to it.

—I did not want to debate that now. I made one comment that was a slight exaggeration and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) has just spent two minutes reacting to it. The point I was trying to make was that native title claimants can be a party to these negotiations. If a profit sharing deal came up—this is something that could happen if the Crown sought to grant a forest plantation lease over some crown land that was subject to native title claim—the tribunal could not resolve the matter because it would be totally outside the jurisdiction of the tribunal. It is barred by this provision from finding some agreement.

—If a person chooses to get there by a compulsory acquisition route, Senator Campbell is right; I do not contest that. But the more usual situation will be the mining situation. If we start getting into profit related jurisdiction, we get into the sort of trouble that we were talking about previously. I hope it will be understood that that is a reasonable limitation in the circumstances.

—The point to this is that it is not only mining. The provisions of clause 25 bring in other things. The forest plantation situation is an easy example for people to understand, but there is a range of other circumstances. This clause supports in part the Greens' proposition that native titleholders and claimants are specifically excluded from negotiating these sorts of deals, whereas people in a freehold situation could do so. To that extent, I think we have a discriminatory situation being established.

—No, that is still not right. They are not prohibited from negotiating something. All that is being prohibited by the limited scope of clause 36 is the capacity of the tribunal—negotiations having broken down—to force upon the parties a profit sharing or profit related formula. There is no exclusion of the right to negotiate such an agreement.

PARA.TAB: In the overwhelming majority of cases, particularly those where there is no capacity for a tribunal to determine it, in practice one would reasonably expect that agreement to be reached. Senator Campbell is partially right in saying that a tribunal cannot make a determination on a forestry related matter if it happens to come up through that compulsory acquisition route; I am not disagreeing with that. But to take the further step of saying that a right to negotiate is not there in that situation is not so. Native titleholders would be in the same circumstances as ordinary freeholders, and there is no tribunal anywhere that enables ordinary freeholders to get an arbitration on a profit related solution to a failed negotiation. If we were to give such a solution to native titleholders, that would be doing something different from that which is available to ordinary freeholders.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chamarette's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a joint statement issued a few moments ago by the Premiers and the Leader of the Federal Opposition (Dr Hewson).

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The joint statement read—

SPEECH.PARA: 20 December 1993
JOINT STATEMENT BY THE LEADER OF THE FEDERAL OPPOSITION AND STATE AND TERRITORY LIBERAL HEADS OF GOVERNMENT

The passage of the Federal Government's Mabo legislation through the Parliament has become totally confused. The Government is trying to railroad through the Senate hundreds of last minute amendments on the basis of deals with minority Parties.
This is a completely unacceptable way in which such complex and major legislation should be dealt with.

Most major industry groups now believe that the Federal Mabo legislation in its current form is unworkable and, at a minimum, should be delayed until next year so that a proper assessment of its implications can be made.
In the light of these realities, we believe that consideration of the Mabo legislation in the Federal Parliament should be delayed.

We also believe that the legislation should be referred to the next meeting of Federal, State and Territory Heads of Government scheduled for February. That meeting should aim to produce a simpler, more workable and more co-operative Commonwealth/State approach to the legislative consequences of the High Court's Mabo decision.

In the end, it is the States, with their constitutional responsibilities for land management, which should have a substantial say in determining the final form of the Mabo legislation, and not minority parties in the Senate that have shown that they do not understand the issues involved.
John Hewson MP, Leader of the Federal Opposition
Richard Court MLA, Premier of Western Australia
Jeff Kennett, Premier of Victoria
Dean Brown, Premier of South Australia
Barry Coulter MLA, Acting Chief Minister of the Northern Territory
John Fahey MP, Premier of New South Wales
Ray Groom MHA, Premier of Tasmania

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the committee. This joint statement is signed by John Hewson, Jeff Kennett, John Fahey, Richard Court, Dean Brown, Ray Groom and Barry Coulter, the Acting Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. This joint statement calls upon this chamber not to proceed further with the committee stage of the bill but to allow it to be further considered in February on the basis of their unanimous view that:

SPEECH.PARA: This is a completely unacceptable way in which such complex and major legislation should be dealt with.

Most major industry groups now believe that the Federal Mabo legislation in its current form is unworkable and, at a minimum, should be delayed until next year so that a proper assessment of its implications can be made.

In the end, it is the States, with their constitutional responsibilities for land management, which should have a substantial say in determining the final form of the Mabo legislation, and not minority parties in the Senate that have shown that they do not understand the issues involved.
It is a very serious statement, of which I hope the committee takes full cognisance by deferring the committee stage of the debate until next year.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague's statement raises certain questions that I will direct to Senator Gareth Evans. All the Australian Premiers bar one—Mr Goss has indicated today that he is not in favour of this legislation—wish to discuss the Native Title Bill at a meeting they are having on 20 February. If the Premiers are inclined not to bring in state legislation to support the federal legislation, what would be the position? Would this federal bill have any effect? Would it fall to the ground?

—At the end of the day, this scheme has never depended absolutely on state cooperation. If cooperation is not forthcoming from the states and they do not bring in legislation through their own legislative mechanisms, to the extent of our constitutional capacity, we will do it for them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —That raises certain practical problems. How would the federal government set up a parallel land administration system? Would it have to set up a titles office in every state or would it have a central titles office in Canberra? What would the practicalities be if the conservative state governments and the Queensland Labor government were to say, `We are not particularly interested in this bill until 20 February when we are having our meeting. We believe it is non-functional at the moment and it will have an effect on our state coffers. We are not of a mind to administer or service any requests that would be imposed on us by the Native Title Bill if it were to get through'? Is Senator Evans with me?
—I am sorry, I missed the last bit. I heard what you were saying about registries.
—What I am saying is we now have a statement from five out of the six Premiers and one senior minister—
—Goss is not very happy.

—Premier Goss has indicated today that he is most unhappy with the legislation. If these Premiers were of a mind not to give the government access to the state titles office, how would the government implement this legislation? Would it have to set up a parallel system, duplicate all titles in Australia and have them in a central office in Canberra? What would be the practicalities if the state governments were not to service this Native Title Bill?

—While obviously it is more helpful all round if there is that kind of cooperation through state titles offices, it is not necessary for the purpose of the effective operation of the bill for that to be a part of its central administration. It is a matter of claims being made and those claims being processed and subject to determination by tribunals of the kind that will be established. If they will not be established under state law, they will be established under this legislation. I think it is really quite premature to be making judgments about lack of state cooperation.
—We are not.

—I am not sure on what considered reading of the various amendments that have been passed that statement is made. I can imagine there being a bit of angst about the failure to pass the amendment to clause 24 on Saturday night, because that was an issue about which the mining and pastoralist industries had made a considerable fuss—not because, I repeat, there is anything fundamentally omitted in the legislation at the moment, but it was really a belt and braces exercise. It was putting into substantive statutory provisions that which had been implicit. The failure to pass that amendment has not in any way fundamentally changed the course of the legislation or its likely impact.

PARA.TAB: The various other amendments that we have been passing on the way through, or for which the government has shadowed or qualified support, have mostly tended to be—if any side of the argument is discernible—on the side of assisting to clarify issues from an Aboriginal perspective. Nonetheless, I do not think there is anything the states should be getting unduly fussed about. It is a matter of looking very carefully at what we have been able to accomplish. I doubt very much that the states have had an opportunity to do that so far. If they had had an opportunity, I doubt very much that they would be very strident in their anxieties.

I do not think that we ought to get too carried away or too distracted by all of this. We have a legislative job to do here. The government is determined to get on with it. If there are any things that have upset the states in terms of the knocking back of three pro-industry amendments, then it is Senator Boswell's colleagues in the Liberal Party who have more to answer for in that respect than anybody else. I do not want to set that particular hare running again. Let us get on with the substantive debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The effect of the government not getting clause 24 passed is that no-one will be able to renew, with any certainty about their validity, any pastoral or mining leases granted over native title land. Such a determination could take years. Valid pastoral or mining leases, where there is any native title present, cannot be renewed under the bill. That is the effect of not passing clause 24.
—That is not true—you have overstated the position.
—I think it is. Mr Griffiths, on 3 February 1993, gave an absolutely ironclad commitment to existing land-holders—something like Mr Kerin's commitment to the wool industry. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In responding to the High Court decision on native title, we made it clear that existing grants of interest in relation to property would continue. It is wrong to see the High Court's decision in terms of existing land holders losing their land.
We remain committed to this principle. The Commonwealth, in cooperation with the states would, if necessary, act to ensure that the rights of existing land holders are protected.
We are committed to treating this decision properly, in full consultation with both state and territory governments, and, of course, other stakeholders.
Mr Crean gave a similar commitment to the farmers at the national outlook conference on 2 February 1993. He said:

In October last year, the government in responding to the High Court decision on native title, made it clear that existing grants of interest in relation to property will continue, and it is wrong to see the High Court's decision in terms of existing land holders losing their land.
They must have been using the same speech writer. He continued:
We are committed to this principle and the Commonwealth, in cooperation with the states, would, if necessary, act to ensure that the rights of existing land holders are protected.
We are committed to treating this decision properly, in full consultation with states and territory governments and other stakeholders.

Senator Evans has not only given a commitment to the states, but he has also given a commitment to Mr Crean, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy; Mr Griffiths, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development; and, to Mr Lee, now the Minister for Resources. I understand that there have been six or seven commitments given to the relevant ministers. That is not only an important clause, but an essential clause to the bill. The bill cannot operate without clause 24. Through losing the vote on the passing of that clause, the government has lost the support of Richard Court, Jeff Kennett, Dean Brown, Barry Coulter—

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't know if you had them before.

—The support of John Fahey and Ray Groom was also lost. All those premiers have peeled away from the government, as has the National Farmers Federation. The government now has no support. The minister has tried to sidestep the question and swerve around it. I ask him to answer it honestly: if these state premiers are not of a mind to give the Commonwealth its state facilities on land management, such as access to the titles office, how will the government work this bill effectively? In other words, what will the Commonwealth do if it is locked out of their titles offices? How will it get around it? Will it send in ASIO to break in and take their files? What will be its course of operation?

PARA.TAB: As I see it, the Native Title Bill needs state cooperation. If the Commonwealth does not need state cooperation, it should pass the whole Native Title Bill to the states for them to administer under their own legislation, which we would support. The track we are now going down seems to lead to a dead end. Unless the Commonwealth gets cooperation from the state premiers, it will not be able to implement this legislation.

I would like the minister to tell this Senate how it will do it if the states will not cooperate. Will federal legislation give the Commonwealth the power to go in, override their decisions and allow access to their files; or would some sort of international convention give it that power? How does it intend to do it? I believe the whole Senate and all the Australian people would like to know how the government will implement this legislation without some form of access.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell raised a very good point which Senator Gareth Evans very flippantly dismissed. When Senator Evans answers Senator Boswell, I ask him to indicate whether he has any idea of how land titles registries work. For a QC who did not know the difference between joint tenancy and tenancy in common, I suspect that he has little idea of the practical aspects of titles offices.

PARA.TAB: I do not speak on behalf of anyone, but it is fairly clear that the government has never had Richard Court's support in this matter. Senator Boswell has raised a point which I wish the minister to comment upon. The government has to get descriptions of land, details of the registered owners of land, easements across the land and mortgages on it. How will the Commonwealth government possibly do that if, for example Richard Court—who has indicated that he will fight this to the death—says, `You're not getting into our titles office. You'll not see who owns the land, who has the easements and all that sort of thing'?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a threat? Are you threatening on behalf of the Western Australian government that it will stop publicly accessible records being made available?
—Are you interjecting or taking a point of order?
—I am interjecting.

—The minister should not interject; that is unruly. I am not speaking on behalf of anyone—obviously I have no authority to—but I am saying that it is a reasonably logical extension of what has been happening so far.

PARA.TAB: Richard Court has said in the past—correct me if I am wrong—that he will fight this to the very end because he believes that it is a matter of very great concern to his state. The Western Australian government is even talking about secession. I am not making those threats. Can Senator Evans fathom what would happen if Richard Court said—I am not saying that he will—`It's all shut up. You cannot get in and find out who the registered proprietor and lessee is, who has the mortgages, who has easements and who has the right of way'.

If that happens, where is the government going to go? We simply cannot set up a Commonwealth registry. We could add to that list the other Liberal states. I am not suggesting that they would do it. I know Mr Goss is very concerned about these latest developments. There are 3,000 pastoral leases in Queensland that are to go into no-man's-land on 1 January. Mr Goss for his own political survival will have to do something about that. He might have to say, `Look, we will just shut up shop. You will not get in'.

I do not know how this works. I am asking the minister to explain it to me. If one is making a claim over land, one has to be able to describe it. One cannot just say, `I claim Cape York', `the land around Aurukun' or `a little corner of Shark Bay'. One might be able to get descriptions off maps. One might get halfway there.

But what about the registered proprietors? How is one to find out who the proprietors are? Who are claims going to be against? Maybe the claimants will have to search that and perhaps file an extract of title when they file their claim. I suppose that is what they might do. They could get an extract to their title and file it in court, and from that the Commonwealth and the native title registry could start building up a whole new system of land register. If that is the case, has the minister any idea what that might cost.

These titles offices in the states have been going for centuries. The cost of re-establishing a new Commonwealth titles office system would be absolutely prohibitive. It is a real concern. Perhaps it has been thought about before. It did not seem from the comments given to the minister by the adviser that it had been thought of. Senator Boswell raised a very valid point that I would appreciate the minister's answer to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you tell me how relevant this is to clauses 25 to 39?

—I am following on from the statements that were made. I am not aware how it is relevant. Senator Teague incorporated, by leave, a document and Senator Boswell has been speaking to it. If the point is correct—I am hoping that the minister might be able to assure me it is not—the government has enormous problems and difficulties.

—I will respond quickly to this matter and then return to the substance of clauses 25 to 39. It is a complete misconception to think that the Commonwealth or any tribunal established by the Commonwealth needs to have a complete title registry of its own or even have access to it. The job of establishing the details of the land which is the subject of the claim is the responsibility of the claimant. The claimants are the ones that will need access to the public documents in those state and territory title registers.

PARA.TAB: It is a most extraordinary suggestion—I think the full implications of it ought to be thought about very carefully by Senator Ian Macdonald before he starts giving this greater currency than he has already—that bloody-minded state Premiers or parliaments might be moved to go so far as, in effect, close off to public access, not merely Commonwealth government access, from potential claimants the registry simply because of the nature of the claim that they might conceivably make. It is an absolutely extraordinary suggestion that there should be some closure—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is less extraordinary than secession.

—It is about as extraordinary as secession. It amounts to something approximating secession and it certainly would be a grossly irresponsible course for any state to follow. Moreover, it is one that I would like to see sought to be immunised from court intervention in the sense that it would not take too smart a lawyer on behalf of a claimant to be able to draft a mandamus or prohibition action of a kind pursuant to these provisions of Commonwealth law if there were any attempt to close that off.

PARA.TAB: Moreover, any attempt to close off a registry would manifestly work to the disadvantage of a great many non-Aboriginal land-holders right around the place who might be only too keen to be able to quickly establish that land in relation to which a native title claim is being made is freehold, the subject of a proper freehold grant such that a native title claim cannot get started.

When Senator Ian Macdonald gives someone the benefit of his considered wisdom on this matter, he ought to think very hard about the implications of all that, so far as a title exercise and a defensive exercise by land-holders in respect of whom a claim is made is concerned. None of these points make any sense at all. They are just an example of the half-baked, crazy, throwaway lines we have been getting from Western Australia, in particular, and so many people on the other side of this particular argument. Might I suggest that it is time to get back to the clauses immediately before us. I understand Senator Chamarette is moving another amendment which was circulated some short time ago, following the defeat of her previous attempt to get some action going in this particular area. I think we ought to see what she has to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make some preliminary remarks in relation to the right to negotiate. During the hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, there was a good deal of comment about the delay that would be occasioned by these clauses. They appear under the heading of `Right to Negotiate'. Under clause 25 we are dealing with certain permissible future acts, such as a mining development. If a state government is to acquire land for a mining venture, then to make it available there are state processes which have to be gone through, such as the wardens court, environmental statements, et cetera—
—Sit down if he's having a chat with his mates; it's just rude.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—The minister is seeking advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am making some preliminary remarks and then I will be asking the minister some questions. It is only after the state processes have been gone through that a state government can form an intention to acquire. That is what then triggers this notification process, whereby notice has to be given and two months has to elapse to see whether anyone objects. After that, there is a period for mediation; it is four months if it is a prospecting and exploration licence and six months if it is a mining lease or acquisition. That then makes this process blow out to six to eight months. After that, if there is no resolution to that mediation, it then goes for determination.

PARA.TAB: There is then a period of four months again within which a decision is to be made for prospecting and exploration licences and six months for mining leases and acquisitions. After that, if the act is disapproved, then the minister still has a discretion because an appeal, more or less, can be made to the minister who can then overturn the decision. So there is another hurdle, so to speak. The decision is to be made within two months after the determination. All of that, at the worst case scenario, is a process of some 16 months, and I have not allowed in that for a party which says that it is entitled to be involved in all this and there is a dispute resolution under clauses 60 and 61, if I recall correctly, in relation to parties.

The delay with this process was complained about by the mining industry because in that time the international market could go sour and the venture might then be called off or financiers might say, `Look, this is just too long; it's too strung out' and the project just would not go ahead. Alternatively, a developer which is not BHP or a multinational could just say, `Look, I can't afford all this. It's costing me hundreds of thousands of dollars in lawyers' fees and this process is just too long'. So that then is a distinct disadvantage to development.

With those preliminary remarks, let me ask the minister in relation specifically to clause 25(2)(b) as to what is called extending the area to which it relates. My question to the minister is this: there may be a situation where there is a mine which has a licence or lease after the tribunal has approved it—this is after the whole process has been gone through—which then fails to comply with the terms of the tenement or lease, that is, it does not mine it and it fails for some reason. Miner B may come along and say to the state government, `Look, we will take over that mine because the first lot has failed, and we think it should be forfeited'. In that case would that action be caught by 25(2)(b), the variation of a right or the extension of an area, in any way? Would the second venture have to go through the process again that the first venture went through? Would it have to go back again to the tribunal, back through that process, back to negotiate? If anybody objected, would it give the native titleholder a second bite at the apple?

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first point about the duration of the process, I do not disagree with the analysis Senator Ellison made except in one respect: the total is two months less than the 16 months that he mentioned because the original period of four months has the two-month notice period subsumed in it. It is not two months on top of that, I am advised. Still, 14 months is a significant time frame—about as long as this committee stage debate seems like going on present indications, and maybe in that context it is not too bad. As to the last question Senator Ellison asked, I am sorry, I am just getting some advice on that.
—Perhaps I could run through it again for the minister's benefit. That was a situation where the process is gone through, mine A is approved—

—I can answer it now. Tell me if I have not answered the whole of your question, but my understanding is that if the variation involves an extension of the area it is true, a person would have to go through another right to negotiate. If it involves a different person on the miner's side, if it involves a variation in the mining interest, the legal personality involved in the mining side, the answer is no, the person would not have to start again or repeat any of these processes, apparently. That can be quite important in the context of joint venture arrangements and so on changing, which is I guess the main reason why one would not want to have a further protraction of these proceedings following on variations of that kind. If we are talking about varying an area, the geographical bite of the claim in question, clearly that opens up new issues and the clock does start running again to that extent.

—Flowing from that I have just one last question, if I may. When the minister says that if the area is extended, albeit by a small amount, that that reopens things, does that take us back to square one or do we only talk about the increased area? For instance, some mining tenements will have a prospecting licence in the middle, and they might then want to mine that area as well. When the minister says it is reopened, is it reopened as to the whole of the area or just as to the increased area?
—The latter would certainly be the case just as to the area of the increase.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the committee debating the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) concerning proceedings on the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I intervene with this matter because the debate that flows from what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has said is totally relevant. We just witnessed an ignorant Prime Minister attacking not only the coalition but also the processes of the Senate itself. This Prime Minister fails to understand the functioning of a house of review. In fact, we know from his previous statements that if he had his way we would be abolished but, if he could not get away with an abolition, then we would simply be treated as a rubber stamp.

PARA.TAB: We have just heard from the Prime Minister that a filibuster has been occurring in this place for almost a full day. Yet he is obviously not communicating with his minister here. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) acknowledged this morning that there has not been a filibuster; that there has been a proper conduct of a difficult and complex debate which is raising serious social issues and legal issues in the way in which this Senate is structured to conduct such debates. When the chamber has before it over 200 amendments in a debate as complex as this, they do take time.

We could abandon our responsibilities as a house of review and do what the Prime Minister wants and simply rubber-stamp this bill through, but we are not prepared to do so. Perhaps that is a good thing because the Prime Minister—Senator Gareth Evans ought to hear this—says that he is prepared to debate this bill as long as is necessary. He said that the Senate will get up on Christmas Eve and come back on Boxing Day. Well, so be it.

However, we understand that Senator Gareth Evans is in the process of negotiating a guillotine with the Greens and the Australian Democrats. That would not surprise us because, whenever we have had a serious debate that has taken some time in this place, in the end the Greens and the Democrats—no matter what they have said in the past—have said, `We'll agree to cut short the debate. We want to go home. We'll guillotine it. We are not interested in the very serious issues'. And so they have brought the debate to a conclusion.

It was also interesting to hear the Prime Minister's attitude towards the state Premiers. He regarded the views of the Premiers, as they were put this afternoon—that this bill should be withdrawn and that it should be taken to the next COAG meeting for serious debate between the states and the Commonwealth—as irrelevant to the total process. The Prime Minister has bagged the state Premiers; he has bagged AMIC; and he is now bagging the NFF. He bags anyone or any group that does not hold his particular view.

I guess that gets to the core of this whole problem. What the Prime Minister is doing at the moment is encouraging division in this country. He is encouraging confrontation and, albeit whether deliberately or not, the Greens and the Democrats are unfortunately part of that process. What we have put on this side of the chamber is that this is such a complex, difficult issue—an issue that can cause such social dislocation in the community—that the Prime Minister ought to be going out of his way to draw together interested parties; that is, the states, the Commonwealth, industry and the Aboriginal community. He should draw them all together, take time and use whatever proper processes are necessary—whether that be through a royal commission, a Senate select committee or whatever—to seek to build a cooperative attitude to the matter and to try to build a consensus.

But that, of course, is not the attitude of the Prime Minister. He has said, `I've looked at this matter. In fact, I've been dealing with it for a year. It requires no more consensus than what my view is'. As a matter of interest, the Prime Minister also said that the bill is totally clear and that there are no issues requiring further clarification because he has been looking at it for a year.

The interesting thing is that when the Prime Minister was asked some specific questions at the end of the press conference in relation to the bill he could not answer any of them. He became embarrassed, attacked the coalition again, attacked the Senate again and then walked out of the press conference. He could not answer a simple question on the bill. He had to walk out of the press conference rather than face up to that responsibility.

The Prime Minister does not know what is happening in this chamber. He does not understand this chamber's responsibility. All he is doing is seeking to distort the process and, unfortunately, building division and disunity within the community. That is appalling. Instead of calling press conferences in the middle of this debate to attack us and the Senate, what he ought to be doing is getting out there and talking to the state Premiers, asking how we can use this meeting in February to try to not only overcome the farce that he has caused but also find a formula within which Australia can be drawn together on this complex matter. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —If ever we needed any proof that what we were having here is a deliberate attempt to waste time so that this legislation will not be dealt with, this attempt to suspend standing orders is that proof. Sitting outside watching the press conference, we said, `Senator Hill will come in and move a motion for the suspension of standing orders to debate this'—and, as we looked through the window, in he walked. We knew that that was the next excuse.
—Because that's the normal reaction to that sort of statement.
—No, it has never happened before.

SPEECH.PARA: That was the next excuse—to come in and say, `Let's seek to divert the debate away from the terrible prospect that we might have to have a vote on a clause'. This morning we came in on clause 24, 25; now at 5 o'clock tonight we are still on the same body, the same group of clauses, we started on. That is absolute proof of a significant—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is because they are so rotten.

—Aha! That is because those opposite are so fundamentally opposed to it. I do not object to them being fundamentally opposed to it. There has not been a new piece of information, a new bit of detail, in any of the questions since 11 o'clock this morning. What did the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) actually say? He did not make a very scathing attack—

—Madam Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I have a problem in understanding why the minister who is in charge of this bill is not able to stand and speak to this motion. Why has he had to send out for reinforcements, for a minister who has not taken part in the debate at all?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—Order! Senator Bishop, there is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is just another attempt by Senator Bishop to be rude and offensive; she has failed, although she is usually very good at it.

PARA.TAB: What did the Prime Minister on this occasion say was going on here? What was the scurrilous attack he made? He said there was a filibuster; quite clearly, there is. It is a legitimate, democratic right to have a filibuster, and we are having one. The Prime Minister has said that those opposite are running a tag team; and it is quite obvious that they are, even though they are not organised enough to run a wrestling match. We have been here for six hours, nearly seven, without any progress at all. The Prime Minister has said, `If we need to, we will stay here until Christmas Eve and come back on Boxing Day'. That is a clear declaration of the government's intent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was the minister lying this morning when he said it wasn't a filibuster? Which one of you is lying—Senator Evans or you?

—Madam Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. Once is too much, according to the standing orders; twice is a bit much, but it has been four times now. Senator Campbell knows perfectly well that it is totally disorderly to use that word in respect of a senator or a member of the other place, and I ask him to withdraw it.
—Senator Campbell, would you like to withdraw your words please and refrain from interjecting.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, on the point of order, if we are to deal with comments which are made on the aside, which people might find offensive, perhaps we might also deal with the one you made before the luncheon adjournment. Could I seek your guidance on whether we could deal with that immediately following this point?

—On the point of order, Senator Bishop knows that is not a point of order. I would draw your attention to standing order 190 which says that to continually and wilfully disrupt the parliament is disorderly. Senator Bishop is quite clearly doing that.
—It was a personal explanation, you dork!
—Order! Everybody, please!

—Thank you, Madam Temporary Chair. I do not mind what these people say in interjections; it is of no consequence whatsoever. At the core of this, the shock and horror, is that the Prime Minister has put a bit of pressure on to say that what we should do in this Senate is vote on some of the clauses. Shock! What a terrible attack upon the Senate: it might have to vote on this bill that is before it.
—But your minister doesn't know what the clauses do.

—Then vote against it. Senator Campbell should just stop frothing at the mouth and calm down and vote against it, if he does not like it. All we are asking is: why is it unreasonable to require the Senate to vote on a bit of legislation? If Senator Campbell does not like it, he has a democratic right to vote against it. What is the shock and horror with saying, `Why can't the Senate vote?'? What is the shock and horror with saying that, if it does not seek to exercise that right, we will stay here until it does? That is our intention; it is a clear declaration of intent—just as this motion for the suspension of standing orders is a clear declaration of intent that those opposite will seek to keep wasting time. (Time expired)

—I hope that Senator McMullan actually saw his leader in action. I gather from that contribution that he clearly did not, because what he would have seen was not just a Senate hater that we have all grown to hate—
—He did not attack the Senate once.

—Yes, he did. Let us get it clear what he did hate. He hated the headlines this morning, in particular. He hated the farmers saying that they would dump Mabo. He hated the fact that the NFF has got off the cart. He particularly hated the fact that Wayne Goss has dumped all over him and he was disingenuous enough, to express it politely, to pretend that somehow he did not know what Premier Goss had said. He said, `I did not hear AM'. I think any of us who have been around this place for five minutes would have known what Mr Goss had said, would have read the transcript carefully and would have known in absolute detail that Mr Goss was kicking him where he hurts. But he had the gall to come along and pretend that he did not hear Mr Goss and, therefore, we could ignore that.

PARA.TAB: Clearly he is trying to face the Senate down. That press conference was called because he was wounded by the fact that he did not get his own way, that in fact it has turned around and bitten him, that he has the bad headlines, and that he is the one on the defensive. In fact, he authorised his spokesman to tell the Australian that the government will decide its next move today. I suppose we did not have to be too smart to work out what his next move was going to be—blame the opposition. That is always his next move. That whole press conference was an exercise in pretending that somehow it was not his fault.

We have only to look at what former Labor staffer Rick Farley has to explain to his own constituents. The fact is that Mr Farley thought two weeks ago that this was a good bill. So did Mr Keating, presumably. But, no, at the last minute we have had a series of what are now said to be fundamental amendments. What does the Prime Minister say when it is put to him that everyone in the countryside is confused—just remember that his most fervent supporter, Mr Farley, is now saying that this bill adds to confusion and uncertainty about land title and rights—

TALK.START.PARA: —It says more of the same.

—In fact, Mr Farley claimed that the NFF had been betrayed by the government; that the government had breached a commitment given by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and senior ministers that landowners' existing rights would be protected. Lord knows how Mr Farley was able to get that sort of commitment out of the government because it required the support of the Democrats—and I think anyone who has been around the place for even a short while knows the Democrats never had the slightest intention of supporting that. So, presumably, Mr Farley was simply led on by the bloke that we would not buy a used rat from.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the Prime Minister was obviously trying to let Mr Farley think if he stayed on the cart for long enough, somehow it would work out his way. The Senate has made it clear where it stands, as it has a democratic right to do. Mr Farley, in turn, has dumped on the Prime Minister and the Prime Minister is now trying to dump on everyone else. And to suggest, as he did—
Senator Campbell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he said this with a straight face too. He said there was nothing confusing about the legislation because he had spent about a year putting it together. If he had spent a year putting it together, we would not need one amendment.

PARA.TAB: Senator Burns interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If he had been listening to the advice that Senator Burns has been giving him and he had got it right, we would not have needed one amendment. Yet what have we had? We have seen 75 amendments plus all these others from minor parties. It is a complete and utter shambles. Now we are told that the government is not even going to go back and introduce these watered down versions in the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: So this is simply another bluff on the part of the Prime Minister to somehow try to intimidate the Senate. The Senate is not going to be intimidated. I do not think the press will be intimidated either. They know who is at fault. It is not just the usual suspects who are saying that this legislation is fatally flawed; it is people such as Mr Goss. Unless the Prime Minister faces up to that, he will get what he deserves.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—I call Senator Collins.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first time you've spoken in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard that interjection from Senator Tambling. He said this was the first time I have spoken in the debate. It is true. The reason is that I thought the need to get some simple justice at long last for Aboriginal people in this country, the need to provide the absolute certainty of title which this government has committed itself to doing and to give certainty to that title, whether it is freehold or leasehold, was so important that my major and considered contribution to this debate was to say nothing and thereby shorten the time between the start of this debate and the promulgation of this bill into law by 20 minutes. That was a significant contribution in my view to try to get this into law.

PARA.TAB: I do not think it could be said any better than it was said today by the editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: But instead of a sense of historical moment, debate on the bill in the Senate has elicited mean-spirited opportunism and truculent inflexibility.

That has all been demonstrated here over the last couple of days. Senator Alston has a hide six inches thick; it is his one big asset. How could anybody with a straight face stand up and say that there has been no filibuster on this when we have been debating this bill since 10 o'clock this morning with no interposition of question time or any of the other diversions? It is now 5 o'clock in the afternoon and we have dealt with one clause of the bill. A piece of nonsense was thrown in about the problems of pastoral leases in Queensland and what happens when they expire.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your Prime Minister couldn't answer the question.

—The question is an irrelevancy. Queensland pastoral titles do not contain reservations like the reservations in the Northern Territory or Western Australian pastoral titles. If those titles are valid, they extinguish native title. That is something that the coalition has been trying to distort ever since the start of this debate. It is an absolute nonsense. How can anyone with a straight face, when we have spent five hours dealing with government legislation—
—What do your notes say?
—I will tell Senator Macdonald what my note says.
—Do they say, `Didn't I gag you'?

—No. My note is a letter to the editor that was written to the Sydney Morning Herald in 1892. It just shows that some people in this chamber have not moved one inch since then. I will tell honourable senators what my note says. That is why I am angry in this debate and that is why I have finally spoken.
—Please read this letter.

—I will read it; I will respond to Senator Macdonald's invitation. Many honourable senators would know and most Catholics would know about Mother Mary Mackillop, but few know that she had a brother equally distinguished. He wrote the following letter to the Sydney Morning Herald in 1892:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia, as such, does not recognise the right of the black man to live. She marches onward, truly, but not perhaps the fair maiden we paint her. The blackfellow sees blood on that noble forehead, callous cruelty in her heart; her heel is of iron and his helpless countrymen beneath her feet. But we are strong and the blacks are weak; we have rifles, they but spears; we love British fairplay, and having got hold of this continent we must have every square foot. Little Tasmania is our model, and I fear, will be, until the great papers of Australia will chronicle, `with regret', the death of the last blackfellow. There is a feeling abroad too, which might be worded thus—it is in God's providence that the native races here, as elsewhere, must disappear before the British people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order.
—Senator Macdonald asked for this to be read out.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, on a point of order. I thought we were debating a matter relating to Mr Keating's press conference. Senator Collins has been effectively gagged by the Prime Minister. Obviously someone gave him a bit of paper and said, `Please read this out so you will not put your foot in it yet again'. It really has nothing to do with the debate and, on the grounds of relevancy, I ask you, Mr Temporary Chairman, to call the minister to order. If he wants to take part in this debate, he should in fact debate the issue before the chair.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—Senator Collins's time has expired anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what it was all about—just another filibuster to waste time in the chamber. (Time expired)

—It is unique, certainly in my memory, for there to be a motion to suspend standing orders for the purposes of considering a Prime Minister's statement in the middle of a committee of the whole debate on a bill. I believe that we should proceed, take little notice of what the Prime Minister has said and just continue on with the examination of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few comments on the motion before us and about what the Prime Minister said. What we saw today was a fumbling, bumbling, mortally wounded Prime Minister. He was mortally wounded because he believed that he had stitched up a deal and suddenly found that all the troops were walking away and that he was left on his own. During the whole of that press conference, he could not answer one question of substance.
—But it's simple legislation!

—That is dead right. I do want to pick up a few points because the Prime Minister talked about filibustering. I would suggest that he have a chat to Senator Gareth Evans or read the Hansard. Senator Evans made it absolutely clear this morning that there was no filibustering but that, in fact, good technical questions were being asked. The problem is that Senator Evans has not been able to answer many of those questions. He has tried, there is no question about that, but he has not been able to answer them. That is why we have had consideration of a number of amendments deferred.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins gets up and does his lolly, as usual, tries to bounce around in a fancy sort of way and says that one clause has been passed. In actual fact, from very early in the morning we have been debating clauses 25 to 39. We are debating 14 clauses at once. If the government wants to go through the clauses one by one, I am certain the debate will take much longer.

It is interesting that the Prime Minister did not have a clue what Premier Goss had said. I find it absolutely incredible, in fact unsustainable, that he can have a copy of the press release put out by the Liberal premiers and Dr Hewson only half an hour or so ago, and yet did not know about the statements by Premier Goss on AM this morning. Can anybody honestly tell me that the people who look after his media are so incompetent that they would not have brought the Premier's comments to his attention? The answer to that is, of course, no. Honourable senators can draw their own conclusions from that.
The Prime Minister said that Mr Goss's name was not on the press release. Let us look at what Mr Goss said this morning because I think this goes to the nub of the issue. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well we're certainly very worried. I've got officers urgently trying this morning to find out what the hell is going on in Canberra. We're concerned that an already difficult and complex piece of legislation . . .
Do those opposite remember their reference to simplicity? Do they remember what the Prime Minister said at the press conference? Later on in the interview Premier Goss said:
Well John we understand there is hundreds of amendments or hundreds of pages of amendments being introduced into the Senate.

By whom? The government is the leading culprit, then there are amendments by the Greens and the Democrats. I am not sure in which order they come. It is absolutely and totally dishonest of our Prime Minister to stand up and say at that press conference that we have had this bill for 12 months, that we have this Mabo paper and that we have the discussion papers.

PARA.TAB: The amendments are changing second by second. As I said yesterday, one minute it is 9, next minute it is 9A; one minute it is 6, next minute it is 6A. This morning Senator Gareth Evans did not even know that there was a difference between 33B and 33A. He said that they were the same. That is how confused he is. In terms of this debate, it is time that the Prime Minister woke up to himself.

But the biggest issue of all in terms of what is going on in this place relates to the statements that we will stay here till Christmas Day, we will come back on Boxing Day, this will go on indefinitely, when we know darn well that there is a deal being done right now to limit debate on this bill. It will be interesting to see what Senator Gareth Evans does now. Will he go against his Prime Minister, or will he run this chamber as the Leader of the Government in the Senate? It will be very interesting to see what he does. He has just been put down, in terms of the management of this chamber, by his Prime Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This really is a most miserable and unreasonable motion by the opposition. The opposition has put a proposition, not seriously, to suspend the standing orders of the Senate to talk about the press conference of the Prime Minister. Whom do honourable senators opposite think they are kidding? Whom do they think they are fooling? They are trying to suspend the standing orders in this chamber that has dealt with the Native Title Bill for the last 36 hours and 40 minutes. So that everyone is absolutely clear, the second reading debate on this legislation went for 10 hours and 10 minutes; the committee stage of this legislation has gone on for 26 hours and 30 minutes. What a miserable and hypocritical move from those opposite. I tell them: it will backfire on them because all Australians know that those opposite are the filibusterers.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I rise on a point of order. That is a joint accusation—that people on this side and particularly the people that moved that motion—
—Exactly.
—I do not need your help, thank you.
—I'm telling you it is a joint accusation. It is accurate, too.
—I do not care what you tell me. I do not give a rat's toenail what you think. It was a joint accusation that the people moving this motion are hypocritical. We have had it plainly established—
—You are hypocritical.

—Here it comes again. Mr Temporary Chairman, we have had it plainly established before that where a group accusation is made—and it is against honourable senators, and they are offended—it has to be withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—I believe that the minister was referring to the opposition as hypocritical. If that is the case, I ask him to withdraw it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, if you have asked me to withdraw it, I will withdraw it. I have heard any number of other senators say that. But let me say this: this attempt to waste time, to filibuster and to subvert the processes of the chamber will backfire on honourable senators opposite because they are being exposed in the public arena for precisely what they are. It is they, and they alone, who are responsible for this contempt—and every Australian knows it.

PARA.TAB: We have reached the absolute nadir in this debate when they want to suspend standing orders for a discussion on what the Prime Minister has said at a press conference. They should have the guts to defend their own positions publicly. Why do they not have their own press conference? They should have their own press conference if they have something to say. They should have the guts to put up their own arguments in public. What a miserable attempt from those opposite to—

TALK.START.PARA: —You obviously didn't see the slimy effort.

—Senator Alston should not talk about sliminess. Senator Alston is the most unctuous and unreasonable person in this chamber, so he should not talk about being slimy. He has a postgraduate degree in sliminess. Let us be clear that the opposition stands exposed by the people of Australia for this move. If those opposite have the guts, they should get outside the chamber and argue in a formal press conference, if they like, about what they believe ought to happen but they should not abuse yet again the processes of this chamber with this despicable and contemptible time-wasting exercise. Opposition senators stand condemned not only by the government, independent senators and other senators; they stand condemned by all Australians for the depth they have plumbed in this absolutely absurd suspension of standing orders motion. (Time expired)
—Order! The time for the debate on the motion has expired. I put the question that Senator Hill's motion for suspension of standing orders be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the negative.
Clauses 25 to 39.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we debate these highly complicated clauses in the bill, it is very important that we stress the point that the reason we in the opposition are taking the time to explore and develop the arguments concerning every clause is that the legislation is so bad that people have to understand the uncertainty that is there. When the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his press conference was asked a specific question about how that legislation will affect leaseholders in Queensland, he gave the wrong answer. He does not understand his own legislation. Nor does Senator Gareth Evans understand it. That is exactly why questions concerning leases have to be raised at every point.

PARA.TAB: When we look at the amendments, their complexity and the way in which the operation of various clauses is unknown, the question that still remains unanswered is whether the government has done a deal with the Australian Democrats concerning the application of the Racial Discrimination Act and whether there is to be any subsequent amendment to make this act subject to the Racial Discrimination Act. I ask the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Bolkus, who is on duty, whether any deal has been struck to introduce an amendment at any time during this debate to make the legislation subject to the Racial Discrimination Act.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Had Senator Bishop been here at the appropriate time in the discussion, she would have been on top of the fact that the Greens moved an amendment earlier with respect to the RDA and that amendment was deferred. When that amendment comes back on is very much up to the processes of the parliament. In terms of any deal, my understanding is that the reason this amendment was deferred is that there was no agreement on it.

—I asked a very specific question. Unlike Senator Bolkus, I am fully aware of what has gone on beforehand. I asked: has any deal been done so that any amendment moved by the government, the Greens or the Democrats will be supported or introduced by the government to make this piece of legislation subject to the Racial Discrimination Act? Yes or no?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not really do much for the temperament of this place to become personally insulting, and I will not respond in kind. The discussion has gone on to great effect without that level of debate. It really does this place and its reputation no good for someone to throw those sorts of personal insults at this side of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: When this amendment was deferred, an indication was given that the government was supporting it. Had Senator Bishop been here at that time in the discussion, she would have been on top of that particular fact. However, when going through such a long process like this, honourable senators are not here for all of it, and I can understand Senator Bishop not being here for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't been.
—I have not been out eating sausages in Mackellar, for instance. I have been in my room, pretty close to this particular debate and have been kept informed of it.
—You have not been here for the debate.

—Senator Bishop may not know what I get up to, day in, night out or whatever. Although she probably does not want to know what I have been getting up to, I am sure her colleagues would like to know what she has been getting up to. However, I have been keeping a very close eye on this debate.

PARA.TAB: Time and time today the point has been raised that we really are going through old ground continuously and exhaustively. There is no doubt, to the rest of the outside world looking at this debate, that we are just doing it for no other reason but for obstinacy on the other side.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, on a point of order: Senator Bolkus is now filibustering by wasting time waiting for Senator Evans to come back.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—Senator Campbell, do you have a point of order?

TALK.START.PARA: —If he cannot answer the question, he should just sit down and we will ask the next question.
—That is not a point of order.

—Unlike Senator Bolkus, I have been here for the debate. Senator Bolkus is clearly not on top of it. I asked the question because if an amendment is passed and the act becomes subject to the Racial Discrimination Act, whole sections of the act will fail.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, on a point of order: on this particular point we are not dealing with specific clauses to the legislation; we are dealing with clauses 25 to 39. When dealing with the Racial Discrimination Act and the particular amendment that Senator Bishop raised, we are talking about amendments after clause 6. My understanding of the committee process in this place is that it deals with clauses seriatim.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, on a point of order—

—I am on a point of order, Senator. Sit down until I have finished my point of order. My understanding is that, at this particular time, we should not deal with the substance of the Greens' amendment, which would come in after clause 6. We are dealing with other clauses of the legislation. Pre-empting one of the points that could be raised on this point of order—
—What is your point of order?
—Order! I believe the minister is just coming to his point of order.

—On any piece of legislation one could argue that one part of a bill is related to another part. The procedures and processes in this place have been such that we deal with clause by clause and we do not bring in clauses from other parts of a piece of legislation and deal with them whenever we feel like it. So I am asking you, Mr Temporary Chairman, to rule that any question related to—
—For heaven's sake! Sit him down. What is the point of order?
—Just give us a go. You have had 48 hours on this.
—What is the point of order?
—My point of order is—
—He has been going for three minutes on a point of order. What is your point of order? What is your standing order?
—With all due respect, the minister might be able to make his point of order if there were fewer interjections from my left.
—My point is that any reference to Greens amendment 1(a) is not relevant to the clauses currently before the chamber. Unless we stick to some sort of process, we could be here until next Christmas.

—On the point of order: just to help the poor minister, who does not understand the debate at all, clause 36, which is part of the package of clauses that we are dealing with, is precisely one of those clauses that will fail if the government agrees to anybody's amendment or brings forth an amendment itself saying that the act is to be subject to the Racial Discrimination Act. My question is directly and specifically related to the package of clauses that we are discussing at this moment. As Senator Bolkus has not been part of this debate and is not on top of the bill, I can understand that he does not know that. Perhaps that explanation will help you to say that he has no point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to speak for very long on this occasion, but I do want to pick up a couple of points that have been made in the debate up until now on this group of clauses and make reference to some points that were made in the suspension motion. The first point I want to raise with respect to the debate on the suspension motion is that concerning honourable senators on the other side saying that we should not engage in any delays and that a debate on the clauses which we are now in the middle of is a delay and a filibuster. That is the aspect that I want to raise because the integrity of people who want to raise detailed points, as I and other senators have, has been questioned by the remarks of, for example, Senator Collins, Senator Bolkus, et al. I take the opportunity whenever that accusation is made to reinforce the point. This group of clauses is of no lesser value than any other group of clauses in the bill. They all need to be put right.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins raised today's Sydney Morning Herald editorial, and he correctly quoted—I do not know whether he did it appropriately or otherwise—part of the editorial. To repeat his point, it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: But instead of a sense of historical moment, debate on the bill in the Senate has elicited mean-spirited opportunism and truculent inflexibility.

Senator Collins, who perhaps has been in his office and has not been listening, endorses those remarks automatically. What I say in the spirit of Christmas is, `Hark, the Herald is wrong again'. It has been wrong plenty of times and it is wrong again. We all know that people on this side of the chamber have a different view as to how to respond to Mabo No. 2. Everyone understands that. I do not think there is any animosity or aggro about it. We just have a different view. There are plenty of people on all sides—this side and that side—who believe that whatever the bill that is going through, it should be in the best form possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ah.

—Senator Collins says, `Ah'. Coming from the honourable senator whose first contribution was to come in here today and simply lambaste people on this side, it is not really worth pursuing his point. I will stick to the point I was making: it does not matter what one's view is as to whether this is the appropriate response to Mabo No. 2 or not. This bill, I presume, will be passed. These people here have decided it will be passed and, in that sense, our job is not done until we have it in the best form possible. That happens not just by moving amendments—some people think the only way to achieve improvements in this place is to move an amendment here or there—but sometimes by drawing attention to problems that all parties might want to fix. They may be problems that the government wants to fix—I am sure there are some constitutional problems it will need to fix—otherwise it will lose the whole lot.

PARA.TAB: I look forward to seeing the editorial of the Sydney Morning Herald if and when this bill is passed and if and when it is challenged to see what it has to say about the value put on the historical moment of pushing a bill through without giving it appropriate consideration. The fact that I happen to have a different view about how Mabo No. 2 should be responded to by the Commonwealth does not disentitle me to participate in this debate. It does not mean that I come to the debate in bad faith, and it does not necessarily mean that of any of my colleagues either. The more people on the other side want to raise the temperature of this debate, the less sensible the debate that we will have. I am sure that if Senator Collins really was listening—he told us that he was—he would have heard Senator Evans indicate on very numerous occasions—
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—Order! I think the chair has been rather tolerant. It is about time we returned to the question before the chair which is that clauses 25 to 39 be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I am seeking no further latitude from you than you gave to the minister who wanted to make a point of order, which was not a point of order, and you knew it from the very beginning. You gave him three minutes to make a point of order.
—I think I have given you sufficient time.
—That was another debate. You can't return to that debate in this debate.

—I thank the minster; he is so helpful. That is the first point I want to make: half of the Sydney Morning Herald is wrong again. This side of the chamber is as entitled and obligated as it ever was to raise all the detail it would like on this bill. Heaven knows we need to. As I understand, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), when asked a question relating to the detail of this bill—a bill that he knows so well and was wrapped up in for 12 months—had to walk out.

—I think you are straying from the subject. We have already had a debate on what the Prime Minister said. I really believe that you should return to the matter before the chair which is that clauses 25 to 39 be agreed to.
—That is right. I am speaking to the need to get those clauses right. I am not addressing any specific clause, but saying that these clauses—
—That's true. That's absolutely true.
—I said in the very beginning that I was going to get my chance. I freely admit that. I am not addressing any particular clause.
—You're not filibustering, are you?

—No, I am not. Mr Temporary Chairman, interjections invite a response. I am not trying to filibuster at all but will not put up with the load of muck that spews out of the ocean of factional vomit that I have to look at without responding to it. If Senator Evans wants to attribute bad faith to me, I am entitled to respond. I now consider that I have done so. Every time Senator Evans interjects, I will get up and do the same and it will take more time. Would it not be better if we just concentrated on the detail? Up until now in this debate, that is what I have tried to do. If those opposite want to come in here chucking muck about, a bit can be chucked back.

—My question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) concerns the proposed goldfields gas pipeline which is being proposed in Western Australia. This is to be a private pipeline, not a public work, and will involve Western Mining Corporation, Normandy Poseidon and BHP. It will be a project of great dimension. It will traverse hundreds of kilometres and most of it will be crown land. Does the minister think that that will be a permissible act? If so, why does he think it will be a permissible act? How would it fare if this bill were made law?

—If there is any contemplation that there might be native titleholders with rights in the area in question, they will have to be treated in the same way as freeholders would be in the area in question. The other option is compulsory acquisition of the interest necessary to enable the pipeline to be built. One way of identifying who the native titleholders are, in circumstances where, presumably, that is uncertain, would be through the non-claimant application procedure in clause 23, which we have discussed previously. There is a provision for the particular proposal to be announced. If that does not produce a response within a two-month period, one can go ahead and do the act validly, and so on. All the rest of that falls into place as we have discussed it previously, but that is the way it would work.

—Taking the position that the pipeline can be built on pastoral leases, the government can grant easements. What happens where a pastoral lease coexists with native title? Remembering that Western Australia has these reservations, and that the reservations allow Aboriginal access to the land concerned, how does the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) see that being sorted out?

—To the extent that the pastoral lease applies in the non-reservation part, probably the native title interest has been extinguished, although there is still an element of residual uncertainty about that. Otherwise, if there is a pastoral lease in respect of which one wants to run a new pipeline across—that is what Senator Ellison is saying—an area which is not overlapping with an area of obvious statutory reservation and obvious reservation of native title rights, I guess that it would be a matter of just proceeding to act in the normal way under state legislation with easements and so on, presumably on the working assumption that the pastoral lease had extinguished the native title. I suppose that would be a reasonable assumption on which to begin.

PARA.TAB: That kind of case might generate a test case as to whether native title is extinguished by pastoral leases. It is a reasonable assumption that any state could proceed across a pastoral lease on that basis.

If one were seeking to do something in an area that is already the subject of a statutory reservation for Aboriginal use and where, accordingly, there is some presumption of a continuity of native title rights—in other words, a potential coexistence situation—and if one were dealing with the native titleholders in relation to that part of the pastoral lease that is subject to that reservation, the same principles that I mentioned earlier would apply. One could only do in respect of those native titleholders what could be done with a freehold title. If one did not want to be subject to that restriction, one could then move down the path of a compulsory acquisition.

As always in these matters, one could deal with it by agreement. We tend to overlook the extent to which most of these issues are perfectly capable of being resolved by agreement, perhaps with some compensatory arrangement built into that agreement, thus avoiding the necessity to go down any of these more complicated routes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Buy them out.

—This is all a consequence of the land no longer being terra nullius.
