Once the land is stocked, which has previously been anticipated to be empty except for freeholders and others who have been granted leases and other interests from the crown; once that mental assumption is changed and we work on the basis that common law rights are still capable of being exercised, all these consequences quite logically follow from that.

—Is not the problem really that, in order for such a pipeline to be constructed, one would have to compulsorily acquire the land so as to extinguish the native title? One would clear that up. In that pastoral situation, the only certainty one would get would be to compulsorily acquire the land. One could not simply grant an easement because it would not apply to native title.

PARA.TAB: Another question is that the government equates native title with freehold, because it states that everything has to be done which would be done to a freehold owner. Does the minister agree that one cannot grant easements over native title? Part of the difficulty is that one is forced to compulsorily acquire.

TALK.START.PARA: —One only really needs compulsory acquisition to the extent of the strip of land required for the easement; it is not a matter of compulsorily acquiring a whole property. It varies a bit from jurisdiction to jurisdiction. But when one is granting easements for the purposes of pipelines, electric transmission lines, local government access or whatever, my understanding is that that is usually accomplished by way of agreement or, if agreement cannot be reached, compulsory acquisition.

PARA.TAB: Exactly the same principles apply here. There is no prima facie reason for assuming that, simply because land is native title held, no result is possible. A result is possible, but it has to be achieved by way of either agreement or the compulsory acquisition of the degree of interest that one needs in order to accomplish the policy objective.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can an agreement be reached before a determination is made? In other words, if a claimant comes along and says, `I will agree with the mining company or the people building the pipeline', what title can the claimant give the mining company? I suppose that takes us to the point that if a native titleholder can give a valid title to a pipeline company, can the company use that title in any way as a security? If there is an agreement situation and the claimant offers to forgo native title, how can a claimant do that without a determination being made? Even if the claimant could do that, could the pipeline company use that title as a security for a financier? In the normal course of events it is a different story because one would actually be dealing with recognised title such as freehold and so on.

—I suppose that is a fair question in the sense that if one is entering into an agreement one would want that to be enforceable and one would want the conferring of title flowing from it to be utilised in the way that has been suggested. To achieve the necessary degree of certainty one would wish to wait until the determination has been made and the body corporate has been established to be the vehicle through which some of these things are done. As a practical matter, I guess that is right. Technically, native title rights do exist and are able to be exercised before they are actually deemed to exist by the tribunal. The tribunal process is a matter of recognition rather than the creation of the right in question.

PARA.TAB: I suppose that if there were a high degree of confidence of all concerned that this was unequivocally a case of legitimate native title rights being held, if one wanted to get on with the business of doing something as a matter of urgency and one were prepared to enter into an agreement with the people concerned, and if there were a formalising of that agreement to everybody's satisfactory, there is no inhibition posed by this legislation on such an agreement proceeding with the claimant. I think that addresses the matter.

In the absence of agreement, I am advised that there would be no technical inhibition either in proceeding by way of compulsory acquisition against a complainant. It is a rather odd situation and I suppose no state would want to find itself in the position of shelling out funds on a compulsory acquisition basis in relation to a claim that is not yet determined unless everyone had a very high degree of confidence that it was simply a matter of formalising the obvious.

I cannot really add much to that. The bottom line is that if there is some project that needs to go ahead and that involved easements and easement equivalents, access rights of one kind or another or property acquisition, there is no particular reason to assume that these things have to be endlessly held up waiting for determination processes to run their course. There are fast track ways of achieving the same result.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that not bring us back to the commercial reality that the only way to go is to compulsorily acquire rather than proceeding by way of these agreements and things of that nature? Because of the nature of it, certainly the only way to go is to extinguish native title?

—I do not think that is a fair comment. There will be many issues capable of resolution by agreement. If there is no pressing time frame problem and it is possible to get the determination of the native title status—this will be clear from the body corporate provisions when we get to them—there will be a formal vehicle through which to act—if not necessarily to formally hold the title—on behalf of the titleholders.

PARA.TAB: Accordingly, there will be a mechanism available to do these various things and, I imagine, a considerable will to do it on a voluntary agreement basis, if that can be done. It is always preferable to do these things by way of agreement, rather than compulsory acquisition, just as is the practice of governments in dealing with citizens generally. We do not go down the formal notification of compulsory acquisition if we can resolve the matter amicably in other ways. I imagine that that would be the case here as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise one matter arising out of that. Assuming that agreements are not intended to extinguish native title and one does reach agreements with a series of claimants, what is then to stop a subsequent claimant coming in and throwing a spanner in the works?

—Clause 23 is the basic provision dealing in the first instance with the register situation. The whole point of requiring applicants to register is in order to establish some kind of priority in terms of whom one deals with. To the extent that one can deal with an applicant, and has dealt with an applicant, and reach an agreement with a particular applicant whose claim is registered, then that would continue to stick, as I understand the legislation, notwithstanding some subsequent applicant coming in and a subsequent course of events leading to some revision as to which claimant has the finally determined native title status. But because of the need to get some degree of certainty, from the point of view of other interests with whom native titleholders are dealing, that is why some status is vested in those who make a formal application and who get their claim registered. It is a non-insignificant status that flows from that and it does enable various things to happen.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the order of the Senate agreed to on 18 December 1993 be varied to provide that—

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the sitting of the Senate be suspended from 6.30 p.m. till 8.00 p.m. this day, and
(b)on Tuesday, 21 December 1993, the sitting of the Senate be suspended from 6.30 p.m. till 8.00 p.m.

I discussed with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Alston) and the opposition whip, the change in the dinner patterns for tonight and tomorrow night from an hour, from 6.00 p.m. to 7.00 p.m., to an hour and a half, from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m. This will enable those honourable senators who would like to leave the environs of Parliament House to do so. Senator Harradine indicated that he was keen for me to ensure, within arrangements amongst whips, that we do not have any divisions between 6.20 p.m. and 6.30 p.m. tonight because he will be inconvenienced at that time. I am sure all honourable senators will be able to ensure that we can accommodate Senator Harradine's wishes. I commend the motion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I had made other arrangements on the basis that the dinner break was going to be between six and seven. Only those ten minutes are crucial.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Consideration resumed.
Clauses 25 to 39.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will add one further gloss to my previous answer.
—You don't mean Goss, do you?

—No. That interjection was not in good taste, Senator Crane. If one is negotiating, that is, for an agreement, or if one is going through a compulsory acquisition process and dealing with claims that have been determined, there is no problem under the legislation because even if a subsequent claimant comes along, that determination can be varied only on the basis of very good evidence—and that provision is set out. I understood, however, the question to be not so much about dealing with people whose claims are determined, but simply with people who have made an application and who are on the claims register.

PARA.TAB: It still is the case that it is not impossible for a government—or whoever—to negotiate with such a claimant, but in the context of a compulsory acquisition normally the notice would be given, the acquisition would be made and the question of who would be entitled to subsequent compensation would need to be resolved—and probably would depend upon a determination being reached. Equally, if one is contemplating an agreement being reached, it is probably the case that one would not sensibly pay out money pursuant to that agreement unless one was satisfied that the person had a higher status than that of merely a registered claimant. It is possible to anticipate a condition being set under those circumstances that the claimant have the determination resolved in his favour before the payment is made.

There is provision along those lines, at least so far as mining is concerned, in clause 50. The compensation in the mining situation is held in trust until the determination is proceeded with. The bill is silent as to other possible situations of this kind, but by implication that is the way it would proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the minister was responding to my question.
—Was it yours? I'm sorry.

—I will pursue it a little further, rather than change to another subject. Is the minister not saying that one would be wise to deal with a registered claimant and, to the extent that one signed an agreement, might want to seek some indemnity in respect of subsequent claims? The fact is that an agreement would not exclude a subsequent claim. As I understand it, there is no time limit on a subsequent claim except in respect of notice given by government. So where there is a private owner or applicant there would not be a time limit, would there?

—No, that is true. But when one is dealing with a particular claimant who has not yet been the subject of a determination, the process for getting a determination does not take endlessly long. It takes some time, as we discussed earlier, but one could proceed to get the determination and just have an indemnity arrangement, perhaps, that was conditional upon the determination being resolved favourably for that claimant. The process of the determination might flush out other claimants, but their competing claims would be resolved in that determination.

PARA.TAB: Once a determination is made and there is a native titleholder in existence, it is only in the most exceptional circumstances—which are spelled out in clause 12(5)—that one could vary the determination. It is only where it can be demonstrated `that events have taken place since the determination was made that have caused the determination no longer to be correct', and so on. I think the fact of the determination is as decisive as any proprietary—

TALK.START.PARA: —But that's not exclusive of others, is it?

—It is in the nature of it. The determination would go to whether there is title, what it extends to and who holds it. If someone else wanted to come in over the top and say, `We are entitled to part of it as well'—that is, some group of relatives from down the track who were not part of the original process but perhaps should have been—that will be a variation situation that can be made only if those conditions are satisfied.

—Let us be clear: the minister is saying there would be a variation. I would have thought that a variation meant to the terms of the original determination; in other words, that the basis on which the decision had been made was inaccurate. Surely, one could have a situation where the circumstances do not change other than that an additional claimant comes along. There is nothing that one would want to vary about the agreement or the determination. The determination is that A is entitled to compensation—full-stop. If a subsequent claimant comes along, the original determination does not need to be varied, unless the minister is saying that the original determination is exclusive—in other words, that no subsequent claims can be brought. Is that what the minister is saying?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No subsequent claims can be brought that will produce any variation unless the following conditions are satisfied—and I read again from clause 12(5):

PARA.TAB: For the purposes of subsection (4)—

SPEECH.PARA: the one in issue—
the grounds for variation or revocation of an approved determination of native title are:

PARA.TAB: (a)that events have taken place since the determination was made that have caused the determination no longer to be correct; or
(b)that the interests of justice require the variation or revocation of the determination.

SPEECH.PARA: There is provision for notification of all possible potential claimants and so on as part of the determination process. It is only in the most exceptional case, one presumes, that it would be possible to find that one or other of these conditions were satisfied. The idea is to get maximum possible certainty, not only in the interests of the non-Aboriginal holders but also on the other side of the ledger. That is a very important part of the whole process.

PARA.TAB: It is not a matter of naming every individual native titleholder. The language can be by reference to a community or to certain relative status and so on. The criteria is specified in the determination and it is perfectly possible that some individual may turn up to be part of the mob later on. That is one of the reasons why, when we get to bodies corporate, we talk about the need still to have a body corporate at least for the purpose of acting in an agency role in order to deal with these situations of fluid membership of the title group. But all these issues are addressed. I do not think they will cause problems in practice.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—Senator Alston, you did say that you were only going to be one minute and you have now been 10.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know but, unfortunately, I do not think the answer is addressing the problem. A claimant would only say, `I'm entitled to an order in my favour because I can demonstrate continuous association'. The claimant would not say, `I claim to be the only one entitled to an order'. So the order is made that the claimant has made out the case and is therefore entitled. But that does not mean that when someone else comes along one needs to vary the original determination. The original determination was simply that X is entitled, not that no-one else is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is wrong. The original determination extends to the area in question, the nature of the native title rights that are involved and who—
—And rules out anyone else.
—No, who holds it. Clause 210 states:

SPEECH.PARA: A "determination of native title" is a determination of the following:

PARA.TAB: (a) whether native title exists in relation to a particular area of land or waters;
(b)if it exists:

SPEECH.PARA: And then it mentions a few other things. It is not a question of whether the claimant holds it; it is who holds it.

The whole point of this is that because native title is largely a communal concept rather than an individual concept—although it may have an individual character in particular situations—it is necessary to get it right as to who the communal group is and what the criteria, the boundaries of the communal membership, are in order to avoid future disputation about who is party to this. I was saying, by way of shorthand, that it is not a matter of identifying every individual as a `who' but identifying at least the class of people and defining with some precision what that class is. They are all the issues that should be flushed out in a proper determination process, thus making it that only in the most exceptional case would one be forced to be involved in a variation of that determination.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) to say that it is exclusive, unless one can prove the basis for a determination. If it is right that the interests of justice require it, presumably there is no time limit on that either. So a claimant could come along some years later and say, `The interests of justice require a variation'. We may have already paid out money and proceeded on a certain basis, yet someone could come along and say, `Well, I'm afraid I was not aware of any of this; our group lived elsewhere and we have now come back' and there will be a very valid claim before us.

—But if one performed a permissible future act within the meaning of the act and compensation and so on or compulsory acquisition moneys have been paid in relation to it, it is not a matter of reopening that and having others come along later and hold out their hands. The legislation makes that very clear.
—But you keep saying that you can do it by agreement, and you can't.

—There can be agreement, sure. But, once the compulsory acquisition is complete and there has been compensation for that, that is it. One cannot go on reopening it into the future. Life is not like that.
—That is the whole point: one cannot do it by agreement; one cannot make an agreement with someone who has not already had a determination which gives good root of title upon which one can rely.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that Mabo itself took 10 years to go through the courts; the minister has told us that by 1 January we will have one registry in Canberra—which has nothing to do with the rest of Australia. How many thousands of people will we need to make these determinations so that people will decide to invest their money and convince their shareholders that it is a reasonable investment? The commercial reality is that, once again, we are demonstrating the uncertainty, the sovereign risk, that is not cured by this legislation. Investors will simply make the decision to go elsewhere with their investments. That is what the empirical evidence is, and that is the way it will continue to be. It is no good saying that one can do it by agreement, because the reality is that nobody will do it by agreement until there is a determination.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not disagree with that; that was the point of my supplementary response to Senator Alston. As a practical matter, it is difficult to envisage agreements being able to be bedded down, unless and until such time as the actual determination is made, particularly if significant sums of money are involved. There may well be indemnity provisions or conditional arrangements reached whereby the matter is not resolved until the actual determination is handed down.

PARA.TAB: As I have already said, in clause 50, the mining clause, there is specific provision to cover that, with moneys being paid into a trust account pending the determination that is involved. But as a practical matter in non-mining areas those opposite are probably right; I do not contest that. Again, what those opposite are tending to overlook totally is that native title actually exists. It is out there right now; it is not being created by this bill. To that extent, there is a problem right now. In this bill we are finding procedural ways of streamlining and resolving these issues on a much faster track basis than would otherwise be the case.

In the context of registry arrangements, I will just indicate what the situation will be. Might I say that I actually misheard the advice I was given before; I was told, not ACT, but AAT. I was advised that the original registry arrangements would be based on the AAT, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, rather than the ACT.

According to the note that has just been given to me, the intention is that from the first working day after 1 January—namely, 4 January—there will be the following initial arrangements: registry offices will be opened in Brisbane, Sydney and Perth; an 008 number will be available for everyone in Australia to call which will have information on each type of application that can be made under the bill, and how to lodge such applications; and there will be initial arrangements made for a president and a registrar. I cannot add any more detail to that at the moment. Obviously, a lot of fleshing out will need to take place over subsequent weeks to fully develop the tribunal and the registration process. But at least those skeleton arrangements will be in place.

As we keep saying, it is important to get these issues resolved as quickly as possible, because people do want certainty. The title is out there; it exists right now, whether or not it is formally recognised as a result of the determination process. It has been acknowledged as such by the High Court. We have to live with that reality and the important thing is to get arrangements in place as soon as possible that will make all those arrangements workable in practice. I have given Senator Bishop rather more information than she asked for and I hope she is duly grateful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: After clause 31, page 19, insert the following new clause:

"31A. Without limiting the scope of any negotiations, they may, where relevant, include the possibility of including a condition that has the effect that native title parties are to be entitled to payments worked out by reference to:
(a)the amount of profits made; or
(b)any income derived; or
(c)any things produced;

SPEECH.PARA: by any grantee party as a result of doing anything in relation to the land or waters concerned after the act is done.".

The Greens' amendment to clause 31A stems from the failure of our amendment to clause 36(2). There is one change in wording to the amendment as circulated. The word `must' in the first line is replaced by the word `may'.

PARA.TAB: This amendment represents a statement of intent. It is a fairly weak statement but it prevents clause 36(2) which gives the impression that this parliament is agreeing to legislation which limits any negotiation aspects relating to mining and other developments so that there is no possibility of negotiating profit sharing. This simply puts it back in the negotiating section rather than the arbitral bodies determination process.

I think there was some misunderstanding in the discussion that occurred when we were debating clause 36(2). This clearly puts it in the perspective which we have in mind. The concern of the Greens is still very much there: the fact that there is nothing within clause 36(2) that requires negotiation to occur; that a time limit may simply expire without all the relevant aspects being covered. This particular amendment, 31A, allows for discussion and negotiation.

As I said earlier, this amendment provides for fairness. It responds to the fact that in the United States and Canada mining companies are well used to such negotiating arrangements with indigenous people. This amendment gives companies the liberty to do the same here. It facilitates negotiations and agreements being made. This reframing of the amendment virtually rules out any of the concerns about veto or right of consent. It simply offsets the negative implications of clause 36(2), under which negotiation cannot occur. It says `may' rather than `must', so I urge the chamber to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Throughout the debate on the previous Green amendment I said that there was a capacity to negotiate profit based or royalty equivalent arrangements, and that nothing in the bill inhibited that possibility. Therefore, it would be a little churlish for the government not to accede to this amendment, and we do.

PARA.TAB: We were troubled by the language in which it was originally circulated, because the reference to negotiations having to—in the sense of compulsion—address such issues. That opened up the spectre of mandamus, prohibition, and so on, simply to get something onto the negotiating table without any requirement that it be the subject of actual agreement between the parties, let alone a subsequent arbitral process. That seemed to us to open up a quite unnecessary further legal minefield. With the language now modified to make it clear that this kind of agreement is not excluded if it can be reached between the parties, we have no objection to it.

As we said earlier, the fact that there is a quite different underlying legal regime in Australia as compared with North America—the US and Canada—and as a result it is not easy to simply translate to an Australian context some of the legal regimes that are in the practices that are in place there, in particular, the non-recognition in Australia of mineral rights and so on, creates a quite different legal background against which these issues are properly looked at. All that said, nonetheless, the notion of royalty equivalent is rather well established in various bits of legislation, including state legislation, around the place. It is not a foreign concept that there should be a proper based agreement in appropriate cases. Just to acknowledge the existence of a capacity to negotiate and reach agreements about that is something that does not add any degree of difficulty to the bill and we support it accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest there might be one other reason why the minister is agreeing to the amendment. If it is true that somewhere along the line the government will accede to an amendment moved by the Greens or the Democrats to make this act subject to the Racial Discrimination Act, clause 36, as it stood without amendment, would fail by way of the Racial Discrimination Act because, quite clearly, it is contrary to section 10(3)(b) of the Racial Discrimination Act, which means that it would have failed in any event. Whether or not by agreeing to this amendment as it has been presented—
—Nonsense—10(3) talks about consent in the Racial Discrimination Act. There is no problem about consent in these situations.
—Indeed; if we take management away or if it prevents getting management back, it is tantamount to a discrimination.
—Management without consent. These are consensual situations.

—Indeed. If there is no way of them getting it back, having consented, it is still in breach. Therefore, whether or not this amendment will save that provision remains to be seen. It also remains to be seen whether or not the government accedes and there is passed an amendment which makes this act subject to the RDA act because there are other sections of the bill which are contrary to the provisions of the RDA act. When we come to that relevant debate, we will point those out too.

—We will come to that in association with our consideration of the body corporate provisions in clause 50, as we previously agreed to do. I suggest that any consideration of RDA issues at this stage is quite premature and inappropriate.
—I ask the minister to correct me if I am wrong, but I thought that some of the American and Canadian freehold had mineral rates.
—That's what I said.
—I thought the minister said that.
—It is a totally different legal environment.

—It is totally different. So if the indigenous people with native rights in those two places have what the minister is talking about, they have the same rights as everyone else. Even on the `may' sort of situation, the government is creating a special right for certain people.
—All you are doing is saying they can negotiate to reach an agreement. There are no inhibitions.
—The minister must admit that it opens the door.
—No. If it did I wouldn't be supporting it.

—At least those words have gone into Hansard. I believe, with my small knowledge of the law, that it is opening the door to such an agreement. If the government wants to open the door to such an agreement, let us do so for everyone else, which I disagree with.
—It may be opening the door for agreements but it is essentially a door that was always open. It is just opening another set of doors.
—To everything?

—No, all it is saying is that agreements are possible. There is nothing in this legislation that excludes the validity of any agreement entered into by a native titleholder with someone which has a profit component in it. It does not add anything other than a declaratory clarity to what is already the law. It is in that sense that nothing is added. Since on the one hand Senator Panizza is saying that the arbitral tribunal cannot force it, it is not without its utility to say, `Notwithstanding that a decision can't be enforced, nonetheless there is nothing to stop the parties negotiating such a provision'.

PARA.TAB: As I indicated, there are plenty of examples elsewhere in the system as it operates now of royalty equivalent payments being made, notwithstanding that the Australian legal system is very different on mineral rights than the North American one. I am just repeating myself; I do not think we need to further prolong this agony.

TALK.START.PARA: —Royalty equivalents and royalties are, I believe, two different things. I know that under the Western Australian mining act parties cannot come to an agreement between me or anyone as a private land-holder and a mining company based on royalty because it has to be registered in the wardens court. If an agreement is made on the basis of royalty, to my knowledge it is struck down. So, to me, this legislation is opening something up. It has nothing whatsoever to do with equivalents.
—It's profit-related. That is the terminology we are talking about here.
—That is what I believe the Western Australian system provides. If it is to be changed at all for native title, then let us change it for everybody else.

—Just to clarify for Senator Panizza what this clause actually says, this can be negotiated and is to counteract a clause that says that these matters cannot be part of a determination. I think he would be equally unhappy if other people were excluded from having a determination made about this which implied that no negotiations were possible. It is simply creating a right to negotiate—nothing further than that. I believe it is in the interests of fairness. It is not any superior rights and it has nothing to do, unfortunately, with the relationship of native title to the minerals under the ground. It is simply a relationship between the people who are seeking to make developments on native title land to allow negotiations to occur at the level which they consent to and not to impose anything but also not to deny anything.

—As I understood it, in the negotiation stage, if one came to an agreement, one could virtually agree on anything one wanted, provided it did not have to go to the tribunal and be approved. But I know there is an amendment coming which, I think, waters that down and says that the agreement can then be approved as long as it is appropriate. Is that right?
—I am just not familiar with that particular clause and I would like Senator Ellison to repeat that, if he would not mind, so that I can get some advice on it.

—I understood that, in the negotiating stages, agreement could be reached on virtually anything; there was carte blanche. The only check was if it were to be registered with the tribunal in order to be enforceable. The criteria that was to be applicable escapes me for a moment. An amendment was proposed somewhere that it had to be appropriate in the circumstances. Is this amendment really necessary because there was carte blanche in what could be agreed anyway?

—The amendment to which Senator Ellison is referring, I am advised, does not bear upon this question of enforcement of the subject matter of an agreement. It relates, rather, to determinations as to whether native title actually exists or not. That amendment bears upon that. It does not bear upon the enforcement of the subject matter of agreements that lie outside the scope of the determination exercise.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question really relates to the whole theme behind the bill, but I think it is relevant to this area. Would the minister agree that, under the bill, native title rights are equated to freehold rights? The minister said earlier that, when compulsorily acquiring land, everything had to be done in the same way as for freehold.

—It is not a matter of actually equating them to freehold rights, it is just that, in various parts of the bill, the freehold test is applied as a benchmark measure of whether governments or others can do things in relation to native titleholders. In a variety of those contexts—remember one of them was riparian right situations and native titleholders having some rights to the use of rivers—there was a reference to what rights in relation to the river the owner of an adjacent freehold title would be able to possess.

PARA.TAB: When we are talking about various kinds of government action being taken—whether by way of granting certain interests over land or whether or not certain acquisition strategies could be pursued—the test in these cases is, `What could government do with equivalent land that was held by a freehold holder?'. That is not to say, by any means, that all native title rights are going to be regarded as freehold equivalent with all the exclusive possession and considerations that go with that. A number of native title rights may be held to be much less substantial than that. They might simply involve access rights, hunting, gathering, foraging and so on. In that situation there will be something conspicuously short of freehold rights being exercised, but nonetheless in order to ensure that those interests, which are very important to the people in question, are properly protected, the limitation of the freehold equivalent test is built in at various key parts of the bill.

Again, I am advised that one of the reasons for this is simply to provide certainty for land management regimes and the people who apply them, as to what can and cannot be done. If what one could do varied in accordance with the particular content of the native title right in question—which might be very substantially variable, depending on the determination made by the tribunal in each case—there would be a constant element of uncertainty as to the circumstances under which we could grant leases, licenses, permits and so on. But if we have a rule of thumb test of this kind, it introduces that degree of uncertainty.

The quantum of the compensation and so on that will flow in particular cases for some impairment of the rights in question will depend on a rather close analysis of what the nature of those rights are and the extent to which they are being impaired. In that context, there will be quite a big difference between rights that are in the nature of freehold rights which are interfered with and rights which are of a much lesser status. If we were just talking about hunting or foraging rights, or something of this kind, when it comes to the compensation question there will be no effective interference, in practice, with those rights and therefore no compensation at all would be payable. That is a perfectly conceivable situation. I hope I have made that clear. It is a test in order to give certainty to land managers. It is not a description of what the weight, the content or the compensability of a particular native title interest may be.

TALK.START.PARA: —From what the minister is saying, it would seem that this bill takes the rights of native title further than would the common law. When we look at the Mabo decision, we see that the bill is perhaps going one step further in endowing rights on native title. Would the minister agree?

—To an extent the honourable senator is right, but it is done for the particular competing public interest purpose of generating certainty. When it comes to the actual payouts and so on that may be involved, we are not really creating a class of privileged people who are entitled to more than they deserve, and who are being compensated to a greater extent than the nature of the impairment of their interest would allow. At that point, we are back to total equivalence with the rest of the community.

PARA.TAB: To the extent that it is crucially important now to get certainty into land management in all those parts of Australia where native title rights may be able to be credibly claimed, it is very important to rather quickly get some certainty—a working rule of thumb—into legislation to make clear what people can and cannot do. People keeping saying, `You don't need this legislation. Just let the courts sort it out', and so on. But we do need a legislative regime like this with all its complexity to cover all these different angles. In the absence of this regime, they would simply be the subject of litigation or endless uncertainty. Putting all the politics of this aside, I would like the opposition to think very seriously about the rationale for this because it is real so far as a number of different interests are concerned in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to this process—I am referring to the right to negotiate—it appears that a tribunal could, in effect, determine that an act proposed, say, by a state government not be done. So the tribunal could say to a state government, `No, you can't do that'. It would, in effect, veto the act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true but it is subject to the public interest override clause. At the end of the day, the tribunal does not have the last say; the executive government of the relevant jurisdiction has it. That pretty crucial provision is in clause 40, which we are about to deal with next—if we ever get on to it. The key provision—clause 40, subclause (1)—states:

SPEECH.PARA: If a State Minister or a Territory Minister—
I presume it is defined for this purpose somewhere; everything else is—

considers it to be in the interests of the State or Territory to overrule the determination of a recognised State/Territory body for the State or Territory, the State Minister or Territory Minister may, by writing given to the recognised State/Territory body, make a declaration in accordance with subsection (3).
Paragraph (3) goes on:
(a) a declaration that the determination is overruled;
(b) a declaration that the determination is overruled subject to conditions to be complied with by any of the parties.

Again, at the end of the day it is anticipated that, from time to time, some overriding public state interest considerations will have to apply. The bill makes provision for that. That is part of the regime that we have developed—part of the balance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course that is provided that the Commonwealth minister is in agreement with what state governments are doing. If the tribunal said, `No, you can't go ahead', and the state government said to the minister, `Will you overturn the tribunal's decision in the state interest', the minister could still say, `No, I'm not going to overturn it because I think your venture is not a good one'. That is really it, is it not?

—No. State governments can overturn state tribunal determinations. Commonwealth governments can overturn Commonwealth tribunal determinations. But the Commonwealth cannot be in the business of overturning state tribunal determinations. That is provided there is a state tribunal.
—What happens if there is only a Commonwealth tribunal there?

—Then we have the field to ourselves. That is why it is pretty smart to cooperate with this whole exercise. That is why those opposite ought to be getting off their tails and getting those state premiers—those recalcitrant state premiers, to coin a phrase—to do that.

—That is the problem. The state can set up its state body only if it conforms with the Commonwealth legislation and the Commonwealth approves it. So, if the Commonwealth thinks the state is not doing the right thing, it is still stuck with the Commonwealth tribunal, of which the Commonwealth minister has control. That is right, is it not?

—That is why it would be very smart for states that want to keep total control of all this to themselves—we are very willing for them to do so because we believe that states should run their own land management—to pass the complementary legislation. That would take us out of the game. We are very relaxed about being taken out of the game here. We want to protect Aboriginal interests. We want to put in place processes to do that, but we acknowledge that in particular cases there is a need for a national interest or a state interest override. This provision is built in there for that to happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the chamber's forgiveness for straying off the topic into clause 40. We will come to that later but—

—Can we finish dealing with clauses 25 to 39? We have been on them all day. Can we do that before we wind up at 6.30 p.m. so that we can have a little sense of achievement? Is it possible to pass those clauses?
—In all fairness, I have hardly spoken today and I think I have a contribution to make. Clause 25(2)(e) states:

SPEECH.PARA: (e) any other act approved by the Commonwealth Minister, in writing, for the purposes of this paragraph.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does paragraph 25(2)(e) relate to the ancillary acts concerning roads relevant to the particular venture, mentioned earlier by Senator Bishop—not the act itself but acts enabling the main act to take effect? It refers to acts `for the purposes of this paragraph'. I was confused by the Minister's reference to the access roads being part and parcel of it. If that is the case, why is this paragraph necessary?

—Paragraph (e) is a reference to any other category of act; it is not a reference to any other specific action taken in relation to some particular site or something of that kind. I asked myself what on earth it was contemplated that (e) might involve. I got the answer that it was just a precautionary provision inserted to ensure that, if some new issue arose which seemed to raise the same sorts of questions of principle and so on as these other categories of things in (a) to (d), then that was a precautionary measure to ensure that one could extend the scope of clause 25 without needing to go back to the parliament. I am equally assured that nobody has any specific such class of acts in mind at the moment. The thought is that this process that is laid out here about right to negotiate should be applicable only to the mining situation and the compulsory acquisition for a third party situation.

—Bearing that in mind, it would seem that this is quite a wide discretion. I am troubled about the limits to the Minister's discretion. Does the government anticipate any limit, or is it set down anywhere? What is the position?

—No, it is not. On the face of it, it is left open for subsequent determination in that respect. It also anticipates some possible definition or problem that might arise in a mining context that has not been foreseen in the way the thing is interpreted by the courts or something of that kind. The discretion is pretty open.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under clause 26, concerning the arbitral body, the Commonwealth minister decides whether the state tribunal is or is not recognised and has regard to subclause 236(1). Detailed criteria are set out in that subclause on how the minister recognises a tribunal or arbitral body. That is all very well, but at the end of subclause 236(2), paragraph (j) states:

SPEECH.PARA: any other requirement that the Commonwealth Minister considers relevant will be satisfied.

All these specifics are gone through but at the end the Commonwealth minister can say, `I just do not like their complexion' or, `I don't like the colour of their hair'—it is a completely wide discretion. Why have that paragraph when, in the first instance, there is such detailed criteria? It seems to negate the benefit of such specific criteria.

PARA.TAB: If a state were to complain, `You have not recognised our body', and quite properly so, it could point to the criteria mentioned and say, `We have satisfied everything and you still haven't recognised our body'. Of course, then the minister could come back and say, `I can take into account anything I like, and I did. You might fit all the other criteria, but I took something else into account and I am not recognising you'. That leaves the state in the lurch, does it not?

TALK.START.PARA: —As with all residual discretionary provisions found in statutes, they are never as wide-ranging as they appear at first sight because they are subject to administrative law principles and, in particular, the criterion of relevance. Any Commonwealth minister who insisted upon some utterly, manifestly irrelevant criterion or requirement having to be satisfied would expose himself to action under administrative law to bring him or her back to the field. It is a precautionary residual discretion designed, as draftsmen usually write these things, to ensure that anything manifestly relevant that they forget is picked up. In just about every piece of legislation containing lists of this kind, we find an apparently open-ended thing at the end, and I do not think this one is any exception.

—This area is a particularly sensitive area for the states, naturally, because it deals with the recognition of their arbitral body. The point I make is that, whilst it is a very sensitive area, it should be carefully catered for. I take the minister's point on administrative law; he is, of course, correct. But the problem we have is that it is easier to argue that the minister concerned failed to take into account relevant criteria than to argue that he considered something which was irrelevant, because we can never really know what the minister addressed himself to, although it might be apparent.

PARA.TAB: I see this as a problem in the relationship between the Commonwealth and the states. For instance, if the tribunal were to make decisions which the Commonwealth did not like, the Commonwealth minister could then revoke recognition. The point I am making is: could that be a relevant criterion? It makes it very difficult for the states to address the failure to recognise situations in an administrative fashion. It is very difficult to get cases up under administrative law when they are brought on the basis that an irrelevant consideration was taken into account. The minister could say, `These things were considered and this is the answer', but, without being too cynical, there could well be other things playing on a minister's mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the truth of the matter is that, in practice, there will be cooperative discussion behind the establishment of any of these tribunals. My understanding is there have already been cooperative discussions of that kind with Queensland and New South Wales. This is simply a way of ensuring that the product of that cooperative discussion, even if it is not precisely confined to criteria (1) to (8), can be taken into account in the establishment of the body. I know it refers only to the opinion or the consideration of the Commonwealth minister, but as a practical matter, we are talking about bodies being established through a consultative, cooperative process. I think that can be expected to produce results which are not at odds with the spirit and, indeed, the letter of this clause. Beyond that, I think the language is pretty familiar statutory terminology and not peculiar to this clause.
—What consultation was there with the states over this area? Was it done as a result of agreement with the states or not?

—There was certainly consultation in the discussions which led up to the drafting of this clause. I would not go so far as to claim that there was agreement with the states about this any more than there was about the drafting of any other clause, but there was general discussion. There has been consultation with Queensland and New South Wales specifically about what the state arbitral bodies might look like. I am advised that those discussions, within the framework of this legislative structure, have been entirely amicable and have not given rise to any concerns at the moment.

—Clause 25(1) provides that future permissible acts that attract the right to negotiate procedures—that is, 25(2)—are invalid unless certain requirements are met. In summary, if a native title party opposes the act, the act will be invalid unless approved by the tribunal or the minister. The minister can overrule the tribunal. To make sure that I am not on the wrong track, is what I have said so far correct? We do not want to go down the garden path unless we need to.
—That is right so far. There is either agreement or the tribunal determines it.
—Is it also correct that a native title party is defined as a registered native titleholder or a claimant?
—Yes.

—If that is right, is it not true that, if the bill were to be passed, a person who we might subsequently discover has no native title rights but who claims native title can invoke the negotiation process which can, in a sense, result in a veto? We can have a whole stream of people claiming native title rights who in the end do not have them but who can nonetheless invoke the negotiation process.

—That is not incorrect in the sense that simply by virtue of being on the claims register does not inhibit someone else lodging a claim over that same area. Ultimately, it has to be the subject of determination. If that subsequent claimant comes along later, the process can presumably, in relation to negotiations, be stretched out to that extent. It will become more apparent when we get to debate—if we ever do—clauses 56 and 57 that, as I have intimated previously, there will be tough provisions governing frivolous and vexatious claims and, more than that, claims which cannot withstand prima facie credibility scrutiny against that sort of test. Under those circumstances, anything in the nature of highly artificial and vexatious claims that were designed to stretch out the process or whatever would have the opportunity of being rubbed out and thereby not extending the practical inhibition that is involved.
—I understand that. I do not know whether the minister intends to beef up those clauses—
—Yes, there is an amendment. It has been circulated.

—The tribunals at the very end may well, on any of these matters, have enough trouble deciding whether a claim is genuine. It is very easy, is it not, for someone just to register as a claimant? What is the process?
—Can we debate that when we get to it? If we debate everything when everything else is being discussed, we will never get to do anything.

—I do not want to debate this process with the minister. However, I would appreciate the minister's outlining what he thinks the process is. He has said, `It is okay, in effect, because there might be a series of these frivolous claims'. How will that be obvious in the first instance? How, in the first instance, is the person who receives these proceedings—if one could call them that—or claims through the post, for example, going to have any idea as to whether they are genuine? There would have to be an almost all-knowing, all-seeing, omnipotent body of knowledge in the Aboriginal community.
—It is not a matter of determining its genuineness, but one of striking out those which are manifestly frivolous or vexatious. No doubt there are bases in practice for doing that.

PARA.TAB: Taking into account what is in clause 56 and what is proposed to be put in by Green amendment No. 22(a), when we get to it, a substantial amount of practical information will have to be supplied, such as the nature of the claimants, the location of the property, the nature of the interest claimed and so on, together with an affidavit sworn by the applicant that the applicant believes that native title has not been extinguished, that none of the area is covered by an entry in the register, and that all the statements made in the application are true and so on. A slightly more substantial series of things associated with the application will be required to be in the bill than is there at the moment.

Moreover, not only will the registrar continue to retain the power to strike out on the grounds of frivolity or vexatiousness; but also it will be possible for the presidential member to determine that the registration should not proceed on the basis that prima facie the claim could not be made out. So there is a quite rigorous test, which is a bit more substantial and useful in practice than a mere frivolous or vexatious test, to that which will then be available to be applied. Between them, those provisions will amount to a sufficient disincentive to any other than serious claims being lodged in the first place, quite apart from going through to determination.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you canvass the prospect of penalties for frivolous or vexatious claims?
—No. It is a big enough penalty to be struck out of the register rather than adding anything else. It is not contemplated that it will be an offence; it would be just struck out.

—I am not raising the question of claims that are made because people genuinely believe that they have a fair chance of having them upheld. The minister says it is easy to be able to ascertain the frivolous or vexatious claims. Why does the government not canvass the opportunity of attaching some sort of penalty? This obviously does not hold up anybody who sees that he or she has some commercial interest; it holds up the whole process for those who want to claim their title. The genuine claims get held up.
—It is a significant matter to attach to anything a penalty of a monetary or other kind. The significant penalty here is that the claim does not get further advanced.
—That's not a penalty.

—The important thing is that the criteria be strong enough and clear enough and that the process be available for claims which are manifestly without any prima facie credibility to be struck out. That will be so.
—I understand what the minister is saying.
—I can't help you any further.

—I encourage him to reflect on his position. I will put it to him this way. If someone puts in a frivolous or vexatious claim, it is fair to say that that person is acting in bad faith. Why should we suddenly say that the only disincentive for people to act in bad faith is that they will get caught out?

PARA.TAB: If one acts in bad faith and messes this process up for all parties involved why should there not be some penalty? People who steal things are acting in bad faith—and we put a penalty on them. People who perjure themselves before a court are acting in bad faith—and we put a penalty on them. People who are contemptuous of court—and to lodge a vexatious claim could be considered to fall into this category—face a penalty.

My concern is not so much in a punitive sense but I want to provide a genuine disincentive to those acting in bad faith. I put the proposition to the minister that someone who is genuinely acting in bad faith and who wants to delay one of these proceedings—possibly for commercial benefit, such as to disadvantage a competitor—has no disincentive to do that other than being told, `If you get caught out, you will get struck out'.

TALK.START.PARA: —In no comparable situation that I can think of would non-Aboriginal claimants or litigants be exposed to a penalty. The penalty of being struck out is penalty enough in these circumstances. That is certainly true so far as the conduct of litigation is concerned. That is probably the closest parallel to what is involved here. It would be a pretty innovative provision to go down that path and one that I would think would be perceived as draconian in the extreme. The government is not interested in doing that.
—I put on record that I regard that as an unsatisfactory answer.
—I will press this point because this is one of the issues which a number of people in the mining industry have raised.
—What about pressing it when we get to the relevant area? Let us get on with the clause that is in front of us at the moment.
—It relates to the topic that the minister has been canvassing with Senator Vanstone.
—I am doing that out of the goodness of my heart with Senator Vanstone, not because it is technically before us now in the committee stage of debate.
—The question is extremely brief. While there is a vexatious claim it makes it almost impossible for a mining company or a pastoralist to raise loan funds. That is one of the big concerns.

PARA.TAB: How long would it take to ensure that a vexatious claim does not remain on foot? If a vexatious claim was tossed out in a week there would not be much to worry about. But if a vexatious claim can remain on foot for months, or perhaps even years, that is a real problem. That would provide vexatious claimants with what they may see as a negotiating position with the person who holds the mining or pastoral lease.

TALK.START.PARA: —The vexatious claim will take just as long as it takes the registrar to strike it out. If the registrar declines to do so, an application is to be made by the competing interest to a presidential member; and it will be dealt with by him or her. There is absolutely no reason to presume that these things will stay around forever. We are not talking about full-blown court proceedings; we are talking about the operation of the tribunal and presiding members of the tribunal. It is in everybody's interest to get the exercise running in such a way that the register is a credible repository of credible claims. One can assume that there would be an incentive of that kind.

PARA.TAB: While I am on my feet, I table an opinion from the Acting Solicitor-General, Mr Dennis Rose QC, about the constitutionality of clause 11 which addresses, as I see it, all the relevant issues, including those raised today by Senator Vanstone. I ask for it to be circulated if that can be managed by the Table Office.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister and I are aware that someone who is being vexatious may well see a chance to get an advantage from a particular leaseholder. Is there no comfort that the minister is able to give in terms of dealing with the vexatious claim, because one person's vexatious claim may well be another person's feeling that there is a valid claim?

PARA.TAB: I put it to the minister that there is a very major concern amongst developers and pastoralists that these vexatious claims can be used as a form of blackmail in order to put pressure on companies. I do not think that what the minister has said will give any comfort at all to those who are genuinely concerned about this matter. Is there nothing more that the minister is able to say?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing more that I can say. These things have to speak for themselves. I remind Senator Kemp again—and it is in the amendment that has been circulated and that will come up for discussion—that it is not only the concept of `frivolous and vexatious' that is ground for declining registration; it is also the concept of not being able to make out a prima facie case. I think that is a more useful test in some ways than the frivolous and vexatious claim, because it goes directly to the substance and quality of the claim, the supporting documentation and so on. For that reason we are not proposing that the registrar apply that test. It is a matter which involves judgment about sufficiency of evidence and so on and, as such, is better made by a presiding member. But I think this is an important further guarantee, as it were, in the way in which the bill will operate and it is one that ought to be applauded by those who are concerned to get maximum certainty as fast as possible.

PARA.TAB: I do think Senator Kemp was overstating somewhat the adverse implications for fundraising, investment, finance and so on of having a native title claim. He can say these things, but he should look at the way in which the rest of the bill is constructed—certainly, the absence of a veto right over mining developments and the capacity for the tribunal to make a determination which, in turn, is subject to override by the relevant government. All of those things should give very considerable comfort to developers and those who finance them that these native title claims should not be regarded as operating to fundamentally inhibit any major economic development.

I am reminded that at any stage of an inquiry relating to an application—not just at the time of registration—the tribunal may dismiss an application if it is satisfied that it is frivolous or vexatious. So even if it gets past a threshold test, when the inquiry gets started and it becomes apparent that the promised evidentiary material is simply not forthcoming or whatever, there is an opportunity again to draw down the curtain. That is covered under clause 140. Similarly, not being able to make out a prima facie case is also applicable at later stages in the proceeding rather than just at the threshold. In all those circumstances, I honestly think that we have gone as far as we can to satisfy that kind of concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not get any reassurance from what the minister has said on that matter and, obviously, he cannot give any more. If a number of claimants are looking at claiming for the same native title, even if they have to put in an affidavit, the minister has not described to the committee any active disincentive for someone to lodge what, on the face of it, would look like a very valid and sensible claim, even if that person or group of people did not have that claim. What is the disincentive?

PARA.TAB: Obviously, when people go into a court of law—not a quasi-judicial body—and put in an affidavit or a claim which is supposed to be valid and legitimate on the face of it, but which is not, they have perjured themselves and there would be some sort of penalty. But in this case, I cannot remember the minister saying that there is any penalty if people put their name to a claim and say that they have had a long association with the land, and if they put down all of the criteria that fulfilled that application—knowing full well that they were not the facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a penalty for perjury, which is in the bill. General Federal Court rules are apparently applicable in the court stage and I presume there is equally a provision in the tribunal stage. The provision of false or misleading documents is covered by clause 167. Contempt of tribunal is covered by clause 169. That is the kind of language one would expect, and it is there.

—I am reassured. I had wanted to raise a matter on clause 26 before Senator Vanstone sped us forward to clause 27. My question related to clause 236(2)(g), the recognised state and territory bodies. As the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) knows, the Commonwealth minister has to be consulted on appointments to the arbitral body. There is obvious concern about why the federal minister would need to be consulted on those appointments. Furthermore, with the power to de-recognise an arbitral body, the minister effectively has the power of veto on every single appointment to it. To me, that is a gross infringement of a state government's right to appoint people to a body that is making important decisions.

PARA.TAB: I simply cannot see why that provision is in there if, as the minister says, the states are being encouraged to use their arbitral bodies. Supposedly, decisions should be devolved as much as possible, yet this creates a system whereby the federal minister has an effective veto over the appointments to that body. If the government is genuinely about staying out of matters as long as the states do the right thing, why is there an effective veto over every appointment to the arbitral body?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think `effective veto' is putting it much too highly. The language of the paragraph should be read in its own terms. It is a requirement for consultation, not for approval, and any attempt to exercise other powers over the whole tribunal simply because of dissatisfaction would pretty obviously run into not only political difficulties but legal difficulties as well in terms of criteria and relevance, except in perhaps some very exceptional case. Might I also remind Senator Campbell that there is provision for cross-appointments from state to Commonwealth tribunals, and that the Commonwealth has undertaken to happily consult in that particular context.

PARA.TAB: The other point I wish to make is the one I sought to make earlier to Senator Vanstone, that the creation of these state arbitral bodies and tribunals is premised on the assumption of cooperation and the establishment of a working relationship. I am told that there have been signs of that developing amicably in the initial discussions about these bodies that have taken place with two states, Queensland and New South Wales, and one would hope and expect that that spirit would carry through. Obviously it is desirable to get people with appropriate qualifications and appropriate sensitivity. It is appropriate that views about just those considerations be swapped, but it is not intended that any veto be applied.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been trying to get a go at this for a while. Senator Vanstone, Senator Campbell and Senator Kemp have been going forward—
—And others all day, so far!
—I wish to draw attention to amendment 15, clause 25.
—We aren't back on that.
—I will not be long. I would like to ask why amendment 15 was pulled. What advice did Senator Evans have not to go forward with his own government amendment?

—In short, as we saw it on further reflection, that was because amendment 15 covered most of the ground that was intended to be covered by amendment 14 to clause 24. In fact, we thought that just about everything that needed to be accomplished by amendment 14 was replicated by amendment 15.

PARA.TAB: I had an exchange with Senator O'Chee about this in which I explained with some precision why it was that the references in the two provisions to 1 January 1994 were effectively identical for all practical purposes in their impact. That is the reason why we did not move amendment 15 and foreshadowed that we would not. Senator Boswell now asks why we do not proceed to move amendment 15, clause 14 having hit the fence. The short point is that there is every expectation—for exactly the same reasons and with the same numbers—that amendment 15 would hit the fence, too. So it is a quixotic enterprise and a waste of everybody's time.

That is not to say that we will not give some further consideration to these matters during the actual life of the legislation. In all the circumstances I think it would be appropriate to do so and I indicated as much in an earlier contribution to this debate. But that can be done in the context of the legislation having passed rather than holding the legislation up for further consideration of this kind. It is unlikely to be productive in the present environment. Certainly, we would give consideration to further changes of this kind in the new year.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—Before calling Senator Boswell, I remind honourable senators that the committee has before it the question that clauses 25 to 39, as amended, be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am on clause 25.
—Well, sort of.
—No, not sort of. I am on clause 25. Amendment 15 concerns clause 25 as far as I am aware.
—Fair enough.

—The fact is that I have yielded to Senator Vanstone, Senator Campbell and others who had an interest in these clauses and have proceeded all day. I thought that they were doing an excellent job. I have not come in here and pushed my point. However, I would like to clarify a couple of points. Would the minister be prepared to table the legal advice which confirmed that amendment 15 was the same as amendment 14? Amendment 16 was also withdrawn. Would the minister tell us why amendment 16 hit the wall, to put it in his terms?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were unable to persuade others who were likely to contribute to a majority on this matter that the change was worth making—that is the short answer for that. We would not have had the numerical support for it. I think the amendment was not a terribly substantial matter concerning clause 25(4). The original clause in the legislation reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the Commonwealth Minister considers the act will have minimal effect on any native title concerned . . .

The amendment was to substitute `land' for the words `native title' so that it read `minimal effect on any land concerned'. I suppose that the use of the word `land' is a more objective test. It does not necessarily presume the existence of native title, which might not be clear until the determination process has been gone through. That is why we thought there might be some virtue in having a lesser test just to look at the land, rather than at the native title which implies the particular kind of usage of that land.

PARA.TAB: We discovered that the support was not there for that amendment and so there was no particular point in moving it. The concept is essentially the same. One has to look at the impact on the land itself in order to look in turn at what the impact on the native title for that patch of land would be. We have to be looking at the same sort of thing. It might have made it a bit easier to satisfy in practice if we limited it to looking at the impact on the land rather than the title. That is the process of reasoning and the politics of that amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am finding it difficult to understand why the minister would say that the government did not have the numbers to proceed on 16; it did not have the numbers to proceed on 14 either, but it chanced its arm on that one. I would have thought that the purpose of the Senate was for the government to put up the amendments that it required and it would be up to the Senate whether it wanted them or not. To work the numbers out would have required only a division.

—Let us not get into a sort of a gossip about the politics of all this; we can do that over a beer at some stage. The truth of the matter is that clause 24, amendment 14, was a very substantial issue, albeit a belt and braces issue, but one in respect of which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had given a very public commitment that we would seek the amendment in question. The amendment to clause 16 was a small, essentially technical amendment, in respect of which no commitments have been given to anybody. It is just a matter of judgment; if we know that we do not have the numbers, and those opposite have not been willing to cross the floor to support the government on any amendments worth having, there is no particular point in wasting everybody's time in pursuing an issue—particularly an issue which, as I say, is not particularly substantial but is essentially technical and in respect of which commitments have not been made.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would hardly call amendment 14 a belt and braces type amendment. It is an essential amendment that failed.
—Why didn't you vote for it then, Ron, if that is the view you had about it?
—Quite frankly, I do not know how the bill will work. I am sure that the bill just cannot work. The Democrats were supposed to support that amendment, and that was the deal the government did with—
—You can't have it both ways. You can't sit there and whinge about it and then vote against it.
—The minister is the one who told the industry and the pastoralists that the government had the numbers to guarantee it, and then the minister let them down very badly.

—I want that corrected for the record. We did not say anything of the kind; we said that we hoped we would have the numbers but we could not guarantee it. I have already described my position on this issue earlier today, and I will not repeat it.
—I understood that there was a guarantee to the NFF that the government could deliver on amendment 14 and—I suppose `ratted' on it would be too strong a word.
—It is not only too strong a word; it is an outrageous word in the circumstances.
—But, nevertheless, it is true.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, I am sorry. Senator Boswell is being a little bit provocative. We have been at this for a large number of hours. To suggest that I or the government had ratted on something in this respect is—

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—It would be appropriate, Senator Boswell, for you to withdraw the word `ratted'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot think of a more appropriate word, but certainly, in not delivering this amendment as the government had undertaken—
—Senator Boswell, do you withdraw the word?

—If Senator Evans is offended by it, I certainly withdraw it. Now that clause 15 has gone, it will be very hard for a large mining company—I suppose, even a small one—which is already mining and extracting minerals when the right to renew comes up; there will now be absolutely no certainty for that mine to continue. In other words, one could spend $20 million, $40 million, $100 million and get through half the active use of the mine to have the mining lease run out. Then one would be forced into negotiation—
—Why don't you ask the Liberals about this, if you feel so strongly?
—It is the government's clause; the minister withdrew it.
—It was the government's amendment.

—It was the government's amendment, and the government deceived itself. How is the bill going to work without this amendment—that is what I am asking? If a mine gets halfway through its useful life and then the company goes into negotiation, which is almost a right of veto—

—There is nothing in this provision which inhibits a mine seeing out the full term of its original lease plus any renewal that is specifically provided for in the lease documentation, in the grants that establish the right in question. All this clause really bears upon is situations where a renewal or an extension is sought after the life of the original lease and any provision for extension that is involved. The worst that can happen in that sort of situation is that we get into a right of negotiation mode. It does not imply the demise of the mining interest and, of course, we have all the provisions that would enable continuity and so on.

PARA.TAB: What we are talking about here is just giving some credence to the interests of Aboriginal people who have hitherto been denied rights in this instance to assert them. We were prepared to guarantee in effect absolute continuity in all circumstances. That was the substance of clause 24 as proposed to be amended. We are still prepared to reconsider that issue at some future stage if the legislation passes without that. But there is nothing in here that should be regarded as inhibiting the effective economic operation of these mines through to their total life. I am sure in practice, in the way in which the dynamics of these provisions work, there will be no inhibition in the life completion of a mine.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully understood what the minister had to say. By the way, that was a government amendment and the government failed to get the Australian Democrats on side. I will not go into that now, but we put our position on every amendment to the bill up-front. That was the only amendment where the government failed to get the Democrats onside. So let us put that into perspective.

PARA.TAB: I fully understand that the minister says that a mine will be allowed to run its full course, providing of course the lease is renewed before it expires. We must remember that a mine does not necessarily only have one life. The minister knows that himself. Some of the Victorian goldfields are now reopening after being closed for so many years. If there had not been such a hostile government there for 10 years, perhaps more would have opened, which would have got the economy going better.

We have to look at the situation where a mine, for instance, closes for economic reasons. Although in most cases the lease may be kept up—in some cases the lease is not kept up—if a different company wants to crank it up again, it is in a hard negotiating situation. So we have that to worry about. I just thought I would put that on the record. Also for the record, I referred to mineral rights owned by other than the Crown or to the Crown owning mineral rights. The government accepted an amendment from the Greens. I think that was dangerous. The minister jokingly suggested that I should declare my interest, and I declare it now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the minister a couple of questions which I do not believe have been canvassed today with regard to the right to mine. I particularly want to address the issue of state agreements. Is the minister familiar with those?
—In outline terms, yes.
—I do not want to go into a long rendition to explain.
—These are special acts for particular project sites. I am familiar with those.

—Earlier in the day it seemed to me that the minister was confused between what were public works and private works. The whole aspect of a state agreement is that it is based basically on private works. I would not go so far as to say that is exclusive, but certainly there would be no state agreement unless it were substantially based on private works. If a state agreement is put together after certain potential has been discovered, will it be subject to tribunal veto?
—My understanding is yes.

—So that means that a mining exploration permit could be granted and minerals could be discovered. The plan could then be put forward for the establishment of that state agreement and agreement reached with the company—Hamersley mining is an example of where a state agreement has been put forward.
