That means that, even though an exploration licence has been granted and the discovery has been made, that state agreement will still be subject to tribunal veto. I want to establish the sequence of events.

—It is possible for that sequence of events to unfold in that way. One of the things that native title involves is a capacity to negotiate and ultimately seek arbitration if negotiations fail on these matters. It is within the competence of the arbitral tribunal to determine that the mine, in this case, not go ahead. But the intention underlying the whole legislative structure is to try to create an environment in which significant national interest or significant economic developments are not inhibited but, rather, can proceed on the basis of appropriate conditions, appropriate compensation and so on.

PARA.TAB: I further remind Senator Crane that in the event that the tribunal should veto or determine against a particular project proceeding, notwithstanding all that background, nonetheless, that is not the end of the matter in the sense that there is the provision for the override by the state minister concerned. We talked about those clauses earlier. At the end of the day, I think most objective people would acknowledge that there is plenty of protection for that countervailing economic interest in these situations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that the minister was not suggesting that I am not objective. There was certainly that insinuation, but I will not take offence at this time. The minister has just told us, in effect, that no major mining company will even bother to look further into the Western Australian situation, in particular, where there have been many large discoveries of a variety of minerals, because the only way that they can develop and become fruitful is if there is certainty. I did not raise this point because I knew it was well canvassed today and I understand that quite clearly. But that is just another level of uncertainty on top of this whole issue.

PARA.TAB: I find it astonishing that if the government had decided that it wanted to close down future mining in the north-west, the west and central Western Australia—I am not familiar enough with the rest of Australia to comment on it—it could not have thought of a better way to do it. That will be to the disadvantage of all Australians but, in particular, to the disadvantage of those people who live locally in those areas. Many of them are indigenous people who will not have access to native title. I do not believe the government has really thought this issue through.

My next question relates to the state agreements. We have established that the tribunal has the right to say yes or no and the state minister has the right to say yes or no. If there is not agreement between the Commonwealth and the state, the Commonwealth minister has the right to say yes or no. We have so many yeses and noes all tangled up that it will drive mining away. It has been brought to my attention that a number of chief executives of a number of mining companies have said that they will go offshore.

My next question is in relation to state agreements. I remind the minister that places such as Paraburdoo, Tom Price and Goldsworthy are mining towns. They were constructed and put there by the mining companies. A number of those towns have now been transferred to public control and there is a system in place whereby individuals are buying the houses. So there is a transfer, I guess, to a more traditional system. Will the tribunal have the right to vary a proposed agreement which has been reached between the state and the mining company in the sense that it might say, `You can do X amount of mining, but you cannot build a mining town there.'? Will it have that power? In other words, can it vary the agreement?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is provision for the tribunal to approve a project's going ahead on certain conditions. I suppose in certain instances the conditions of the mining agreement would have to be sorted out between the state and the company.

—From what the minister has just told us, any major development of a mining operation, certainly in my state, will not even get off the ground because no mining company which had to invest many millions of dollars and often 10 or 15 years to get it to that particular stage would even bother spending the first dollar. What will happen? Brazil, Argentina or some other nation will have a number of Australian mining companies over there just as quickly as they can get there. All I can say to the minister is that he had better have another quick think about what he is doing. This is totally unworkable; it is not in the interests of Australian people; and, in particular, it is not in the interests of indigenous people.

—I would like to ask a few specific questions of Senator Evans. I remind him that I have not really participated in this debate, although I suppose I should have. The situation I outline is real, not hypothetical. Most of the Queensland coalmining leases were taken over areas that held either grazing leases or were freehold. The companies at the time, instead of buying the properties, paid compensation to the landowners to surrender the properties to the Crown; which meant that even under the Mabo decision, grazing and freehold leases had extinguished native title. We now have a situation where that land has become crown land. The mining companies were issued leases and surface rights—
—Once extinguished, always extinguished. It doesn't come back into life because it resumes the status of crown land, even if that were so.
—Where there was previously a grazing or a freehold lease that has extinguished it in the past, claims cannot be made?

—It is certainly our understanding of the High Court decision on this that extinguishment means extinguishment, and not a capacity to revive. That is why we had to make explicit statutory provision for the revival of native title in the context of future grants of mining interests. We worked on the assumption that any grant of a mining interest, just as with the freehold or pastoral lease before it, would accomplish the extinguishment as a matter of common law. So if one wants to keep it from being non-extinguished, one has to say so.
—I understand that that is the Mabo decision. Under the Native Title Bill, does that give additional rights—
—No.

—Where there was crown land—and in some cases there has been crown land where this has occurred—the state government itself, going back into the 1970s, gave various leases of 10 years plus 10 years, or 20 years plus 20 years. It did this for its own requirements. It thought that at the end of the period it may well be able to extract a better deal from the companies that were there or even go out and make another one. Presumably at the end of the 20 years, which was there for a specific state requirement, this then enables native title to be claimed.

PARA.TAB: I raise another point so that the minister can answer two questions in one. As the minister knows, a lot of those leases were for specific purposes. For example, we could mine for coal but we could not extract gas. So when a lease on crown land was offered for 10 years plus 10 years, at the end of that 10-year period, or even in the interim period, a decision was made to give someone either an exploration licence or an authority prospect, whatever it is called in the various states, to extract gas. How would that be affected under this particular legislation?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said, whatever the purpose of the lease and whatever the duration of the lease, it is our judgment that once these kinds of leases are granted, as a matter of common law, native title is extinguished. That has been the situation in the past. It will not be the situation in the future. In the future, once the lease is granted, it will suppress the native title operation only for as long as the lease continues.

PARA.TAB: When such a lease was granted in the past—whether it had been for partial extraction of just one kind of mineral and that had been supplemented by an overlay lease of some kind at a later stage for, say, gas, when it was previously for coal—it would not make any difference. The threshold rule to remember is that extinction means extinction. It is gone; it is dead. It cannot come back; it cannot revive. Everything else follows from that. There is a small element of doubt—which I have mentioned a number of times in responding to the Greens, concerns about this—because it has not been decided by the High Court once and for all that that is so. But the overwhelming probability is that it will prove to be so as far as past valid grants are concerned. I think everything follows from that basic premise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, on 27(2)—
—A new lease of life, have you, Senator?
—I am just trying to move things along, minister. If you would rather I go and—
—If you are going to move things along, you will be unique in this place and your presence would be very welcome.
—We can all do that. We can be more brief in our questions and some of us could be a little less verbose in our answers. It works both ways.
—Oh, for goodness sake; you're not very grateful. I give you a compliment and you complain.
—Clause 27(1), which we have dealt with, basically says:

SPEECH.PARA: The act is only valid if:—
and then it goes down to paragraph (f). But then we have clause 27(2). In effect, clause 27(2) says:
Even if any of paragraphs 1(b) to (f)—
that is, those in clause 27(1)—
is complied with, the act is nevertheless invalid if—
then we go down to clause 27(2)(b)—
the Government party does the act without again complying with the requirements of the Subdivision.
I am asking whether this clause invalidates an act which passes the tests of clause 27(1) if the state elects not to proceed at one time and then changes its mind and decides again to proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no basic disagreement with what Senator Vanstone is saying, except there is a gloss I am struggling to come to grips with about what the trustees' obligations are if money is held in trust in this situation, as is provided for in clause 27(2). Maybe this is saying no more than what Senator Vanstone was saying, but in a situation where decision is made, money is paid to the trustee to hold the money in trust until such time as the question of the determination of title is resolved and then the government says it is not going to go ahead with the act in question, under those circumstances the trustee would pay the money back to the government and no longer hold it because there is no longer any anticipated impairment of the native title when determined. Under those circumstances, it would be ruled out from the government then jumping back in and doing the act in question anyway. If people go through this cycle of making the determination, putting the money into trust, deciding against it and paying the money back via the trustee, they cannot avoid going through all those hurdles all over again before they do the act in question.

—That is really the point because of a couple of fairly obvious situations. A state party might get to that point and then want to give notice that it is not going to proceed and, within a relatively short space of time and for a variety of very practical reasons, it may want to proceed. The consequences of this are that the party would have to start all over again. That is what the minister is agreeing to. Starting all over again could take up to 16 months.

—If it did not we would be in the situation of not having the cash in hand to pay the persons whose rights would be impaired. It is just simply to avoid what would otherwise be the possibility of a technical loophole—the possibility of a circumvention. I do not think any great policy issue is involved here. One would anticipate that, when approval is sought for particular acts and we go through these hoops, things would follow their normal course. If they do not follow their normal course, people run the risk of having to do it all over again.

—I understand what the minister is saying. It just seems that there could have been a way of fixing that in relation to a proposal which had been discarded for one reason or another, then rejuvenated and nothing had changed other than the state's intention to proceed or otherwise. An example might be where a state proposes to grant a title and the applicant elects not to proceed. The state might give notice to that effect and then another person might apply for the same licence.

PARA.TAB: Consider another example where the state might propose to grant a title. Circumstances might change. There might be a natural disaster. Economic factors might change. There might be a change of government. The price of a particular mineral might go down, and the state might not want to proceed. It gives notice for that reason that it does not want to proceed. The original circumstances might rejuvenate. Even though the state is talking about the same proposal completely, the Commonwealth government has provided no mechanism for the money to somehow be put back in trust or to bypass going through that procedure again. Would it not be better to provide some mechanism whereby that position could be bypassed and the money could go back in trust? It seems stupid, for everybody concerned, to start the process all over again. It would be a waste of everybody's time and money.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone has raised an interesting point. I am not sure that there is any great practical significance to be attached to this because it is only if a fairly substantial chain of events occurs and is then aborted that this situation would ever arise. In practice, I do not think that is likely to occur quite as often as Senator Vanstone suggests. I recall a provision where, when dealing with a mine, for example, if the mine area and the mine proposal remain the same but the personnel of the mine applicants change—because there is a change in joint venture arrangements or a change in the nature of the partnership involved—it is possible for the process to proceed without starting again.

PARA.TAB: This is a highly technical issue which may or may not have practical implications. This is the kind of issue that I think could readily be reviewed in the first period of operation of the legislation and, if there is some practical problem evident, it is the kind of thing that could be very easily remedied. Rather than spending any further time on it, Senator Vanstone might accept my undertaking to draw this to the attention of the drafters and the Attorney-General's Department with a view to looking carefully at some possible improvement in the legislation. Senator Vanstone may have a point, but it is hard to perceive on the run whether any remedies are necessary. Since she has not moved any amendments on this or anything else, it is not easy to test it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) and I happily accept his undertaking. I bypass his statement with respect to amendments, other than to say that it shows what debate can do without necessarily raising amendments. Those opposite are the government, and this is their bill—
—Well, I am not sure whether you have a point or not. We will just have a look at it.

—I think the minister can see that there is a point. I am grateful so I will not go on about it at length, but it is all very well for the minister to say that he cannot foresee this happening. I have not looked through his records, but I deeply suspect from the tone of his debate that he has little or no commercial experience and, therefore, it does not surprise me that he cannot foresee this happening.

PARA.TAB: The minister says that it may be a rare experience. I can tell the minister that if people do not have third party property insurance and just once in their lives, in a beaten up old bomb such as 17- and 18-year-olds drive, they smash into a chain of Rolls Royces and cause a chain collision, this rare occurrence, of the kind that the minister does not necessarily foresee happening, can cost people an enormous amount of money. I think that this case is like that. It may not be gamesmanship when parties announce that, for one reason or another, they are not proceeding. It may not be a frequent occurrence that economic conditions change or there is a natural disaster or something such that someone does not want to proceed, but where that is the case and everything else is equal, it seems silly to make everybody start the process all over again. I am grateful that the minister has given an undertaking to have a look at it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a serious matter and we do not really need to go to the extreme of a it-will-never-happen third party insurance example. There are examples, which the government should look at, in projects such as Marandoo, a project that has been 15 years in gestation, the Mount Keith nickel development and, I am informed, the Thai West mineral sands development. All of those are massive resource developments which have had a long foundation period, in some cases taking up to 10 to 15 years to get them through. In the case of Marandoo, it took three years just to get through the environmental impact studies and, against the best efforts of Senator John Coulter and some of the other people, finally get it improved.

PARA.TAB: It is quite possible in each of those cases to have all the approvals in place. Then, because the iron ore or nickel market goes bad, as in the case of Mount Keith, or the rutile or titanium market goes bad, as in the case of the Thai West mineral sands project, all of a sudden they do not want to proceed until things go well. In each of those projects, under the current approvals regime, a process can be put in place to get the state development approval held over until economic conditions change.

There are also examples of other disasters. Natural disasters could occur in a range of industries, which could create this set of circumstances. It is not a far off prospect; it is real world. It is not impossible for a massive iron ore project to go through all of the processes, and the added processes under this native title legislation, and find that, due to a range of circumstances, the state may not wish to proceed. Clearly, to have to go through the whole process again two or three years down the track would be an even greater disincentive to economic development. It is positive for us to see that the minister is taking it on board, but I would not say that it is a flippant point. I think that Senator Vanstone has made a very good point. It is of specific interest to the state of Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It needs to be understood that this provision operates only in a very limited context where, after all that process has been gone through and money has been paid to a trustee, the government or the party in question says that the act is no longer going to proceed and the money is repaid. It is only in those circumstances that this provision would bite in any adverse way. It may be too onerous to go all the way back to the beginning in that odd circumstance, should it arise. That is an issue that we are happy to look at when this legislation is reviewed.

—Under clause 28 a government party has to give notice of intention. The problem I alluded to earlier was that the government had to go through the state process before it could give its notice of intention to act. In the mining situation in Western Australia, the matter has to go to the warden's court which then makes a recommendation upon which the minister acts. It is only after that procedure—and I am not saying that the state procedure is short either—that the Commonwealth procedure kicks in. That is for determination. After that is the determination as to compensation. Was any thought given to a concurrent procedure and whether it could be done constitutionally? I suppose the government would have to say to the states, `Look, you've got to do'—
—Did you say current or concurrent?
—Concurrent.
—It can be done concurrently.

—In Western Australia there would have to be quite far-reaching changes in the state legislation because the government, before giving its notice of intention to act, would have to make sure that it had done so properly in accordance with state law. Can the minister see the problem I am getting at? The government party cannot come within clause 28 until those state processes have been complied with. The only way to hurry that up or make it concurrent would be if the state legislated to have those things done at the same time. Can the Commonwealth see any way around that?

—They can be done concurrently. Moreover, clause 41 enables both things to be done using the same process: the same bodies, applications, documentation and all the relevant issues dealt with at the same time. That situation seems to have been anticipated and dealt with.

—That is the situation when the Commonwealth minister determines that alternative state measures can apply. But the state has to comply with the Commonwealth regime for that to happen. So the state is not free; it is still hidebound in the conduct of its own legislation. It cannot act concurrently unless the Commonwealth minister says, `Well, it has to be done that way or it cannot be done at all'. That is the problem.

PARA.TAB: The state might want to do things differently. The Commonwealth government has said that it wants a unified native title system, but there are different requirements in each state. For instance, the mining law of Victoria is quite different to the mining law of Western Australia. Is the Commonwealth going to say that there is a unified, universal scheme across the country that a state has to fit into in order to be able to do this, or will the government do it on a state by state basis?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ellison is right in saying that the Commonwealth has to cooperate in this process. But the whole intention is to work with the existing state land management regimes. To the extent that there are variations from state to state, it is wholly appropriate that they continue to apply.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth is not in the business of applying uniform provisions across the whole range of land management issues that could possibly bear upon native title. We are in the business of trying to get certain basic protections and procedures established by which those competing claims of right can be untangled and sorted out so that compensation can be granted. Within that general constraint, which is very clearly mapped in the bill, there is ample room for divergence. There will continue to be divergence on the ground. It is in everybody's interests that we operate within the state systems.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the state did not comply with the requirements of its own system and gave notice of an intention to act, would that be an invalid notice pursuant to clause 28(1), or would it be of no moment and just a toothless tiger?

—The provisions in clause 28 only apply if there is no exemption from the process granted under clause 41. These are the provisions that will apply in the absence of that kind of agreement that the state regime can continue to apply in all its glory. As I have indicated, there is a natural bias towards using the state machinery and the state law governing this matter, provided that certain basic provisions are satisfied.

PARA.TAB: These should not be read as implying a determination on the part of the Commonwealth to relentlessly apply its own regime. We would be delighted to operate, as far as is humanly possible, within those state regimes. We do not envisage any great difficulty in negotiating the appropriate arrangements once this legislation is passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of questions concerning clause 29, which is on page 18. This clause provides for people who claim native title rights to be additional native title parties if they do so within two months after the notice is given by the state. Firstly, is there any limit on the number of people who can become an additional native title party?
—No.
—Secondly, is each additional party entitled to participate in the negotiation procedure?

—If Senator Vanstone is talking about every individual within the group having some automatic right to participate in the negotiations, then, no, that is not so. That is the whole point of creating this concept of bodies corporate to operate as agents.
—Well before.
—Once determined, yes. If they are at the stage of being just claimants—
—Before it is determined.

—This is just at the preliminary stage of claims. There can only be rights to negotiate to those groups of claimants that are registered as such. Within the group and how it pursues its right of negotiation is provided for in the bill. There is provision for representation or representative persons to act on behalf of the claimants. That is provided for in clause 56(1)(c). That will remain more or less the same when this clause is amended. I cannot recall whether the numbering will be the same. Clause 56(1)(c) states that the application has to `state the name and address of the person who is to be taken to be the claimant'. Realistically, one has to be able to operate through some individual or some corporate entity as the vehicle for signing up to negotiations at the end of the day once one has a determined status. This is the provision to make that workable at the claimant stage.

—Is it not the case that there is no limit on the number of people who can become an additional native title party because they can make that claim individually? Each party is entitled to participate in the negotiation procedure up until those matters are resolved. They may be able to appoint someone to act on their behalf, but they might want to act or have their say individually. That is the point I am trying to get to.
—Native title party is the shorthand for the competing groups rather than individuals within a particular claimant group. It is true that there can be more than one claimant group.
—I understood that.

—That is where I think it is helpful to contemplate the force and effect of sections 56 and 57 as proposed to be amended which introduce not only the frivolous and vexatious criterion but also the capacity to strike out those who cannot maintain a prima facie claim. That is a partial answer to the practical point that Senator Vanstone no doubt wants to make.

—I was not suggesting that within any one group 20 or 30 people would want to claim individually. But feasibly six or seven people or possibly more who generally perceive themselves to have some native title interest—I am not talking about vexatious people—could want to lodge that and pursue it. It could get very ugly. I will leave that there because the minister can see the point that I want to make with respect to how the government designed this legislation and how workable it will be. Is there provision for a claimant who applies after the two months has expired to participate in the negotiation procedures?
—The answer is no.

—What happens to a nomadic traditional family group that is wandering around and does not find out about the notice until the two months has expired? Are they excluded from participating in that procedure? The minister just told me that they are. One can easily foresee circumstances where there may be more traditional family nomadic groups than the minister or I might envisage immediately who may not find out about this notice until after the two months has expired. This government then says to them, `Bad luck, you're locked out. There is no provision for you.'. Is that correct?
—There are extensive notification provisions including through groups like land councils and so on provided for in clause 28. We have debated this before and it is starting to get repetitious.

PARA.TAB: We have been debating this group of clauses, from 25 to 39, and multifarious extensions thereof through all corners of the legislation, since a quarter past 12 this afternoon. Might I suggest it is about time we moved on to some other clauses.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister might suggest that. I have tried not to take long. I did not take long this morning in my contribution and I have not taken long in what I said earlier tonight. Mr Orr may think that is amusing, but that is perhaps a matter I will take up at another time. I certainly do not think this has taken as long as the second part of that clause took. I put a simple question to the minister about those groups. The minister said there was extensive notice here, there and everywhere. But is the minister's answer still the same—that a traditional nomadic family group that may not be super-sweet with ATSIC, or be remotely interested in it, and does not hear about this until after two months is just dead meat and locked out? The government has no provision to handle such a group. If ever the minister practised and did not get something in on time, there would have been a facility for him to get his out of time matter up. Why has he not provided such a facility for people who would be less likely to get the matter in on time than he would if he were a practising solicitor?

—They are not dead meat in the sense that they get no opportunity to get compensation. That is provided for, notwithstanding that the act will have to go ahead and be taken as valid. It is a short matter of getting a balance of interests here. One half of those opposite was fulminating the other day with great vigour and enthusiasm about how outrageous the longwinded, protracted and uncertain processes were, requiring all this notification and general fooling around, waiting for someone to turn up out of the woodwork to possibly have a claim. The other half of those opposite, as represented by Senator Vanstone, is now fulminating about how outrageous it may be that someone might miss out.

PARA.TAB: There are not all that many nomadic tribes, clans, subgroups or family groups wandering around the outback these days, particularly ones that are having a political brawl with ATSIC, if that is the criterion involved. The truth of the matter is that it is perfectly reasonable to anticipate, under the notification provisions that are here set out and which are designed to be followed and designed to ensure that any reasonable claims are known before acts do occur which are subsequently uncontested. I think it is just part of the balance that has to be struck in any legislation of this kind, and I think the balance to be struck is a pretty good one in this respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that I get a reasonably acceptable answer, this is the last question I want to ask. But I am almost prepared to make an offer as to the contribution that I might make in this debate and the effort I might make to be even more articulate than I have been. I ask the minister to make an equal contribution and to not portray in this debate that he is the source of all knowledge. A word search on the minister shows that his favourite phrase is `the truth of the matter is', as though he is the great possessor of all that is right. If the minister does a word search on that phrase in the Hansard, he will be fascinated by how many times he uses it. What it conveys to people is that he has some full understanding of what the truth of the matter is.
—What have I done to deserve this?
—Just about every time the minister has answered a question he has repeated the phrase `the truth of the matter is'. It is just a way of conning people that he is correct.
—I will say `the fact is' from now on.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Perhaps Senator Vanstone could ask her question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I will. Eddie Mabo was an individual claimant and there were two other individual claimants in that particular matter. Is it possible under the government's bill for individual claims to proceed in the way they apparently did in the Mabo matter?
—Yes.

—Thank you for that. I do not want to go on about it, but when I first asked this question, the minister indicated that if there were others they would probably be operating as groups and it would not be too much of a problem; there would only be a couple of groups here and there. That may be the case, but the case on which the minister based this had people acting as individuals. So we wonder where we get when we ask these questions. I do not have any more questions on that clause.

—I said that I had finished on clause 28, but I want to pick the minister up on one thing. The minister mentioned the cooperation of the states and how it would be a necessary ingredient. Having regard to the attitude of the five or six state premiers who signed that letter today, it does not augur well that the minister will have this cooperation when the states really want to view it one way and the Commonwealth views it another way. What chances of success does the minister think that has?

—I keep giving Senator Ellison the benefit of the doubt, thinking that someone on the other side is seriously interested in the technical issues and is not going to be drawn into vulgar political point scoring and so on. Every now and again he disappoints me, I am afraid.

PARA.TAB: If this legislation is ever passed—we are determined that it will be and we will sit here as long as necessary to get it through—the states, confronted as they will then be with that reality, will have to work out how to live with it best. No doubt they will then take a slightly less jaundiced view than some of them seem to have done this afternoon. It was based, no doubt, on their disappointment that those opposite failed to cross the floor to enable us to pass a particular amendment which they regarded with some significance.

If those opposite had come across, they know perfectly well that that clause would have been passed. They were invited to do so. I waved my arms and invited them. I said, `Look, this is something we are absolutely serious about. You made a commitment about it; come and join us'. Now those miserable people have the disposition to sit back and snipe at us for not being able to control parties that are not our parties, not our people. We did our best; those opposite let us down.

I am quite confident that once this legislation is passed and it becomes a matter of implementing it—with the choices and machinery available, the good sense that is involved in having national approaches to these complex and sensitive issues, and compensation strategies—the kind of cooperation that I am sure will then be forthcoming will be encouraged.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not disappoint the minister for long; we will get back to technicalities. I refer to clause 31, which has a requirement for the state to act in good faith. I notice that that clause does not have the same requirement for the native title claimant. Before dealing with why that is so, I ask who decides whether the state is acting in good faith? Is that something for the tribunal or the Federal Court to work out? How will that be determined?
—Either the tribunal or the court—the normal judicial process would apply.

—Also, why is it that the requirement for acting in good faith is made only of the state and not of the claimant? It is normally a tit for tat situation and what is good for the goose is good for the gander. One would hope that all parties would be required to act in good faith. Why did the Commonwealth not include that for the claimant?
—There are already inhibitions upon the claimant in terms of the character of the claim. It has to be non-frivolous, non-vexatious and have a sufficient prima facie foundation.
—Who is going to be the judge of that?

—We have been through that, Senator Panizza. I am not going to track over it again. I suppose the short point is that the Aborigines are the ones who are making the claim. The problem is to generate an incentive for the states and grantee parties to respond and negotiate in a cooperative and active fashion. The Aboriginals are the demanders and the others are responding to that. The important thing is to encourage them to respond in good faith, not in a way that endlessly protracts the response or does not amount to a serious response to the claim that is being made.

PARA.TAB: Also, the point has been made to me that, in the mining context with which this deals, it is the Aboriginal people who will find themselves with a mine stuck on top of them, as it were. They are the ones who not only stand to gain compensation but who also stand to lose quite dramatically in terms of their enjoyment of the land in question. I think their good faith in those circumstances could be more or less assumed; what may be necessary to encourage is the good faith of those they are dealing with, in order to ensure a fair and just result.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister will recall my submission in relation to the delay in this whole procedure. If we have a negotiating process, what happens if one party just does not negotiate, just will not come to the negotiating table, or perhaps is being evasive so that the matter is getting nowhere, and nowhere fast? Why not have a provision to shorten that period? We have the time there—four months and six months, I think it is—for a prospecting licence and then a mining lease and acquisition. What happens if one party is passive and does not do much at all and the negotiating process is going nowhere; can it be shortened?

—These time limits have been set having regard to experience under equivalent legislation elsewhere and with some knowledge of the real world time that it takes to conduct and progress a negotiation. If we have provision to be rushing off to courts for orders to shorten and so on, there is a danger of that just being, in itself, an unnecessary cause of protraction of the process. To have a clear-cut provision for reference to an arbitral body at the end of a reasonable time frame is probably the best way of balancing out the relevant considerations. It would mean having some incentive to do it properly, but also having not too long to wait if it is not done properly—for it to be done by arbitration rather than negotiation.

PARA.TAB: We could add provisions of the kind that Senator Ellison has mentioned, but they would again be cluttering up the landscape with yet further processes and options for litigation. I thought, on the whole, that that was something we were seeking to avoid.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some questions on clause 31, or at least they are consequential on 31, because they relate to the definition on page 104. I refer to the act attracting the expedited procedure; it is a very narrow procedure. Where the notice states that the expedited procedure should apply and the native title parties do not object within two months, the act may be done without the right to negotiate procedure. Given the definition in clause 222 on page 104 of all the things that the act cannot do in order to be an act attracting the expedited procedure, can the minister give me a couple of examples of what he imagines we would be able to do under the expedited procedure arrangements?

—The assumption is that most forms of exploration licence would probably come within this sort of category, or at least attract the potential for this sort of provision to apply. We are talking about something a little bit more than what was previously described as `low impact activity': camping, beekeeping, car rallies—some essentially transient activity of that kind, which should not properly attract these provisions at all.

PARA.TAB: But there are cases of an intermediate class which clearly do not, by their nature, involve major impairment. They may involve a quite short-term presence; for example, seismic or general exploration activity—rock chopping that geologists do or outcrop surveying or something of that kind. Provided that activity does not interfere with sites of particular significance or with community life and provided that it does not create a major disturbance, it is possible for that to go ahead and attract the expedited procedure, for which provision is made in clause 31. There is still provision for objection and so on to it, but not the whole box and dice of processes that apply when a major substantive impact is involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 222(c) states:

SPEECH.PARA: the act does not involve major disturbance to any land concerned or create rights. . .
Who decides what a major disturbance is? Where are we going to find some meaning for that?

TALK.START.PARA: —Read clause 31(4). If there is an objection by the native title parties concerned, the arbitral body determines whether the act is an act attracting the expedited procedure. It determines whether or not those criteria are satisfied.

PARA.TAB: I draw the attention of the committee to the fact that in the course of this debate we have ranged over, I think, almost every single definition in the last part of the bill. I hope that will be remembered if and when we ever get up to those definitional provisions, because we want to avoid endlessly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting that we adopt an expedited procedure when we deal with the definitions?

—I am just reminding honourable senators that if and when the mood is around or others share my mood in favour of an expedited procedure, I would wish it to be noted that in this unmercifully protracted debate, particularly on clauses 26 to 39, which has taken since 11.45 p.m.—
—But we are on 31. We have moved quite well since dinner.
—We have moved through about three clauses since dinner.
—Well, we only did one up until then.
—It is a 9.45 p.m. There are a mere 207 clauses to go after clause 31. Let us try to move it along, shall we?
—Both sides perhaps.
—Do you want me to answer your rotten questions or not?

—Yes, I do. I just want Senator Evans to cut out the sort of half-baked insults in between. I am not offended by them. I actually quite enjoy a little repartee but it takes up time; it invites a response and we keep going. Then Senator Evans thinks that we are taking too long. He cannot have it both ways.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans mentioned seismic activity in relation to general mining activity. Do I take it, therefore, that the minister is saying that exploratory drilling and seismic surveys would not be major disturbances and that they could be undertaken under the expedited procedure arrangements?

TALK.START.PARA: —One cannot make that judgment in the abstract. Those would be candidates for the kinds of thing that might well come within the scope of this measure, but one would have to look at the effect on the particular communities and on the cultural sites and so on which are also part of the set of requirements that are laid out in clause 222. It is a matter of looking at all three of those criteria together.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought, personally, that seismic-type activity probably would, by itself, not be the kind of thing that would be regarded as involving major disturbance. Even that is a matter for argument because it involves the creation of roads and site lines and all sorts of things. It can make a bit of a mess of the landscape, as one notices flying over areas of intense seismic activity. So it is a matter for judgment. But at least the scope is there to get an expedited process if one can persuade an arbitral body. If one does not object at all there is scope to go ahead without going through all the rest of the paraphernalia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last but not least, in relation to clause 222 (b), how does one know in advance—or does one have to have some sort of hearing or whatever—what is of particular significance in terms of a site? If the minister says, `You'll know that because the Aboriginal people will come and tell you', does one assume that there is no means to ascertain whether that is right or is simply a delaying tactic? Does that, in any event, force the relevant community to disclose what its sites of particular significance are, which they are traditionally somewhat reluctant to do? The minister is saying that if they want to avoid the expedited procedure, they have to disclose them. Do they come up and detail their objection and detail what it is and then someone says, `Well, yes. That is okay'? Is that what happens?

—I could spend an awful lot of time going through every phrase in this bill and saying what it means, how it will work in practice, and who is going to determine it by reference to what criteria, what data and what material, but the point is that an arbitral tribunal is vested with the power to make a decision on this issue on the basis, no doubt, of the material before it. It will make a decision and the criteria is there on which to do so. There are matters of judgment involved.

—It begs the question whether the minister thinks it will take longer or the same time for the tribunal to determine what is an expedited procedure than it would be to follow the normal process. What is the point of it all?

—It is more expedited that the available process for permissible future acts generally, as Senator Vanstone ought to be able to well determine, having given this set of clauses such intense study over the last eight or nine hours.
—If the native title parties object to the expedited procedure, does that mean that there is a minimum effective delay of two months waiting for an objection in each case?
—You can read that for yourself, yes.
—Is there any appeal from a decision of a tribunal that the expedited procedure does or does not apply?
—Do I have to keep standing up all the time?
—I don't care if you don't but standing orders say you should.

—Senator Vanstone is just reading out the bill and asking whether this is the case or that is the case. If she reads the goddamn sections, she can see it for herself. There is an appeal to the courts only on questions of law. That is provided for somewhere, maybe not here. Yet another clause buried in the bowels of the bill will be extracted and laid out for Senator Vanstone's meticulous attention and around we will go again.
—I have a quick question for the minister.
—When is a filibuster a filibuster?
—I think all the questions I have asked have been relevant.
—Not today. You were reasonable on Saturday; you are just going through endless rubbish now.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—Senator Ellison, if you address the chair you will be less intruded upon by interjections.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 32 talks about giving a copy of this agreement to the tribunal. What is the purpose of that and does that mean that the tribunal has some implied power to vary the agreement?
—For its information. It is important that it know all the relevant facts when it is making its decision.
—Will that be available through freedom of information processes?
—No doubt, subject to the operation of those processes.

—Clause 33 relates to the negotiating parties applying to the tribunal for a determination. What is the delay before a party can actually apply for a determination? Is it an eight-month minimum or is it 12 months?
—It says in paragraphs 30(1)(a) and (b) four months and six months respectively. Can't you read it?
—It does but the question is: is the two-months notification taken as part of that time limit?
—Yes it is, and that is what we said earlier in the day.

PARA.TAB: Clauses, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 40 to 44—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the minister's attention to clause 41(f) as an example of requirements to be satisfied. That tells us that one has to take into account matters mentioned in proposed subsection 37(1) which of course is fairly specific until you get to the final omnibus paragraph which states `any other matter that the arbitral body considers relevant'.

PARA.TAB: Even if one took the minister's view that that is legitimately broad, how can the minister possibly explain what 41(f) means when it goes on to say `an appropriately broad range of other considerations'? Surely it is an abuse of the statutory provision to express the requirement in such vague language. Can the minister give us any possible precedent for that? How could he ever find anyone straying outside those terms?

TALK.START.PARA: —It does seem to involve a bit of creative drafting. I must acknowledge—
—I think the articled clerk did it.
—I doubt that an articled clerk would be quite so confidently creative as in this particular subclause. I cannot answer that question except to say—
—It is a plea of guilty, is it?

—Confess and avoid, I think. We just want the Commonwealth minister to be appropriately large spirited in dealing with these particular proposals. I think that is the best I can offer, limp as it may be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 10.Clause 44, page 25, after paragraph (b), add the following paragraph:
"; and (c)all mining leases granted after 31 October 1975.".

This amendment provides for mining leases granted after 31 October 1975 to coexist with native title. This will ensure that Aboriginal people have access to waterholes, sacred sites and other areas of importance to them on those leases.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate the Greens' support.

—We do not like this very much. We told the Australian Democrats that we did not like it before, they know we do not like it and they said that they were not going to pursue it with great vigour. The bill deals with the effect on native title of past invalid grants and future grants, as we know. To make provision in the bill now for the effect of past valid grants would be to venture into rather more controversial territory. This amendment, for example, deals only with the effect of past valid mining grants for which it provides non-extinguishment.

PARA.TAB: Would the Democrats be equally happy with extending other aspects of the regime for past invalid grants to dealing with past valid grants—for example, the provision that past valid pastoral, residential and commercial leases extinguish native title? I imagine they would not. Therefore, it is better to leave the effective past valid grants to the common law. That is a fine spirited response. See what happens when I stick to the script? An amendment of this sort would create significant uncertainty, at least in the minds of those in the mining industry.

The whole point about trespassing onto territory and of the impact of valid grants is that to do it systematically and comprehensively would involve some major redrafting of a number of different areas of the bill. We are content to rest with the notion, so far as the extinguishment issue is concerned, that it is a matter for the courts to determine. We believe that the law is pretty clear on this. The High Court intimated in the leading judgment of Justice Brennan, and in the other relevant judgments that touched upon this, that the principle of extinguishment would apply. But there is some reason for doubt and it is appropriate that it should be the subject of litigation to test that matter once and for all. We have said that on many occasions.

To selectively anticipate the result of that litigation, in the context of mining grants, would raise a whole series of question marks—as I said when I conscientiously read out my note—in relation to other particular kinds of grants that are not the subject of equally robust clauses. We think that this is, by and large, a matter that is better left to the operation of the common law, particularly with very selective drafting of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats obviously disagree with the view that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) has put. However, in the interest of time saving, we shall not prolong the debate on this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 40(4), under the heading, `Time limit for making declaration', states:

PARA.TAB: Any declaration by the Minister concerned must be made within 2 months after the making of the determination.

SPEECH.PARA: Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) tell me: if the relevant minister makes a decision in the negative, does he have to give reasons for making that decision?

TALK.START.PARA: —Which clause was Senator Crane referring to?
—This is why we have consistently said in this debate that it is very important that the minister does not have little chats on the side. The clause I was referring to minister is—
—I was talking about the process and the procedure for dealing with the bill. I am not talking—
—I am quite happy to give the minister five minutes to deal with whatever he has to fix up with Senator Faulkner; that is not a problem. I am afraid that I am going to lose my voice.
—I hope you do. It's not worrying us at all.
—It would not worry Senator Faulkner; but with his level of intelligence, he would not understand what I am saying.

—I have heard the question, I have understood it and I have now satisfied myself as to the answer. The minister is not required to formally give reasons, as such, for his decision. But he is subject, as all these sorts of decisions are, to normal administrative law process. If challenged, he would, no doubt, have to supply reasons, establish relevance and show that no improper consideration had been taken into account and so on.

—It is all very cosy for the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) to hop up and say that but could he please explain why he does not have to give reasons? This is a serious question. When it comes to overruling determinations, it is not good enough to have a situation where no reason has to be given. Can the minister explain why the government has made the decision that no reasons have to accompany this particular clause?

—I have already answered that. The honourable senator must not have been listening. I said that I am proceeding on the assumption that normal administrative law principles would apply in this situation. I said as much about one minute ago in answer to the last question. It is not terribly usual for provisions empowering ministers or anyone else in the executive to give reasons. There are as many examples of that kind of clause as not. That does not mean that the decision can be made for arbitrary or irrelevant reasons. That is a matter that can be tested, I am advised, by administrative law principles applied through the courts in the ordinary way.

—I will make one short comment about that. I think this exposes another fundamental weakness in this legislation. It is another reason—amongst the thousands of others exposed by the debate so far—why this legislation is unworkable.

—I have a few questions which relate to clause 40. I am not quite sure how the overruling is triggered by that clause. Is it all on the part of the minister, or can an affected party seek an overruling? Will the regulations include a procedure for seeking to have a minister overrule a determination? In examining the question of whether or not to overrule, is there criteria that the minister must apply? Does he have to go back to the criteria that the tribunal adopted? How does he know? If he does overrule, can affected parties appeal against that overruling?

—The whole point of the override provision is simply to enable a national interest decision or a state interest decision to be made by a responsible political authority in the event that affected parties believe the other process has gone off the rails in producing a result that is consistent with the national interest. There is no provision for such a decision to be taken on the approach by one or other of the parties. In a sense, it is anticipated here that the kind of decision that would be made and the kind of criteria that would be applied would not be of the kind going to the interests of the individual parties but rather to overriding national interests. It is not just the profitability of a mine or possible investment that would be looked at; it is how important the going ahead of that mine is to the national interest and so on.

PARA.TAB: There is no provision for appeal other than through the judicial review provisions that I have already mentioned. I think they would have an application here as they do elsewhere—at least to ensure that improper considerations were not taken into account in the decision. Essentially, a degree of latitude would be given to the relevant executive government to make the relevant national interest decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) inform the committee whether the decision making process in relation to Coronation Hill would be analogous to the position he has described?

—It would not be directly analogous. Problems about competing interests constantly arise before governments—for example, economic interests versus Aboriginal interests or conservation interests. These are classic dilemmas with which governments are confronted. To the extent that a government decision was made in that instance—not an easy one and not an uncontroversial one—to result in a mine not going ahead, I guess it has some resonance with the sort of situation that would be confronted here. But Senator Campbell can work that out for himself without my having to tell him.

—The point at issue is that, even though the tribunal has a set of quite clear criteria, to some extent the minister will not have and he has to make a decision based on the so-called national interest. The national interest may be as it was in the case of Coronation Hill.

—It is different if one is making a decision pursuant to an express statutory authority rather than just a general cabinet decision. If one has an explicit responsibility to make a decision with at least the criteria set out here—or criterion in each case of interest—one has something upon which it is easier for a judicial review exercise to bite if there is a belief that it is improper. The judicial review process would not seek to second-guess the substantive policy decision. It would only determine that, as I keep saying, improper or irrelevant considerations were taken into account.

PARA.TAB: The whole point of this is to allow executive governments, at the end of the day, to make the necessarily balanced judgment, weighing and balancing the competing interests involved and coming down on one side or the other. If there is an element of corruption or anything else that made the decision an improper one there would be the capacity to review it, but there would not be a lot of scope for that. This is something that has been constantly sought. This is a concession, in effect, to those who are concerned that, for example, insufficient attention may have been given by the tribunal in a particularly important case to national economic interests. This is an opportunity for some redress to be given.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will turn my attention to clause 42.
—It is so wonderfully ludicrous.

—We have a problem here in that we on this side are seeking to move through the clauses in a numerical way. We had an experience earlier which we did not refer to because the chair, in all circumstances up until when Senator McKiernan was in it, was moving in that fashion. He put a question when we had a number of other questions before the close of the last batch and we did not make a song and dance about it. If we continue to have the question put in that way, we will have to jump a little more and it will slow things down. None of us were happy with what happened a few minutes ago.

PARA.TAB: Clause 42, if I am correct, relies on the corporations power. The obvious question to ask is whether the government is using that head of power because it doubts the constitutional validity of the provisions riding on the other heads of power which this bill rides upon. That is the first question.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, just belt and braces.
—Does the government think that the corporations power permits it to regulate the manner in which corporations enter into contracts with Aboriginal people?
—One of the things that I do not have to do in this place is give kerbside legal opinions. There are rules about that, and I do not propose to venture too far into that territory.
—Does the power extend to compelling corporations to enter into contracts without their consent without any intention on their part to enter into a contract?

—It may or may not. That is up to the High Court to determine. The scope of the corporations power has not yet fully been explored, but I do not discern any such compulsion in the text of this bill that would give rise to that matter having to be tested as a result of this bill.
—Clause 44 relates very specifically to the issues that are raised by the operation of the McArthur River mine by Mount Isa Mines in the Northern Territory. Why is this clause necessary at all?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the time of the negotiations over the McArthur River mine project earlier this year, the government's native title proposals were still being developed. The Northern Territory government and the McArthur River mine, the MRM, put to the Commonwealth that early action was needed to ensure the validity of the McArthur River mine leases. They told us this could not await the development of a national solution to native title because the company was approaching a critical decision on funding and that, for this purpose, international investors had to be certain of the validity of these land titles. We agreed to a legislative scheme under which the leases would be validated by legislation passed by the Northern Territory assembly. However, we put it to the Northern Territory government that, in keeping with developing national policy, the leases should not extinguish native title. In a letter dated 25 May 1993 to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said:

SPEECH.PARA: While my government will support legislation to validate the McArthur River leases, we will not support the unnecessary extinguishment of native title. Should you legislate as you indicate, we reserve the option of remedial action with reference to a wider Mabo context.

In the event, the Northern Territory legislation made no provision for the effect of the validation on any remaining native title and, in effect, left this to the common law. To provide certainty, and in keeping with the reservation that was made in the Prime Minister's letter of 25 May, clause 44 of this bill brings the McArthur River leases in line with all other mining leases which are to be validated by means of this bill. In other words, the non-extinguishment principle applies. This means that the holders of any remaining native title in respect of the mining leases validated by the Northern Territory legislation will not be at a disadvantage in comparison with native titleholders affected by the validation provisions of the bill before the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that since the development of legislation in the Northern Territory has taken place in a way that has been satisfactory to the Commonwealth, this is yet another occasion where the Northern Territory is being singled out for special treatment. It has now become very specific in regard to this project. As the means sought to be achieved by this measure have already been covered by other provisions of the bill, clause 44 would in effect be totally unnecessary. I believe that the evidence given by the general manager of Mount Isa Mines for the McArthur River project, Mr Peter Freund, at the hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in Darwin last month very specifically addressed that matter and drew it to the attention of the committee and thereby the government. Did the government reconsider, in light of that evidence—particularly from a very major Australian mining company—the necessity for this clause and did it consider removing it?

—I do not doubt that there was knowledge of the preferred position of the mining company in question, but I have already told Senator Tambling the background to this exercise and referred to the very firm nature of the position taken by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) back in May when he spoke of not supporting the unnecessary extinguishment of native title. We were prepared to act to help out the project and make sure that it could go ahead in the circumstances in which we found it. But we do not believe that, for this project, any more than any other future mining operation, there is any need to extinguish otherwise unextinguished native title.

PARA.TAB: The situation is different for pastoral leases. We have made this distinction often enough. The situation is different when looking into the past because of the need to have some degree of certainty and the presumption that the High Court decision will in the event provide that extinguishment follows in most of these situations. For the present and future, we believe it is appropriate that the non-extinguishment principle apply. We do not see any economic disadvantage associated with that as far as this mine is concerned, any more than any other. That is the background to that decision and this clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the fact that Mr Freund, the general manager of Mount Isa Mines, drew attention very specifically to the investment risks and the experience of the Japanese principals and developers of this important project and made reference to that in his evidence to the Senate committee, I would have thought the government would have taken the opportunity to be mindful of the representations of such an important mining company and such an important project and would have adhered to the requests of that company.

PARA.TAB: The government is always prepared to accommodate the proposals that come forward from the Australian Democrats and the Greens on issues such as this. But any sensible solutions that are put forward by mining companies are obviously set aside by this government. That seriously concerns me.

TALK.START.PARA: —The crucial matter in issue here is guaranteeing the validity of the leases. That resulted—
—Paul said it didn't matter.

—I am talking about guaranteeing the validity of the leases. If Senator Campbell cannot tell the difference between the validity of the leases and the non-extinguishment of the title, he should not be sitting here after all this time because he has not learnt very much.
—I was referring to the inane interjection from the gentleman behind you.

—That is all right then. I find it very difficult to believe that Senator Burns would be guilty of making an inane interjection. I am deeply indebted to find that Senator Campbell does not believe what I assumed he must have, if that interjection had been directed to me.

PARA.TAB: I have nothing further to usefully add on this. The crucial matter in issue was to establish beyond any possible doubt the validity of the mining lease itself, given the uncertainty which would otherwise have existed. That has been accomplished by the Northern Territory legislation. We are prepared to fully recognise and respect that. This is just a provision to make sure that the non-extinguishment rule applies. I find it difficult to believe that that would operate as any kind of a significant financial disincentive to the project proceeding or being financed sufficiently.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am also keen to establish whether the government was attracted at any stage to the possibility of amendments by the Democrats, the Greens or those that were put forward by the Coalition of Aboriginal Organisations working party to this clause. Does the government have any intention of accommodating any amendments or has it made any arrangement that would suggest that in the future there will be any further amendments to the specific clause?
—We have just made it clear that we did not accept the Democrat amendment to clause 44. Is Senator Tambling talking about a specific amendment to the McArthur River clause?
—Yes.
—As I said, the Democrat amendment was to clause 44. We just indicated that we did not accept it, and it has been voted down. There is nothing else in the pipeline of which I am aware.

PARA.TAB: Clauses 40 to 44 agreed to.
Clause 45.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (20)Clause 45, page 26, lines 7 to 10, omit subclause (2), substitute the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(2) For all purposes under this Act in relation to the application, any extinguishment of the native title rights and interests by any of the following acts must be disregarded:

TAB.TAB: (b)the creation of any other interest itself in relation to the area;
(c)the doing of any act under the lease or by virtue of holding the interest.

PARA.TAB: Note:The applicant will still need to show the existence of any connection with the land or waters concerned that may be required by the common law concept of native title.".

SPEECH.PARA: (21)Clause 45, page 26, line 14, omit paragraph (3)(a), substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(a) the determination does not affect:

TAB.TAB: (ii)any interest of the Crown in any capacity, or of any statutory authority, in any public works on the land or waters concerned; and".

SPEECH.PARA: These government amendments have been before the chamber for quite a few days. This particular amendment would require the tribunal to disregard any extinguishment of native title caused by the doing of an act such as the erection of fencing by the holder of a pastoral lease. It would also allow the creation of other interests in land, such as easements or temporary pastoral leases, granted to neighbouring properties to be disregarded.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, where the native titleholders continue to live on the land and work for the pastoral lessee, it would allow the tribunal to disregard any disruption to the observance of customary laws which resulted from actions of the pastoral lessee, for example interference with sacred sites. At the end of amendment No. 20 there is a proposed note, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The applicant will still need to show the existence of any connection with the land or waters concerned that may be required by the common law concept of native title.

The existence of this particular note makes it clear that native title claimants will still have to show that they have a connection with the land in accordance with Aboriginal tradition. The substance of that amendment speaks for itself.

PARA.TAB: The proposed amendment to clause 45 addresses concerns that have been raised by the Northern Territory government. It makes it clear that where there are public utilities, such as water supplies and so on, on pastoral leases where native title is recognised under this clause, they will remain the property of the relevant government. I do not think there should be any contest about the utility and good sense of both those provisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a number of question relating to these amendments. My understanding is that the amendments relate basically to the revival of native title over pastoral leases where it has been extinguished under common law principles. My first question relates to the situation which currently exists in Western Australia. Some 39 out of 400 stations—approximately about 10 per cent—have leases held by Aboriginal interests in a variety of forms. Could the minister explain to the chamber what the status of the stations will be, particularly in view of the fact that this was part of a program that was started in the mid-1980s by the Western Australian government after consultation with a number of groups in the community? What will be the status of those stations under this proposed clause?
—The stations owned by Aboriginal people in Western Australia will be able to be claimed.

—I think the minister has missed the basis of the question. Maybe I need to elaborate on it. In referring to the status of those particular stations, when the minister says they can be claimed, is the minister saying they can be claimed by the owners now or are they subject to a possible claim from other Aboriginal groups?

—This clause is all about the situation where people who would otherwise be native titleholders of the land in question but for the probable extinguishment of that title as a result of common law principles applying to the lease can nonetheless get that native title back if they are the owners of the pastoral lease now in question and if they have that status as satisfying the criteria that they need to satisfy to be determined to be a native titleholder. That is the way in which the clause is intended to operate.
—Now you haven't got it; that is the problem.

—That is what the clause is about. I was just coming to grips with which clause it was. That is the one that involves the de facto revival of native title, the native title equivalent, notwithstanding its probable formal extinguishment in situations where a pastoral lease is acquired or is owned by a particular Aboriginal group which would otherwise have the native title. That is what it means. Those opposite might have some policy objection to it, but I do not think there is too much argument about what it means.

—Once again the minister is jumping to conclusions. Let me try to do it another way. It is clear from the minister's answer that the owners of those stations now, if another group or community of indigenous people cannot have a successful claim—is the minister listening?
—Yes.
—I am letting the minister clarify it. I do not to want to rush him because we need to get the answer right.
—What would you do if you got the right answer? Would you vote for the bill?

—No, but I think it is important that we establish this. I have had requests from a significant number of the current owners of those pastoral leases, who are Aboriginal people, to address these matters and I want to do it properly on their behalf. I am not being flippant; I am being very serious about this. It is clear from the minister's answer that, if no native title can be established by another community, then that can be converted to native title. Do we agree on that? I think the adviser nodded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have to be able to establish what would otherwise be claimed a native title themselves. It is not just a matter of an absence of an effective native title claim from anyone else. The people who are occupying and owning the pastoral lease in question have to be able to establish it themselves.
—So they cannot at some future time have that transferred over into native title?

—No. Just because a person is sitting on a pastoral lease, if he has no common law connection with the land in question that he is sitting on, he cannot convert that to native title. It is only if he would otherwise be able to establish a native title claim. Clause 45(1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: This section applies if:
(b) when the application is made, a pastoral lease is held over the area by:
(i) any of the persons who made the application claiming to hold the native title or any other persons with whom they claim to hold the title; or
(ii)a trustee, on trust for any of those persons; or
(iii)a company . . .

It is not just enough to claim the thing to enjoy the status, then, of taking over. The applicant has to be established by the tribunal to have the appropriate status and has to be determined to be, in effect, a native titleholder. I keep saying `in effect' because this is premised on the assumption that the actual native title has been extinguished as a result of the conferral of the pastoral lease.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the problems we have with this bill—and this also relates to clause 55 and other aspects of the legislation—is the actual drafting of it. There are bits and pieces all over the place, which makes it complex.
—Go on!

—I am going on. It makes it very complex. The minister is finding that out. I am not the only one having problems coming to grips with this legislation. In terms of the establishment of native title, if it concerns an Aboriginal holder who satisfies the requirements of Mabo No. 2 to establish native title then that is clear. What I am trying to establish is the statute provision of establishing native title, which I do not believe one can divorce from the complexities of it. If the minister wants to tell me that I need to ask this question in releation to some other part of the bill then that is fine and I will do it there. What I am trying to establish is its actual status if one group of Aboriginals own it but they cannot establish a native title situation and yet another group—
—They still own it.
—Is Senator Collins trying to be difficult?

—No, I am following where Senator Crane is going. You are referring to where an Aboriginal group makes a native title claim but it is not the same Aboriginal group that holds the pastoral lease. That is what I thought you were getting at.

—That is right; that is what I am asking. It is not a simple issue. Where another group can establish a native title—whatever that bundle of rights might be—what is the status of that particular group that is not the pastoral leaseholder but which establishes native title? Can they in fact have that pastoral lease put into a full native title situation as can be done under statute native title?

—It is only if we get this conjunction of two things happening simultaneously: first, the ownership of the pastoral lease in question; and, second, by the same people who own the pastoral lease, a capacity to claim native title in relation to it. If an Aboriginal group lives elsewhere and is not claiming a pastoral lease but has some credible native title claim—based on history, tradition and so on—to the area of the pastoral lease, that does not help.
—What do you mean by `It doesn't help?'

—It does not help the person who lives in another area and is not the owner of the pastoral lease but, nonetheless, happens to have a native title claim. In the situation which we are talking about, the native title claim would have been extinguished. This is simply an opportunity to convert, in appropriate cases where one has a coincidence of occupancy or ownership of the pastoral lease with a historical right to claim the native title for it, but which has been lost because of extinguishment. It is only when we have those two things together.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Teague)—I take this opportunity to note to the committee that the order for the sittings today does not specify at which time the sittings of the Senate might be suspended. We are just sitting until there is some action. It is past 10.30 p.m., and we could well go past midnight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought a reasonable courtesy would be for the government to tell us what time it is planning to rise.
—On present indications, we will continue sitting until we get the bill.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Hill) put:
That progress be reported.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I follow on from where we were in regard to the stations, to which I have referred, that are now held by Aboriginal interests.
