I understand that this situation exists in other states. I will not go into that, but I am familiar with it in Western Australia. What happens with the stations now held by Aboriginal interests if another community can establish it has native title to them? Can the minister explain the co-existence of native title and the Aboriginal interests that are running those stations?

—Nothing follows under this legislation from the mere capacity to prove native title by some group that is not occupying or owning a pastoral lease. It is only if we have a combination of things happening together: occupancy or ownership of a pastoral lease plus a capacity to establish native title, were it not for the presumed extinguishment. I suppose, as a practical matter, it might well be possible for the `native titleholders' to seek some agreement with the owners or occupiers to take over, particularly if they happen to be another Aboriginal group.
—For compensation.

—No, not for compensation, but to take over the occupancy or ownership of the lease in question and then build a basis for conversion to native title. There is nothing in the legislation to inhibit that, as I understand it. So, as a practical matter, we might get some rearrangement of ownership patterns of Aboriginal pastoral leases. But, by and large, those Aboriginal pastoral leases, as I understand it, tend to be occupied by people who are more likely than anyone else to have a claim to native title of the land in question. We can imagine the situation where that may not be so.
—Not always.
—But mostly.
—There are not too many Aboriginal pastoral property holders in Western Australia. How many are there?
—Ten per cent.
—There are a lot.

—Alright. I was not sure of the scope there. It is getting late. There is a large amount of bits and pieces of information that I may have come across over the years, months, last few days—or hours, for that matter—which I cannot completely recall in all its detail. The legal principles are those that I have described: we do not manage the conversion and there are no other consequences that follow, unless there is the combination of circumstances I have just put.

—I would like to follow this matter through because I think it is very crucial to the harmony of the intent of the government's bill. I know that Senator Collins has a close understanding of this; we chatted about it beforehand. He would help the situation considerably either if he gave an explanation or if he did not interject with comments across the chamber.

PARA.TAB: I re-emphasise that approximately 10 per cent of pastoral leases in Western Australia are held by Aboriginal interests, which is 39 out of 400 stations—a significant proportion. That has all happened in recent years. We have established the fact from the minister's answers that if no native title can be established, it can be converted to statutory native title; and that if co-existence can be established and agreement can be reached between the current owners of the pastoral lease and the people who co-exist with the title, that could be converted to statutory native title.

It begs a number of questions. It highlights the inequity that exists in this legislation and why there needs to be certainty in Western Australia—and I think this is covered by the legislation that exists there, but we are not debating that tonight, so I am not going to go into that.

Is there not an incentive to encourage this to happen because of the fact that there will be no requirement under this bill, once land is converted to native title, to have to abide by the various state laws on control of vermin, noxious weeds, bushfires, and the conservation laws of the land? Is the government not creating a situation whereby that problem—it is a very serious problem—will be encouraged? How does the government require that people in these situations have to operate within those necessary types of law?

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, we are back to the argument about the operation of state laws of general application. It is obviously our intent—and we believe it is obviously the effect of the bill, and no subsequent amendment proposed will change this—that ordinary laws relating to bushfire controls and spread of noxious weeds, vermin and so on continue to operate with their full force and effect. There is nothing in the legislation which would suggest otherwise.

—I am not quite as confident as the minister about that; obviously, we will have to deal with it. I turn to the situations which occur under the Crown Lands Act in Western Australia. This provision will obviously alter the responsibility under the lands act, which has some very specific powers relating to conservation matters. Overstocking is one example, as is the effect of a drought, where country can be closed for a period of time. That occurs not infrequently. What is the situation with regard to that aspect? From a point of view of maintaining the flora and fauna and managing the state in what I would term a proper and ongoing way, it is absolutely essential. Can the minister explain that to us.

—Lessees, whoever they are, would still be subject to the terms of the lease. To the extent that those land management regimes contain many such terms and conditions of the kind that Senator Crane is talking about, they will continue to be applicable.

—So the minister is saying that, even once it has been converted to native title, those requirements will still be covered by the Western Australian Lands Act and the Western Australian Soil Conservation Act?
—Yes.

—The minister told Senator Crane that Aborigines could have control of a station and another group could prove native title. How then can he really say there can never be a compensation claim from one group to another? If a group establishes a native title claim and another crowd is occupying the land, why will there not be?

—I am proceeding on the assumption that the native title has been extinguished by the pastoral lease concerned; that is the clear intimation from the High Court so far as the common law position is concerned. We have not determined that as a matter of statute. It has been left to be further explored if anyone wants to explore it. The working assumption is that the vesting of a pastoral lease extinguishes native title, so there is nothing left to claim. The only claim that one can make is under this particular statutory provision specifically tailored to a situation where there is a conjunction of interests—a conjunction of ownership of the lease in question combined with the capacity to claim `native title' were it not extinguished; that is, the people who own the lease can establish the necessary connection with the land in question and all the other criteria. It is only in this limited statutory situation; it will not arise otherwise.

—If that situation that the minister just described does arise and this other crowd makes a claim, going through all the procedure that we spoke about all day today, would that not tend to halt operations by the group which is occupying the station?
—The others wouldn't get to first base in establishing their claim.

—The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) would be aware that the proposals, under which the land acquisition fund will have considerable resources to enable it to purchase pastoral properties for the benefit of Aboriginal people, will subsequently result in claims to native title in many of those instances. In the case of the Northern Territory, the conversion will probably never be exercised because of the provisions of the Northern Territory Aboriginal Land Rights Act under which the Aboriginal people currently have the right to convert to inalienable freehold title.

PARA.TAB: Given that for the last number of years the federal government has been saying that it would amend the Aboriginal Land Rights Act to preclude the conversion of pastoral leases under the Northern Territory act, I am keen to establish how the minister sees these two pieces of legislation working in parallel or working with some degree of compatibility. Given that there are quite extenuating circumstances, there will now be a slush fund that will enable the purchase of more properties.

To date in the Northern Territory, there has been a considerable number of properties purchased—about 10 per cent of the properties of the Northern Territory have already purchased or have been converted or are in the process of being converted to inalienable freehold title under that provision. Therefore, I ask the minister to clearly explain the compatibility, comparability and the areas where the two fall out of whack, particularly as the government has been intending for some time to remove those conversion rights in the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a conversion provision in the Northern Territory land rights act which allows—at least until 1997 when I think this option runs out under this legislation—conversion to inalienable title under the Northern Territory act. The Northern Territory government—Senator Tambling is obviously following that position—has expressed concerns that the land fund under the legislation we are debating now will be used to convert pastoral leases to inalienable title under the Northern Territory act and hence take advantage of the veto provisions that are associated with that. That is the concern that has been expressed.

PARA.TAB: It is my understanding that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has indicated to the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Mr Perron, that we will not necessarily allow the land fund under this act to be used in this way. My understanding is that there has been some communication of that kind and that has also been repeated to the Aboriginal negotiators on the subject.

It would not be our intention to prevent existing land acquisition programs, whether pursuant to ATSIC programs or ABTA funds, from being used in this way. The matter in issue is the use of the land fund under this bill. We understand the concerns that have been expressed about that and the response is as I have described it. I cannot give Senator Tambling any more detail than that, but hopefully that will be sufficient to assuage some of the concerns Senator Tambling has been spelling out.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) for that response, and I note the government's intention in that regard. I think it is a very important commitment of the government with regard to the use of funds that will acquire from the land acquisition fund. Is the minister in a position to indicate a timetable by which the government will respond to its previous commitments to withdrawing the conversion opportunities and rights that exist under the Aboriginal Land Rights Act?

PARA.TAB: The government has previously committed itself to making amendments to that legislation to again ensure the issues that I have been stressing a number of times in this debate, both in my speech at the second reading stage and at several times during the committee stage. The government is running two agendas. The Native Title Bill has certain objectives and proposals that are not consistent with the continued operation of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act of the Northern Territory and that will lead to a lot of confusion.

Inequitable situations will arise for Aboriginal people across the border in South Australia and Queensland, where very different provisions will apply. I am looking for some sort of timetable commitment from the government as to when it will be addressing the raft of amendments that it has been promising and has been committed to for several years now, but has not addressed. That is why in my speech during the second reading debate I expressed my disappointment that the government did not take this opportunity to bring the operation of the Northern Territory Aboriginal Land Rights Act into a consistent package or operation.

There will be continuing problems and false expectations created for many Aboriginal people because of the operations of these two areas. There are a number of factors that impact not only on the operation of properties, but also on mining provisions and on the various aspects of administration that impact on Aboriginal communities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most I am able to say in this respect is what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said in his second reading speech. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I note too that the bill does not affect rights under Commonwealth land rights legislation. We will be looking at a range of Commonwealth legislation, including Commonwealth land rights laws, in light of the native title regime.

I am not able to give a more specific commitment than that. We will be looking at the question of the interplay and interrelationship between the two. Obviously some very complex issues and some very sensitive policy issues arise. We have not given any great consideration to that so far but, as the Prime Minister said, we will.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I understand it correctly, a native title party who has obtained a pastoral lease is able to convert that to native title. That person clearly has to establish that he would have met all the other criteria for native title except for the fact that it was extinguished. That is correct. I know my colleagues broadly canvassed the issue of other people who may have sought to claim native title over that same or equivalent area. I think I heard the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) say that they would not have a claim because the common law native title has been extinguished under those circumstances.

PARA.TAB: In my mind, there is an inequity there. There could be people who had an equal native title claim over the same area, but because the claim had been extinguished at common law, they could not claim it. However, the people who are able to purchase the pastoral lease will be granted the native title right. So that group of native title claimants, who coincidentally own the pastoral lease, have a claim under this legislation which they would not have had if the legislation did not exist. The other people, who would have had an equal right to claim native title over that area under the common law, to that extent are disadvantaged. A quite significant inequity exists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell may choose to describe that as an inequity. That is one of the consequences from making the concession, in a sense, that is built into the legislation—but not making it on an open-ended basis and going further than a relatively easy step would allow. If the opposition wants to move an amendment to potentially bring more people within the reach of the land rights claim, please feel free to do so. As I have said to the opposition on many previous occasions, we would be prepared to consider the policy implications of that.

PARA.TAB: Again, this is just one of these fine balancing judgments that the opposition makes—the idea being to give at least the semblance of native title to those people who have the good fortune to own the pastoral lease in question and who can establish native title to take advantage of the incidence of that and the dignity associated with it. There will be other people potentially missing out, but I guess they have the option of negotiating a participation in the ownership of the lease. That may be one way through the dilemma for them. But the Native Title Bill certainly does not seek to redress what Senator Campbell describes as an inequity in this respect, although I understand the point that he is making.
Clause 45.

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing concerns me a little about this clause. As the minister has been saying, if native title is extinguished, it is extinguished and that is the end of the story. But here we have a fairly significant exception where in fact it is not extinguished. The minister has been assuring us that pre-1975 pastoral leases extinguish native title, that pastoralists can operate on that basis and that, if it is extinguished, it is extinguished. But all of a sudden we find that in these cases it is in fact not extinguished. Is it the government's overt intention—it may well be—to go beyond the High Court judgment in providing in this way for Aboriginals who have pastoral leases to resurrect native title? If so, why?

—Yes, of course it goes beyond the High Court judgment in that direction—we make no bones about that—just as some other provisions do for the non-extinguishment of mining title, for example, in the future. The working presumption has been that mining title probably does constitute extinguishment, but we have made it clear that it will not have that effect in the future. These are all questions that are yet to be determined. But, in relation to this one, we presume from what was said in the High Court case that granting of a pastoral lease does extinguish title. To the extent that we are making provision for revival of that, we are going further than it.

—One of the things that is concerning pastoralists, rightly or wrongly, is that many of them would love to have more secure or stronger title to their leases. They would love to have freehold title. Pastoralists observe that, under this provision, Aboriginals with pastoral leases will be able to convert them to a title that gives them certain rights and privileges that they do not otherwise have. They, as pastoralists, cannot make that conversion. That is one of the causes of resentment. Could the minister enlighten us as to the policy reason why the government is going so far beyond the High Court judgment and thus causing this concern?

—When Aboriginal people have had their guts ripped out for over 200 years, have been treated in the way in which the white community has basically treated them in this country, when there has been as much depression and despair as there has been, with Aboriginal people having a general sort of lack of confidence in their own future, and with the recognition of that by the rest of the country, it seems a rather small price to pay. But the conversion of these particular leases should be able to be accompanied by a statutory resumption of native title.

—I hope the minister's optimistic view that this is a small price to pay proves to be correct in terms of the considerable resentment and anxiety being caused to pastoralists. In the practical sense, if Aboriginals have their leases converted to native title, what happens if they sell them? Presumably, they can subsequently sell the leases, because leases can be bought and sold. What happens if they do sell their leases? What happens to the native title? Is the native title then extinguished? Is it possible that, having sold the lease, members of the same Aboriginal group could at a later stage actually repurchase the lease and revive again the native title—if they can presumably re-establish the connection or if the connection has already been established? If they have sold the lease, what happens to the people who buy the lease from the Aboriginal group? Can they operate with the security that the native title has been extinguished? Can it subsequently be revived?

—Let me get clear what Senator Minchin is asking. The particular scenario he is painting is that native title equivalent holders who own pastoral leases may choose to sell their leases, for whatever reason, and Senator Minchin wants to know what the status of the native title claim would be thereafter. It would be an unlikely circumstance in which it would be sold; I think we have to make that the working assumption. It is not that there is a legal inhibition on them doing so. It is highly unlikely that people who have struggled through this process to get both the land and the recognition of title would give it away. But that may be so.

PARA.TAB: Under those circumstances, the leasehold interest would be enjoyed on its own terms by the new lessee. Obviously the new lessee would not be acquiring anything in the nature of native title. If that person was not an Aboriginal entitled to make that claim, the native title equivalent would still continue to notionally exist and be capable of reapplication in the event that, at some future time, the pastoral lease was reacquired by the native title equivalent holders.

In the meantime, their status as native title equivalent holders would not give them any particular right to any authority. They would be able to reacquire it, but also, I am reminded, when the lease actually expired they would, in those circumstances, be regarded as having the reversionary interest in the lease—rather than the crown taking the reversionary interest, as would be the usual case. That is the extra advantage—about the only extra advantage—that is conferred upon native title equivalent holders in this sort of situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the acting minister's understanding of clause 45 that, in order to establish native title where an Aboriginal group has ownership of the pastoral lease, the group needs to establish the normal conditions that attach to a native title claim, in other words, that there is a traditional association with the land?
—The fact that an Aboriginal group holds the lease to the pastoral property does not distinguish them in that sense from the processes any other Aboriginal group has to go through.
—Doesn't exempt them?

—Correct. The special and, I think, unique provisions under the legislation provide for an Aboriginal group in the unique set of circumstances where it both holds the pastoral lease and can establish successfully that it is the common law holder of title in the land to make a claim for native title. Under those unique circumstances, the extinguishment of the native title which the lease would otherwise have affected would be set aside.

—Does that mean that they then hold what is elsewhere termed native title equivalent as opposed to ordinary native title? If so, would separate terms and conditions attach to native title ownership in this situation? Consequently, are there any lesser limitations on them disposing of the land?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. I refer Senator Alston to page 5 of the government amendments and draw his attention to the note which will be included in the legislation at clause 45. The note reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Note: The applicant will still need to show the existence of any connection with the land or waters concerned that may be required by the common law concept of native title.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the status of a note? I would have thought a note was only able to be called in aid if there were a doubt. Is that just a layman's explanation of what is contained in that amendment?

—That is correct. I happened to be in here when Senator Evans was providing the whole explanation. The legislative force of these notes has already been explained to the committee by him. The explanation that Senator Alston has provided is correct.

—Following from that, until the government sought to introduce an amendment clause 45 did not require the establishment of traditional association with the land. Therefore, the government is inserting this amendment for the purpose of imposing that obligation.

—No; that is not correct. The bill as printed always required that. The amendment with the addition of the note in layman's language—which I think is the expression that Senator Alston used—makes that comprehensively clear. It was always the intention of the bill that claimants, whether they be on pastoral leases or elsewhere, would have to satisfy the test for native title.

—Subclause 45(2), which has been amended by amendment 20, talks about the acts which will lead to this disregarding of extinguishment. The government has added, as one of the acts, `the doing of any act under the lease or by virtue of holding the interest'. Could the minister tell us what that addition achieves, what its purpose is and what it means? Is the doing of any act to be taken literally? How is that defined? How does anybody know what those acts are?

—The purpose of paragraph 45(2)(c) is to make it clear that it is not simply the lease that is involved—in relation to the question of extinguishment—but the doing of any act under that lease that would also have that effect. Paragraph 45(2)(c) makes that clear. Any actions that might be taken on the lease, that would have the same effect in respect of extinguishment as the lease itself, will also be caught up by the amendment.
—As the government has not been prepared to give us a finishing time tonight, I move:

PARA.TAB: That progress be reported.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to clear up another point in relation to the matter I raised. I was particularly referring to pastoral leases in Western Australia. We have established that if native title can be proved by Aboriginals who own a station then native title exists. If the Aboriginals who own the pastoral lease cannot establish native title they can establish co-existence with another community. I think the minister said that they could do a deal and have the lease converted to native title.

PARA.TAB: When a station is not held by Aboriginals, in other words it is one of the other 361 pastoral leases that exist in Western Australia, what happens then? I am sure the minister is aware that there has been a statute reservation on co-existence around for many years in various forms. Where a lease is held by other than Aboriginal interests and co-existence is established with another group, could they do a deal and convert it to native title?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Senator Crane concerned about Aboriginals occupying a statutory reservation or a common law area within a larger pastoral lease occupied by someone else?
—Yes.
—That is correct only if the Aboriginal people in question are the actual owners of the pastoral lease.
—That is not what you told us before.

—That is not what I said before. If people want to convert a pastoral lease in which the presumption of extinguishment applies to a native title equivalent, the pastoral lease must be vested in them. If it is a matter simply of occupying a statutory reservation area and someone else's pastoral lease, where it is possible, as I said before, that some residue of native title applies because it can co-exist with that statutory or common law reservation, I guess the native title claimants could seek a determination as to whether they do have native title over the area of the reservation. I suppose it is possible—and that would have to be tested.

PARA.TAB: The question is whether the granting of the lease originally, together with the statutory reservation—perhaps at the time of the granting of the lease—did or did not extinguish native title in relation to the reservation area. That would be a matter for determination. We cannot be decisive or definitive about that. It is just one of the situations in which a sliver of native title might still exist. A pastoral lease is the subject area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish the minister would not keep using the word `sliver' because it is misleading in the extreme. I do not believe the minister has thought through the ramifications of where reservations are being held. I am certainly not opposed to those reservations. In fact, I support them. While some people might describe what has happened in Western Australia, the Northern Territory and South Australia as being too little; it is certainly one helluva lot more than what has happened in the rest of the country.

PARA.TAB: I think the minister has a tiger by the tail. Because of the complexity of this, he is creating a whole series of indigenous people or different communities which will find themselves being treated quite differently under the law. They will live on adjoining stations, in the communities or towns around them—or wherever. I do not believe the minister has really thought this issue through.

This particular law under the government's bill—and I say once again that I do not support this bill—could well be suitable on the eastern seaboard—Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria. It is unworkable to provide justice and equity in Western Australia, the Northern Territory and South Australia. It needs to go back to the drawing board and be put in a form where it meets those objectives. Otherwise—and I have already had this said to me by a number of elders in Western Australia—it is going to cause massive and dangerous conflict in a number of communities. I want to put that on the public record because it is important that it is understood that this legislation is dangerously inadequate with respect to the reservations aspect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that Senator Gareth Evans is back from his coffee break—
—Oh, God!

—I needed someone sensible here to answer my question. How long does Senator Evans intend to keep going tonight? We are rather concerned with the state of his health. From this side Senator Evans looks terrible and we certainly do not want to be the cause of some collapse that he might have. He has been taking it fairly heavily. Our compassion is not going to stop us—

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Senator Macdonald, please resume your seat. The question before the committee is that amendments 20 and 21 be agreed to. I would ask honourable senators to address that question.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we do not have an answer, I move:

PARA.TAB: That progress be reported.
Question put.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister was talking about a situation where a sliver of native title is claimed on a station. I presume he does not mean that literally; he means a situation where a claim is made over the whole station and Aboriginal owners may prove that native title. I know—there is a case in Western Australia—that a leaseholder of a station can turn the lease over back to the lands department. That can be done. The lease can be surrendered. What would the case be then?

PARA.TAB: If someone surrenders the lease, all that would remain is a piece of ground with a claim for native title on it. If one has turned the lease in, one would have ceased the pastoral activity—that is, the stock would have to go. In that situation would the holders of the native title still have to abide by the laws of the state as far as the environment and that sort of thing is concerned?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a very big unresolved question as to what kind of native title, if any, would be regarded as surviving in those circumstances. It is the case that, quite apart from the small geographical proportion of a pastoral property on which there might be some statutory reservation or common law right based on occupancy established, some Aboriginal reservations do extend to traversing, hunting and activity of that kind on the lease as a whole. It is conceivable, although this certainly remains to be resolved by the High Court, that to the extent that the complete economic enjoyment of the lease could still proceed consistently with that limited right being enjoyed by the native titleholders, there might be a native title right defined in those terms—the right to hunt, gather, camp or something of that kind. That is possible.

PARA.TAB: If the courts were to uphold that possibility, that would still be a rather limited kind of right. Any other character to the right would have been extinguished by the grant of the original lease. If the lease were to be surrendered to the Crown, the only kind of native title right that would be left in these circumstances is the very limited version that we are talking about that would not have greater character than that. Certainly there would be complete subjection to the ordinary laws of the state in that respect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens will be supporting the first of these amendments—No. 20—and not the second. The amendment which we are supporting corresponds so closely to our amendment No. 15 that we will not present that, but will present two other amendments to this clause. When we come to vote on those amendments, I ask that they be separated.
—What are you moving by way of your own amendments? You might as well do that now so we have them all in front of us.
—by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 16.Clause 45, page 26, after subclause (2), insert the following subclause:

"(2A) The court, person or body, in making a determination on the application, must disregard the effect of exclusion of the native title holders from access to the land by reason of their exclusion from the pastoral lease.".
17.Clause 45, page 26, after subclause (3), insert the following subclause:

"(4) If subsection (3) applies to a pastoral lease the pastoral lease may be surrendered to the State or Territory which issues the lease and the State or Territory must accept surrender of the lease, and on the surrender of the lease, all other interests, apart from the native title interest, are extinguished.".

After subclause (2) of clause 45, page 26, we insert a provision because we do not want people, who in the past may have been removed or driven off the property against their will, to lose the capacity to claim. There is no other provision which allows people who have been inadvertently excluded from this to be excluded from consideration. Basically, our amendment states that:

PARA.TAB: The court, person or body, in making a determination on the application, must disregard the effect of exclusion of the native title holders from access to the land by reason of their exclusion from the pastoral lease.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is an historically accurate incident where they have been driven away, that should not exclude them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a breach of fiduciary duty by another name?

—This amendment would not penalise them. In amendment No. 17 we have a provision to show that, if in the conversion from a pastoral lease for native title it becomes a burden for people to maintain it as a lease, we believe they should be free in their capacity as native titleholders from the restrictions of the lease and be able to surrender that lease. That is provided in amendment 17 which relates to clause 45.

—I am indebted to the Greens for their support of our amendment 20. I am disappointed by the attitude they have taken towards amendment 21. Just because it is advanced by the Northern Territory government, as I said it was, does not mean, ipso facto, that it should be regarded as a bad thing.
—It is an ideological response.
—Then presumably it will attract your support, Senator Alston.

—One would hope so, but that would really be to pursue a false dream. The amendment makes clear that where there exists public utilities, such as water supplies, on pastoral leases where native title is recognised under this clause, they will remain the property of the relevant government. It is a bit hard to see how that impacts adversely on the interests of native titleholders or anybody else. Be that as it may, I note the Greens' position and ask them to reconsider. I hope they will, but I have no great confidence that, in the circumstances, that is likely. So maybe that is another issue that will have to be subject to review at some later stage next year.

PARA.TAB: As far amendment 16 is concerned, the Greens possibly have underestimated the extent to which the real impact of what they are trying to say in that amendment is covered by our amendment 20. Government amendment 20 to clause 45 does make it clear, in determining whether native title exists over land, that any extinguishment caused by acts done under the lease are to be disregarded. Acts done under the lease could include the fencing off of areas thus preventing future access to the land by the native titleholders—in other words, the sort of situation that I think Senator Chamarette has in mind.

The trouble with Senator Chamarette's amendment, which also addresses the situation of exclusion from a pastoral lease, is that we read it as just simply going too far, in effect providing for conversion to native title in these pastoral lease situations, even though the Aboriginal people in question have not had a continuous connection with the land. It is an understandable attempt to deal with situations where at some stage or another people were forced off the land, but we see that a continuing connection of some kind, not necessarily physical, with the area in question in accordance with their customs and laws still needing to be established. We think it goes too far to strip away all of those criteria. There are clear criteria in the common law and we believe they should have some force and effect.

Similarly, I have to say that we have difficulty with amendment 17, which addresses the question of escape from obligation arising under the ordinary terms of the pastoral lease. We see the effect of this provision—whether it is intended I do not know—as enabling those of acquired native title to surrender the native title by converting a pastoral lease and thereby escaping from any obligations arising from the pastoral lease. It is certainly not our intention that by converting a pastoral lease into native title the owners would be able to renounce the pastoral lease and then escape from the obligations which the pastoral lease carries.

The pastoral industry is obviously a very important export earner. We are committed to its future development. We are committed to rational and equitable treatment of all people occupying these leases. Aboriginal owners are an important part of the industry and they should regard themselves as having as much of an interest and obligation as fellow owners in the industry to ensuring that their fellows live up to their obligations in areas such as feral animal and pest control. They are very important obligations to be preserved and we see the terminology of this amendment as undercutting those obligations.

There is also a technical problem about this amendment. The states cannot be required to accept the surrender of a lease where its terms do not provide for this. The Commonwealth under those circumstances would have to acquire the underlying estate from the state in order to accept the surrender itself. I have tried to give some reasoned explanation for our position on those amendments. Regrettably, we cannot accept them and ask the committee to vote against them accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all let me put on record that the Australian Democrats will be supporting government amendment 20 but will be opposing amendment 21 for reasons similar to those enunciated by Senator Chamarette. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (11)Clause 45, page 26, after paragraph (3)(a), insert the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(aa)the native title rights and interests prevail over the lease except that the determination does not affect:

TAB.TAB: (i)any interest of the Crown in any capacity, or of any statutory authority, in any public works on the land or waters concerned; or

SPEECH.PARA: (ii)the interests of any person, other than the Crown in any capacity or a statutory authority, that derive from the lease, and".

This applies to pastoral leases held by native title claimants and provides for native title to prevail over converted pastoral leases. It also protects crown public works on the land and any other interests that derive from the pastoral lease.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are five amendments before the chair. In relation to government amendment 20, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) gave fencing off as an example of the type of act that might be covered by the amendment. In a situation where land had been fenced off 50 or 100 years ago, would the mere fact of fencing off, however long ago it might have been, constitute exclusion? I ask the minister what else would need to be shown, given that he says that one would need to demonstrate a continuing association with the land. Surely the mere fact that land was fenced off at some time in the past is not sufficient.

—It would be if the extinguishment of native title was, in effect, produced by such an action. That is the way my notes read. I am not entirely sure what that means in this context. Let me just discuss it with my advisers. The context in which a fencing could produce an extinguishment—this is using the word `extinguishment' in a rather different sense from the sense in which we have been using it so far, as attached to the grant of a particular interest in land—is really a loss of a capacity to claim a common-law right by virtue of losing a connection with the land in question. That means a drifting away, a losing of any sense of a kind of connection with the land that matters and still matters if a common-law claim is to be established. But the mere fact of fencing off by itself would not necessarily create that kind of a situation. It depends entirely on what the practical effect of that fencing has been. If, no matter what the fencing is, people have still been moving over the land, camping, hunting and doing various things there, it would simply be a matter of fact to identify what the implications of that have been.

PARA.TAB: The other sorts of situations here that are mentioned in my note as being possible examples of the sort of thing that should be disregarded are the granting of easements or temporary pastoral leases to neighbouring properties. I think one could see situations in which that might otherwise be thought to operate as a form of extinguishment but should be disregarded for that purpose in this context.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the fencing-off is the act that is then disregarded, in order to establish a continuing association—which the honourable senator says remains the obligation—surely the essence of the claim would be that we were unable to access the land because of the fence and, therefore, there was not a continuing association? How can the continuing association with the land be proven on the one hand but, on the other hand, it can be argued that a continuing association cannot be maintained because of the fencing-off?

—That would be relevant in a situation where, for example, a particular sacred site is on the land in question. That site may be inaccessible, but it still has dreaming stories about it which form part of the continuing character of the particular community and, while that community may be physically detached from the sacred site, that site is still very much a part of the community's ongoing cultural environment. In this day and age, not many of those sorts of situations are likely to be ascertainable or sustainable before the tribunal. However, that is the kind of thing that the draftsmen and my advisers had in mind in drafting the note in this way.

PARA.TAB: It will always be a matter for the courts to determine what kind of connection will count in establishing a native title claimant's right. It is not to be assumed that continuing physical association is necessarily a part of that, although obviously a continuing physical association will be by far the easiest evidence to establish to the satisfaction of a tribunal. However, we do not want to exclude other kinds. Maybe that example I gave is not a bad example of one such continuing form of non-physical association.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) mean by that that they would disregard the fencing for the purposes of visiting a sacred site from time to time?

—No. I am saying, for the purposes of ascertaining whether or not native title continues, that an act would be disregard which might otherwise have had the effect of appearing to extinguish that native title.
—In other words, if they stayed away because it was a sacred site.

—No, I am not saying that. It would be if they stayed away because they could not get access to the land but, nonetheless, it could be established that there was a continuing association with the land by virtue of the continuing significance of that sacred site in the ongoing cultural tradition whereby people still talked about the hill or whatever.
—Although they were exiled from it.
—Yes, although they were effectively exiled from it. That would be a way of establishing a continuing title or relationship, possibly.
—The mere fact that it was fenced off wouldn't be in any way sufficient?
—Not the mere fact.

—I may not have heard the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) indicating what the government's attitude to our amendment will be as, if he is concerned about the interests of the Northern Territory government, our amendment would seem to cover that.

—I am not sure whether I should read my briefing note on this because it is a bit rude. It says that this is a confusing amendment as taken together with Democrat amendment No. 12. Where is Democrat amendment 12? When is the honourable senator moving that, or has he already done so?
—No, not yet.

—It is not part of this. My briefing note says that the practical effect of the interaction between native title and leaseholders does not appear to have been resolved. It also says that the validity of the lease would not be certain as a result of these amendments. The basic point is that we want the lease to have full force in so far as the commercial, economically relevant rights it confers are concerned.

PARA.TAB: To put it in terms of the native title rights and the interest prevailing over the lease is really to reverse the kind of situation that we have regarded as being necessary in practice for the economic rights associated with the lease to be effectively enjoyed. I think the Australian Democrats are pushing their luck a bit in reversing the order in that way. I think the honourable senator knows that. I hope that Senator Spindler will accept, with as much grace as he can muster, the fact that the government will have difficulty in voting for this.

TALK.START.PARA: —What the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) explained is correct, of course, and it was exactly the intention of our lease.
—You are being deliberately confusing, are you?

—No, there is no confusion. We are of the view, quite firmly, that this would benefit Aboriginal people more than the government's version. If I cannot move the minister, and it would appear that I cannot, we may reconsider our position on 21.

—I would like to express the Greens' concern again that the amendments that we put up have not gained the support of the government. We believe that at every point where native title interests and anybody else's interests are being put in the balance, native title interests are being held back. However, we have to face the reality of the numbers here and we are not going to be able to get that support. We thought that Senator Evans had done such a magnificent job controlling his temper today that we would concede and support amendment 21.
—I want to clarify the Greens' attitude on clause 21. It is not that the amendment has any sense at all; it is simply that Senator Evans has been nice so the Greens are going to vote for it.

—No, we did feel that the Democrat amendment was superior to the government amendment. However, on balance we felt that an absence of any kind of concession in that regard was inappropriate and therefore we have bowed to reality. There is a certain merit to including the change that the government has moved in its amendments 20 and 21. So we are just trying, with reasonably good grace, to improve the legislation where we can and accept where we cannot, on occasions. We will not accept all the instances where we cannot improve it but on this occasion we will. I suggest that it would have been far more constructive if the opposition could also have tried to improve the legislation rather than simply slow it down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the point needs to be made that some of the positions taken by the Greens, particularly in the last few minutes, reflect the growing view of people on my side, and also industry leaders and state premiers, that the Greens are moving down the track that we have seen them move so regularly over the last few months. They have postured, they have suggested that they are going to stop the bill if they do not get their way, but as the crunch approaches they are caving in again.

PARA.TAB: I think everyone in this chamber knows, and the Greens know it themselves, that they will be supporting this bill. It is worth quoting from yesterday's Canberra Times—Monday, 20 December. In a long article about this it states:
Greens senator Christabel Chamarette said yesterday the Greens had "made some headway" in debate on the Bill but it was "still not supportable in its present form".
"It is not looking bad but it is not home and hosed," she said.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is it is moving down the track, it is on the way home and it is probably about to get hosed.

PARA.TAB: The reality is the government knows the Greens' position, the opposition knows the Greens' position, but the Greens do not want to tell us yet. We are nearly on the way there. It is probably in the Greens' interest to play the game a bit tougher on a few other pieces of legislation because the government would start taking them seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think they got public relations advice that they rolled over too soon last time.
—Maybe they should stay on their legs a little bit longer before rolling over.
—Are you just having a general rave?
—Yes, a general rave. Can I get to a substantive issue—
—I want to take a point of order. General raves on the whole are out of order. They are compatible with some kinds of contribution to the debate but—
—Order! Senator Campbell, please resume your seat.
—What standing order is that?
—The standing order excluding general raves is essentially that it be based on relevance.
—That has never stopped people like Collins before.
—You can have a rave as long as it is relevant, but an irrelevant rave is not within standing orders and I suggest that Senator Campbell should be shut up.
—He is coming to the point or else he is finished, one of the two.

—Mr Chairman, I was actually making a quite relevant rave because the Greens just explained to the Senate that they had made a decision to vote for a particular amendment because the minister had been a good boy for a few hours, which we all welcome. But—
—That is a better reason than most they have given!
—Gareth's interjections are better than most of the reasons they have given.

—That is most unhelpful. I will place a bet—if that is parliamentary—that we will see this bill passed with the wholehearted support of the Greens after they have called their compulsory press conference to explain all the terrible dilemmas they have had to grapple with, but they will say that in the end they had to support it because it is the best piece of legislation they have got. I certainly hope I am wrong, but I will lay a bet, Mr Chairman—even if it is with you, even if it is for that bottle of French champagne you owe me—that that is what will occur.

PARA.TAB: But on another issue, not the issue of the Greens voting for these amendments, when the minister was discussing Senator Spindler's amendment he referred to the economic viability of a title form. I was wondering whether he was referring to a pastoral lease, or a pastoral lease that had been converted to native title.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was referring to a standard, common or garden pastoral lease and the importance of preserving the full effectiveness of that lease in terms of the economic rights and interests associated with it. There is no intention of the government to undermine that; that is why we have difficulty in accepting any amendment which suggests that native title should have primacy over an already granted lease, rather than the reverse.

—It raises the question of the government's opinion of the economic viability and the potential to use a native title, or pastoral lease that is converted to native title, as collateral for raising finance and developing the pastoral lease once it is converted to native title. I am sure the government has considered this matter. It would be of concern, not only from an attitude of making sure Aboriginals are able to develop the pastoral lease that has been converted to native title for the future economic benefit of the native titleholders, but also in terms of the general development of regional Australia where investment is required in that property.

—I think I made it clear in an earlier response—and since I have made about 2,500 responses I am never quite sure now what I have said before—that in this respect the `conversion' of the pastoral lease to native title equivalent does not in any way change the character of the pastoral lease itself. It continues in force and effect with all its terms, with all its conditions, and with all its effectiveness as collateral for any loan or security that might be sought. It will be able to be used in that way. That is the clear intent of the legislation and nothing in there suggests otherwise.

—For example, if there was a large pastoral lease which had been converted to native title and if the native titleholders went to the Bank of America or the National Australia Bank and negotiated a normal mortgage and the conditions of that mortgage were not met by the native titleholders, would the National Australia Bank be able to sell that native title on the open market?

—Yes, it could certainly sell the lease. The bank could sell the lease and take over the title and then dispose of it on the open market. That is certainly the case. The native title would be rather like the resumption situation that we mentioned before, would it not? Let me just check. In that situation, the native title equivalent interest would be left dangling with no lease, no physical possession of the land to be attached to it. The only significance would continue to be that, on the expiry of the lease, the native title would in fact resume its full force and effectiveness under those circumstances.

PARA.TAB: This is an important practical issue. The banks will obviously, before lending or continuing to lend on these titles and these conversion situations, want to be confident about the capacity to resume and alienate the land in question. There is no inhibition on their capacity to do just that. Obviously, it is not in the economic interests of Aboriginal people who hold these pastoral leases thus converted to be denied the negotiability of the title in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the minister's or the government's view of the strength of collateral and the form of lien that a bank would get over a pastoral lease which has, coexistent with it, a native title? When the lease is sold, you are left with a lot of land and some improvements, but the improvements are on land which is basically controlled by the body corporate or the native titleholders, so effectively the bank is selling a lease on some land which other people have control of. The strength of the collateral in most pastoral leases these days is pretty low. But the strength of the collateral the government is offering the banks is such that it is quite incredible to think it could even be considered. Further, I would like to know if the government has actually consulted with the pastoral industry and with the financial community in relation to these matters. I think the government is misleading itself if it seriously think banks will lend to a pastoral lease that is based on native title land.

—(12.21 a.m.)—I do not think Senator Campbell is giving a sufficient weight to the point that I am making. It is intended that the pastoral lease continue with its full force and effect as a lease, and that it be fully negotiable. When I say `its full force and effect', I mean the usual characteristic of a pastoral lease—not of all of them in WA, but most of them—which is exclusive occupancy in the traditional, common law sense. So the acquisition of that leasehold interest by a new purchaser, in the kind of situation you are contemplating, would enable the new purchaser to assume exclusive occupancy and to exclude others from the land.

PARA.TAB: It is subject always to statutory reservations and common law reservations which may or may not exist, but the notion of some people still holding the native title equivalent rights in relation to that would not be an inhibition to the full and effective commercial enjoyment of the full character of the leasehold interest concerned. It would be a matter for the banks to make their own judgments. Some of them may be nervous, but it is in the interests of Aboriginal people for them to assuage their nerves in this respect and to acknowledge that the leasehold interests are fully negotiable in this way.

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Evans is saying is that, in that particular circumstance, even whereby the native titleholders own the lease—which is the example we have been talking about over the last couple of hours—they could then—
—You still haven't been able to understand it.

—I think I understand it a hell of a lot better than Senator Murphy does. The native title equivalent is, in that respect, similar to a ground lease situation, where the native titleholders or the body corporate holding the native title would then be able to sell that pastoral lease in the normal form to someone else who would operate it, and who would then have the power to exclude the native titleholders from that property.
—Yes, they could sell the pastoral lease in that situation. Is that the question?
—So the buyer could exclude the native titleholders from the land?
—Yes. If exclusive occupancy is the characteristic of the leasehold in question, as it usually is, then that is possible—again, subject to statutory and common law rights that might otherwise exist.
—With regard to this clause, when native title is established by either process, will it be inalienable?

—Otherwise than by this process, at conversion? Ordinary native title which is achieved by way of determination can be surrendered to the Crown, but is otherwise inalienable. I just checked on whether it is also applied to the native title equivalent situation that you could obtain in the context of a pastoral lease, and that is also surrenderable to the Crown. But it is otherwise inalienable. But remember: that is the native title interest, as distinct from the leasehold interest. The lease itself—which may well carry with it, and usually does, full-scale exclusive occupancy rights—is alienable, either voluntarily or in effect compulsorily, if it is a bank resumption in the event of a mortgage failing.
—Could the minister expand a little more on the bank situation? I think he was referring to bankruptcy—
—Not a bankruptcy. I have been talking about this bank business for the last 20 minutes.
—I have been listening, but you did not come to the crux of the question that I asked.
—I will, but first tell me the crux of your question again.

—I am trying to establish how an inalienable title stands in commercial terms, say, in the case of a pastoral lease. How can collateral be obtained for the development of that property? If the title is inalienable, how can it be offered as security? That is the crux of my question.

—The question seems to be: if you have got a successful native title claim over previously vacant land, where there is no question of a continuing pastoral lease, what kind of collateral is available for the native titleholders to put up so as to attract a financial institution to lend on the strength of that? I suppose the short answer is that that collateral would not be especially attractive because it is inalienable.
—It is one of the reasons why Aboriginal people may well choose not to do it, Senator Crane.

—There will be other sources of finance presumably from ATSIC or possibly, conceivably, a land fund; although, whether that will be available to support improvements or whatever on land, as distinct from the purchase of land itself, is yet to be determined. However, there are some inhibitions. It is not intended that native title thus granted be able to be easily given away. It can be surrendered to the Crown, but that is it; otherwise, it is inalienable. The other situation we have been talking about relates to what one can do with a pastoral lease when one has a native title equivalent in association with a pastoral lease. That is a very different situation from a pure native title situation over land that does not have any leasehold interest associated with it.

—I thank the minister for clearing that up. But as far as that answer goes, I can see some problems for people who are holding a native title in getting to a position of commercial independence. My next question follows on from that. As I understand it, under the Mabo decision, if the traditional owners were to leave the area the native title would be extinguished. What is the position when native titleholders leave their area, particularly when the title is held by a body corporate?

—The mere fact that native title has been determined to exist and the mere fact that that native title interest happens to be vested in a body corporate which is in the existing statute, or the mere fact that it is held in some other way but with a body corporate playing a role as an agent and so on for native titleholders, would not affect the possibility of that native title being over time extinguished by loss of connection with the land over which the title has been obtained.

PARA.TAB: It is possible that in the future, just as has happened in the past, native title will be extinguished, will be lost, will just disappear in a situation where the relevant and necessary connection with the land, be it physical or spiritual or whatever, is in fact lost. I suppose it would be difficult to envisage that happening in a future where it is a matter of native title being newly established and determined and vested in a body corporate and so on, because it is hardly likely that people are going to let that go. However, it could be a very small community; maybe the members of it die out; maybe there is no-one left to maintain the continuity and in that way the native title is lost. That can happen in the future just as has happened in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the minister that it would be something that was rare rather than infrequent but it does establish the fact that there is more than one way in which native title could be extinguished: one is what he explained before, that is, when it can be sold to the government; the second one is where the connection is broken by virtue of the fact that the traditional owners decided to leave for whatever reason. There are two questions that arise from that. After leaving, for whatever reason, what would be a reasonable period of time before the native title would be extinguished, and are there any other ways by which native title can be extinguished?

—I cannot answer that question directly because the High Court has not given us a total set of guidelines for the way in which this will operate. This is a matter to be developed, I suppose, on a case-by-case adjudication by the High Court and, indeed, by the tribunals as to what will constitute the acquisition of native title and what might also constitute the loss of it. I simply cannot anticipate that. We are talking about common law with only one real case spelling it out and it is necessarily a process of evolution hereafter. I would like to be able to help the honourable senator further but I simply cannot. We have not been given enough guidance by the High Court so far to be able to reply fully to him.

—What this highlights is that we are now dealing with the government's response to the High Court decision, and that response has gone far beyond the High Court decision in many areas. I am saying to the minister that there are a lot of areas where he has felt it not necessary to be guided by the Mabo decision. I am not making a judgment in this comment one way or the other about that, but I am asking the minister, in view of the fact that he said that when extinguishment would be something for the tribunal to assess, whether there is any provision in the bill—and if there is, maybe he can help us—where that can actually happen. The position of the tribunal and the framework within which they can operate are spelt out pretty clearly, but I do not see any provision in the bill where they actually have that authority.

—The tribunal's job is to determine the status of claims that are made, applications that are made, for native title. All I am saying is that, in the course of determining those sorts of claims, some ground rules are bound to evolve about what kind of connection is sufficient to constitute a native title that ought to be recognised. No doubt there will also emerge some decisions about what kind of loss of connection with the particular land will lose what would otherwise perhaps constitute native title.

PARA.TAB: I am not saying that the tribunal has got the power under the legislation as drafted to specifically make a judgment that a newly granted native title right at some future time has been lost. I am not saying that it is in the bill in that form, but what I am saying is that the process of case by case determination of what constitutes a valid native title claim is bound to give us some guidelines, one presumes, over time as to the sort of connection that is necessary and what circumstances will lose that necessary connection. The court itself will no doubt have something to say.

I am reminded that actually we were talking about that earlier today, in relation to clause 12. There is provision to seek a revocation of an approved determination of native title. One such circumstance is where events have taken place since the determination was made that have caused the determination to be no longer correct, or the interests of justice require the variation or revocation of the determination. I suppose one such situation might be a small community where all the surviving members of it in fact die out without a continuity of a family line or some other physical manifestation of the interests in question. Under those circumstances a mining company or a pastoralist, or whatever, might seek a revocation of perhaps the native title right which remains notionally held in a body corporate but which no longer has any facts on which to bite. In that sort of circumstance maybe a body of case law that would affect that would evolve over time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge what the minister says in terms of clause 12. I have got to say I have great difficulty trying to work out precisely what it means and how it would be applied. But what it highlights is, once again, the enormous complexity which exists in terms of this bill. I think it also highlights that, even to the point that we have got to now in terms of the complexity and the inconsistencies, really to proceed further with this bill is just getting the minister deeper and deeper into water. It is time really to stop and have a look and reassess this legislation because it is very seriously flawed, as has been noted by many of the questions, and of course acknowledged by a lot out in the community.
